Maybe I  should buy another pair for ten years down the road...***(Additional comment added March 2014)***A friend recently asked about the headphones I had plugged into my iPod. I let him listen to them and he was blown away. I told him to look for them on Amazon as it was one of the few places I've still seen them available at a reasonable price. Thirteen years after I wrote the original review above, and about twenty five since I purchased them, they are still going strong. Not many things last that long--outside of body parts.  :)

I and my sons listen to audio books a lot, sometimes on long trips my son will listen all day.  These have proven to be comfortable with excellent sound quality.  My sons are 12 and 14 years old, and although I tell them to be careful with these headphones as they are somewhat expensive, they are still just kids.  They haven't broken them yet!

I had a pair of Sennheiser HD 208's i believe, man these things DESTROY them. First of all they aren't tight, at least on my head, so they rest comfortably. Second the sound quality is AMAZING! no wonder they've had these cans selling for decades! if you have an eq on your pc, then you can raise the bass a little if you're feeling frisky (lol). I use them for some mxing and casual listening and they're great so far! Anyway with that said these headphones are great and at $50 (when i bought it) they rival a lot foof the higher end headphone! Definitely in my recommendation for a good set of headphones!!

another positive review for this, surprising it's relatively cheap compared to other budget headphones. nothing more to add than what's already said, this one is definately one to add to your collection, even if this is the only one in your collection

Nice clear sound with nice quality build. Only down for me was the weak bass.I mainly use the headsets for my computer to play games - FPS, LOL and others with lots of action and explosions and other entertainments listen to rock and Trance music and movies. Basically, all of my entertainments are done on my computer...If you are not into heavy bass, like Beats Pro, then this is for you.

I have had many other headphones in my time. When I cam across these pair from a friend, I fell in love with them. Someone stole my first pair so I bought another for me and my girlfriend. We love listening to music with these bad boys. They  have solid bass response and you can hear distinct instruments with the songs!

I am extremely picky about headphones and these are the best that I've ever had.  Quality from top to bottom.  Sound quality is incredible, comfort level is perfect, the cord is solid and long enough to give you room to move.  I couldn't be happier with this purchase.

These headphones are great! They give what some people call a flat sound...just the way an acoustical instrument woud sound in a room without an echo. In other words no excentuated highs, basses or midrange. They are ruggedly constructed for professional use. They are also pretty comfortable with one slight drawback. The plastic padding around each phone fits so snugly around my ears that my ears eventualy get a little too warm.Buy them. You wont be sorry.

Perfect headphones for Mixing.  A very neutral sound that allows me to clearly differentiate frequencies,  If you are just getting into recording music, buy these.  You can't beat the price for value.

When the MDR-V6 were introduced it took me a year to get a pair.They wandered off still working great..IMO you just can't find better sounding 'phones without spending twice as much.They are snug on larger heads/ears but comfortable for most.True to the source I use them w/ my Onkyo A-8700 integrated & AudioControl 10.They perform flawlessly.

Sony MDR-V6 Monitor Series Headphones as good as Grado SR325 more comfortableYes they are that good.  I have the SR225, and SR325 which are the higher end of the Grado lineup.  The Sony MDR-V6 are extremely crisp treble and nice full basses.  I think they produce a more true to life voice than the Grado.  Sony's are infinitely more comfortable too.  Day to day use I'm on the Sony.  The Grado's are sitting on the shelf these days.The bad side is that some of the cable (around the headphones themselves) is a bit on the narrow gauge side. Not sure how that will last over long term use.
summary: Sony MDR-V6 Monitor Series Headphones as good as Grado SR325 more comfortable

reviewText: These have the best headphone sound I've experienced (i'm no audiophile) but the price was right and I'm happy with them.
summary: Love the sound, a little uncomfortable after extended periods of time

reviewText: Good product build plus excellent lack of leakage- can we worn at work close to others.
They're pretty good.  Other reviews have beaten it death, so I'll leave it at that.
summary: They're pretty good. Other reviews have beaten it death

reviewText: I am a tentative flyer and needed a good pair of headsets that would eliminate the noise of the plane, has great sound, and doesn't break the bank.  I use them with my iTouch and they are fantastic.  I bought some padded ear cushions thinking I would need them, but I didn't.  These are very comfortable.

The first thing that you should do is stretch out these headphones until you no longer feel them gripping your head when you put them on. You should feel more force on the top of your head than on the sides. Otherwise, you're going to get a headache. For the longest time, I thought that the headaches I got while wearing them were just because I wasn't used to them yet.Aside from the headache issue, they're the best headphones I've ever had. I love the stretchy cord (helical, like an old corded phone). The audio is fantastic. I just compared them to my GF's MDR-ZX100 ZX, and the difference is night and day.
summary: Sound great, but headache-inducing if you don't strech them out

reviewText: Maybe it's the fact that the first song I listened to was Pearl Jam's "Yellow Bedletter." Perhaps the nostalgia is clouding my senses. Perhaps it's the Pink Floyd that followed. Maybe it's just that it's Friday night, and after the realization that my employer views my fellow employees and I as easily replaceable as Band-aids--and equally detestable as used Band-aids--I'm just relishing my own time and the simple satisfaction of cruising through my play-lists randomly to test out these new headphones and remember a time when I was a stupid kid and the whole wide world laid before my feet, thinking I could wedge myself and my mind into any professional crevice that suited me. Whatever it is, I'm in a sort of sublime revelry right now. Not sublime in any sense of unknowing, band-name reference that just calls out vocabulary I hope others will automatically connect to.No. This type of sublime is like standing on the highest point in Hell's Canyon and being instantly dwarfed, feeling the raw power of a place that is so overwhelming in size and power that I feel my place in this universe for what it is. Tiny and irrelevant to the overall flow of time and space. It's like the realization that after dying, my only purpose would have been to feed worms, if we hadn't decided to load our dead with preservation chemicals that make us unpalatable to any living thing, but still knowing that what I leave behind in family and works will be just enough to live on--that sort of hope mixed with despair. Honestly it feels good.These friggin cans halve the background noise when put on, even with no music. Once the music starts, I can't even hear the "Teen Mom" my wife is watching, or the video game my son is playing. I can't hear the kids next door shouting and gasping at a dumb frat boy breaking a beer bottle over his head. The screaming drunk girl in the apartment across the way is gone. By the time Blind Melon starts, and I've poured my third beer, this spot on the couch feels every bit as eye-opening as any teenage first-time experience.I know there's better over-ears available. I know that there's better output for audio. However, at my income level, this is the most magical thing I've purchased in the last year. This is almost better than the native Idaho cutthroat I caught on a fly I tied myself, standing waist deep in a river without those waders I can't afford, fighting current that wants to wash me into the rapids only a few feet away, where the North Fork of the Clearwater drops suddenly into a raging narrow channel, reaching into the icy water to hold a final remaining natural vitality for a brief moment before setting it loose again, wading back to the purple granite beach to sit in the sun and smell the watery pine shores of a single remaining wild river.This audio experience, as modest as it may be in monetary terms, has filled in a hole that is usually spent gazing into the void and contemplating the nothingness canonical authors can only address by describing its boundaries.If you want nuts and bolts, the coiled cord is thick and firm--with a heft that says the money I saved to buy this will last a while. The pressure on the ears is as comforting as falling asleep against the breasts of a new lover. The sound quality is the best I've ever experienced--so much better than a worn out Toyota's stock speakers or a second-hand Macintosh or a cheap Phillips stereo system dressed in clear-coated maple to make it seem like a luxury. I'm hearing qualities, details, and performances in this music that I didn't even know existed. I could literally sleep in these headphones, and just might now that our thrift store couch is empty of family and friends, waiting with worn cushions and ratty blankets for someone to curl up and float through a flashback of carefree days when drugs, alcohol, and cigarettes could possibly kill me, not that I'd live long enough to ever know. Now, mostly sober, with aching feet and knees, I'm the most comfortable I've ever been in my own skin.Thanks, Sony. It sounds sad, and trite, but this first delving into a private little world of huge sound has ripped away a tired, bitter mind and ironed youth back into my ears.

I'm a DJ and having the (actual) sound relative to your mixer is great! It is so important to hear what your'e playing rather than be fooled by most other headphones that have auto EQ adjustments like a punchier bass or modified treble. It also makes it much easier for beat matching with the crisp and full sound of the MDR. Very well made. Very light which is great especially if you wear them for long periods of time. Great ear coverage which is a must when trying to listen to two tracks at once [= Also are sleek and look excellent. Industry standard headphones here. If you want to listen too your music as the artist intended then get these! Full range of sound, deep bass and crisp treble, these headphones just don't fake it like the others.
summary: Wondeful. sounds like I'm really there

reviewText: I bought my first MDR-V6 around 1980 (possibly even earlier but my memory is foggy on exactly when I got it). Round about 2011 the left side stopped sending sound. Up until then, for over 30 years, those headphones were as good as the day I bought them. I retired them and bought a second set. On the first day the outer seams on the lining covering the foam padding came undone on one side. About a week later the inner seams on both sides started to come undone. Now the outer seams are unattached on both sides. The sound is still good, but the craftsmanship is very disappointing. 5 stars for sound and comfort - minus 3 stars for poor craftsmanship for the model I purchased.
I bought these headphones to use at home and at church.  I am involved in the multimedia ministry at my church and these really do a great job.  You won't be disappointed if you get them.

I received these headphones a couple of weeks ago, and have been using them occasionally.  Last night, one of the ear pads slipped off.  My son has a pair of headphones with a similar design, so he told me to just unclip the center of that earpiece and slip it back on.Turns out that the center of the earpiece on my headphones can only be removed by unscrewing four screws.  Once the piece is removed and the ear pad is slipped back on, the screws are covered up!  We reattached the ear pad with some shipping tape at one edge (to hopefully keep it from slipping off again), and screwed the screws back in while it was folded back away from the screws.  Once that effort was completed, we had to slip the flimsy edge of the ear pad back into a very narrow slot and stretch it all the way around the fixed plastic part of the earpiece.  That step was a nightmare!Now these aren't the most expensive headphones out there, but they aren't bargain basement priced either.  The edge of the ear pad that slips over the ear piece is extremely flimsy, so I'm sure the other ear pad will slip off very soon.  And the way that the ear pad attaches to the earpiece was designed by an idiot!The sound quality of these headphones is great, and the comfort is excellent as well.  But I would recommend that others buy some headphones that will stay in one piece for longer than two weeks!

Just get these please and do yourself and your ears a favor! The audio quality is truly outstanding and for the pricetag is unbelievable, which is why I believe many people hesitate on buying these... they could be compared at 1000 dollar audiophile heaphones easily

First bought these back in 1995 along with a Sony diskman with my first paycheck. These headphones have been used along with my Sony Diskman, iPods (gen 1, 3 and 6), home stereo and gaming pc's since I got them. It has outlived most of the tech I had plugged them into and kept on kicking until a friend stole them. Bought a replacement pair in 2009 on Amazon and just got around to reviewing them.These headphones sound great when I first bought them and still do now. They opened my ears to cleaner sounds when listening to music that default electronic headphones don't pick up.I have taken these with me while riding the bus, long car trips and on the airplane. They can be compacted to be taken on the go and stuffed in a bag. So they are very portable even come with a leatherish bag to be carried in. They are very comfortable enough to be worn for extended periods of time. Even taken long naps and slept with them over night. They do make your head warm after extended hours of use but that goes for any over the ear headphones. They are very adjustable you can wear them on one ear and the other behind the head and wont fell like your head is in a vice.Only problem I ever had with them is that the earpads start to flake off after a while. But you can get replacement pads that don't flake. But I cant knock the rating down for that since I had these for such a long time and since it has outlived several gaming headsets just to get plugged back in.

I bought these as a gift for someone, and not being in the music industry I would say these are the best sounding headphones Ive ever used. As far as quality headphones go these are very well priced, come in a nice box if you want to gift it- the sound was amazing

I bought these headphones in the 2012 Black Friday. All I can say is that these headphones offers an incredible quality/money value. Stunning sound (good bass levels, trebles, highs and so on) and great quality materials is what you get with the MDR-V6.  Sony did an excelent engineering work here. This headphone model is for some reason a classic favorite in its area. I've heard people saying they had these heaphones working with no problem for around 10 years!.I totally recommend them.
summary: And that's why Sony is Sony.

reviewText: These headphones are very comfortable and worked nicely for about 6 months.Maybe I'm hard on my headphones but I think for the price I paid ,they should last longer than 6 months.
After only having it a week it has a short in the plug. Had to send it back to Sony. Dealing with their people and maneuvering around their phone system hasn't been the easiest task.

so sweet and sublime, there isn't anything here that shouldn't be.  great separation and pure, rich sound as it was intended.  awesome, flavored with old-school cool.  buy a pair and find out for yourself.  rock on.

OK, so my last set of headphones were only $20, and I've apparently been missing out!  I had done some research on response across the frequencies, and these popped up as nice and consistent across the range when compared to a number of others often even 2x-3x more.Now I feel like I just moved from VHS directly to blue-ray (skipping DVDs) in sound quality from my old set of cans, and I am potentially hearing the music as the artist intended!!  I can even feel parts of the music now and new parts have come to life that I hadn't previously noticed in some of my favorite songs!

Amazingly comfortable, low profile, very well built, and the most clean, uncoloured sound I've ever heard in a pair of headphones. I recommend these above any pair of headphones. They sit VERY comfortably on the head - you'll forget you're wearing them. They fold up nicely, but they're built VERY sturdily so you wont be afraid of breakingthem.It should be noted that i work in music and audio engineering, so I know good sound from bad sound. These headphones reproduce tones clearly and consistently, and can really pack a punch when the bass asks it to. I love working with music with these phones... Absolutely no ear fatigue either. They're just that smooth.You wont be disappointed. 5 Stars!
Great headphones and by far the best I've used. If you're looking for durability, and great sound, these are for you.

I read a lot of reviews for gaming headphones. It was confusing picking the right one. Then I read the reviews on the Sony MDRV6. This no nonsense headphones was just what I needed. The headphones do not have active noise canceling, but they fit around your ears and you can hear the drop in noise volume while wearing them. I needed a pair for long gaming sessions and these satisfy that requirement at a much lesser price than those other "gaming" headphones.My only negative would be that the headphones fit a bit too snugly that after so many hours of wearing them, my ears begin to ache just a bit, but maybe that would happen when wearing any headphones for so many hours! Get these headphones, you will be pleased with your purchase!

Like a few of the other reviewers here, I've owned my SONY MDR-V6 headphones since 1992. I use them ALL the time. They are still working great, the pads did finally wear out in 2006, I ordered replacement pads and everything wass great again. One of the best purchases I've ever made, highly recommend them.

From the first time I put these over my ears and hit play I have been disappointed.The brightness of the audio is EXTREME.  Very sharp highs.On the bottom of the spectrum the bass is nearly non-exisitant.I can hear the speakers distorting before I can even really turn them out to what I consider a loud listening volume.I have tried these on 3 different devices(one being an amp to actually drive the headphones more proper).  Little difference between any.After about 15-20 minutes my ears felt hot.  I removed to headphones to realize I was actually sweating.  I understand new $20 aftermarket ear pads will remedy this.I left them playing music over night so they had a total of 20 hours of music playing through them, hoping they may break in.  No avail.These are not what they are cracked up to be.  I am returning mine.
Great quality, there is a reason this particular model has been around for so long! Excellent sound for a great price!
I bought these to replace my old MDVR-V6 that i enjoyed for over three years until the dog chewed the through the cord. Very good quality headphones.
Great head phones, great sound, and they fit perfect not to tight or loose. I would recommend these to anyone

reviewerName: Charles G. "An Engineer and Business Person"
reviewText: I spend at least 10 hours a week in these mixing music professionally.  I've owned mine since the late 80s and have two pair: one for home and one for work.  I've replaced the earpads about every 8 years.These are quite simply one of the best ten products I've ever owned.  The sound quality is unparalleled.  They are efficient enough to be driven loud from a computer or an ipod.  I have a super large head and these are very comfortable.  Those of you complaining they are too tight don't understand how to adjust them - pull the earpieces down if they are too tight.I've never found a better pair at any price.  The fact that these are under $100, last essentially forever, and sound superb, is a modern miracle.Flat frequency response as high as any human ear can hear and lower than most any equipment can produce, and yet the sound is pleasing from just about any source.Buy a pair of them without hesitation.  You'll never regret it.
summary: Probably one of the best purchases I've ever made

reviewText: These headphones give me a persistent headache every time I wear them. As a matter of fact, I think they have created a bruise on the crown of my head.I am very angry that I paid $100 for these things, thinking they were going to be the best sounding and most comfortable pair of headphones, and ideal for long-term, hours-of-studying, use. They are not.I switched back to my $45.00 Sennheiser HD 212Pros that are probably 10 years old and sound 80% as good as the Sonys, but don't try to drill into my skull. I gotta tell you, any reduction in the sound quality is well worth a reduction of the amount of skull-drilling.I know, they're supposed to be industry standard. What can I say other than stay away if you're planning to wear these for more then 20 minutes at a time!

I own: Bose IE2 In ear, Sony V500, Sony V250, and Panasonic RP-DJS400.These are the best headphones I have owned.Physically: high quality construction, padding is comfortable, not too heavy, don't squeeze my head much (i have a medium size head), the ear padding cups my ears comfortably and doesn't let any sound in, and I can listen to them for hours without my neck/head getting soar, even though I wear glasses.  The construction of the cord looks solid and I am confident that it will not break/tear.Sound: due to the good seal around the ears, the quality of the sound is easy to hear.  without burning them in, they sound great out of the box.  you can clearly hear a full range of sound-far superior clarity compared to my Panasonic DJS400's, and superior bass to my Sony V-500's, while maintaining good balance.I listen to them at the computer and I am installing an external sound card to get better sound quality out of my laptop so that I can enjoy the headphones even more.  I have not taken them outside, nor to I intend to as my DJS400's and Bose IE2's are more portable and I do not feel that these headphones were designed for that purpose.  I feel like these headphones are designed to enjoy indoors with a good quality sound source.  The headphones have a good capacity and should be enjoyed to their fullest..not on some cheap mp3 player.Thanks for reading and happy listening :)

I loved these headphones for the 1st hours I had them.  Awsome sound.  But then, I took my daily walk with them.  The first thing I noticed was that they amplified every step I took like a bass drum.  They also amplified the cord as it swished and rubbed against my body.  When I scratched my face, it sounded like sandpaper.  Then when a slight breeze began (5 - 10 mph), it sounded like I was in a hurricane or wind tunnel and drowned out the music. I am returning them.  If you just want to use them while sitting still inside, they are awsome, but not good if you're moving around.
Had a pair of these a long time ago. I forgot how good they sounded so I was pleasantly reminded when I first put them on. Excellent clarity and balance. Very comfortable. Highly recommended.
I really like this headphones. Sound is great and fit is comfortable. Only complaint is that the size adjustment doesn't seem to stay. I find myself having to readjust the fit every now and then.

I've never owned a pair of headphones that wasn't just a cheap pair of earbuds.  When my very last pair broke in one ear, I decided it was time for me to finally upgrade to something with better quality.I scoured the internet for recommendations and found various lists headphones for varying price ranges.These headphones were in my price range, and I couldn't be happier with the quality.  Maybe I'm thinking too highly of them, because I've never owned a real pair of headphones before, but these were perfect for my needs and price range.

I am not an expert on this but based on the quality of the output sound, I would definitely recommend these. worse than expected, not worth.I didn't think them comfortable for long use at all, made ears red by pressing them against my head.Sometimes, it is distorted.Bought it in Thanksgiving Day for good price.I don't like it.not wanna recommend to anybody.

reviewText: The price of these headphones does not reflect the quality of them. They are by far the best headphones I have ever used. Every aspect of these are incredible. The headband is comfortable, the earcups fit perfectly, the folding mechanism is sturdy, and they are extremely portable. The cord is seriously good quality and length, yet the fact that it's coiled means it does not get in the way. Even the plug which is secured by a metal piece rather than plastic or rubber is sturdy.PROS:-Extremely clear sounds in all ranges. Background noise in movies such as cars passing behind the camera sound like they are behind me in my room.-They muffle external sound surprisingly well considering they aren't technically "noise cancelling"-The cord stays short and compact but doesn't require much force to pull it out to its full length. when it's plugged into my laptop I can pull the cord out to nearly 10 feet without moving my laptop at all.-They fold up and I don't even notice them in my backpack.-Obviously, the amazing price for headphones that outmatch Beats by DreCONS:-They attract attention which is good, but people tend to think I paid hundreds for these when In reality I paid $65, yet at the same time I don't want them to get stolen since they do look very expensive.-They are much louder than most headphones I've used. Once again, this could be a good thing but just be careful to not blow out your eardrums.-After using them for a while, all other headphones sound really terrible. There is no going back.Also realize these headphones have mechanical parts inside. After about 3 hours of listening they sounded even better from being broken in a little bit.Would buy these over and over, and I recommend them to everyone that asks about them.Update: I found out you can buy replacement earcup pads for this exact model. I don't need them yet but I'm very glad it's possible. The fact that there is a market for replacement earcup pads means these headphones last a long time.

Honestly an amazing product, with headphones I always stuck with the 3 S's, Sony, Sennheiser, And Shure, they never let me down, this product didn't let me down so I'm sure it won't let anybody else down either.

I've bought two pairs of these now, only because one was a gift to my Dad.  They're the best sounding I've used for the budget (and budgets hundreds higher).  Just know the ear pad will start to fall apart after awhile, I think it was around two years for me.
summary: I have trouble buying anything else.

reviewText: These are very nice. I am replacing a twenty year old set MDRV600. I loved them. I was told back then that the MDRV600 are an upgrade from the MDRV6's. I must agree with the other reviews that the MDRV6's are better sound and little more comfy. The MDRV600 still work but are going to need the plug replaced as one channel is cutting in and out. I will replace the plug and pads for my son. The MDRV600 is louder at the same output I find. So, maybe better with portable devices. In closing These are outstanding headphones IMO the best value for great sound quality, light, and well built headphone on the market. These have been around since 1985 they must be doing something right.

Bought these because of their range.  Glad I did.  Only problem I have is the cord.  It may be 10 feet long but because it's coiled you really are limited to where you can go.  Go too far and out comes the plug or down goes the stereo.  Just need to limit your range.  No biggie.  I just move the chair closer to the stereo.Also, the cushions are fit just right around my ears where they do a good job of blocking out outside noises.

I am not a big headphone fan and I only use them when I have to. I use these for monitoring vocal recordings and general mixing/production. The sound seems to be neutral and quite accurate to what comes out on the studio monitors. The only qualm I have is the extremely flimsy looking ear pads, but I could be wrong and they may last a long time. I like the coiled cord and the screw on adapter included.  Either way, for the price these are great.

These are a great set of headphones. I also own a MDR-V600, and was so impressed by those that I decided to get these as well. Listening to music on both, the V6 is noticeably (although barely) better. I'm not an audiophile, but I could still tell the difference.However, for me the V600 were much more comfortable. They completely surround the ear which makes them very easy to keep on all day while you work. The V6's are still relatively comfortable, and if I didn't have the V600 to compare with, I would say they are good enough (comfort wise).If you want a pair of headphones to listen to at work in the background, I might suggest you look at the V600s. Otherwise, its hard to go wrong with this set.
summary: Better sounds than the v600, but not as comfortable

reviewText: These are, by far, the best headphones I've ever owned.  Sony got it right when they invented the MDR-V6's, and that's why they've stayed pretty much the same (even the packaging) for about 30 years.  I'd recommend them to anyone.
These headphones are solidly constructed. I might get different pads, but I've only had very slight ear pain after long term use. Good sound.
As many reviewers have said these sound great- I use them at work and they are perfect for blocking out all the distractions. I think the padding is sufficient.

Very good headphones; during my research, I was surprised to learn they have been around since 1985.  I last had 'good' Sony headphones around 1990 .....but my cats ate one of the wires.  So I swore I'd never do that again ....until now.  I've been using the MDR-V150s, a $20 headphone, for the last 5+ years.  The V6 delivers so much more 'nuance' that it occasionally surprises me and I think, "I've never heard *that* before..." in a song that I've listed to 100x.  I recently imported Enya's Shepherd Moons CD using iTunes at 320kbs, but even at that setting, I could not hear anything 'better' with tracks I'm already familiar with.  So that may be the limit of their range.  I have not yet tried them with my cd player (Sony D-555, also from 1990; yes it still works!!), so I know that iTunes may be compressing or clipping the signal.  And since I sit in a kinda busy spot at work, they do a great job of keeping out noise.  No problem using them for 6+ hrs at a time!

I got these because I thought they looked cool and I was unwilling to purchase the vastly overpriced Doctor Dre Beats product. These work particularly well as I listen to many podcasts and audio quality is important to me

I have owned a pair of these headphones since they were first made available in 2001.  Reading the reviews from other long-time owners helped me locate replacement felt for the ear covers ... I expect to get another 10+ years of service out of these awesome headphones.

I have owned these headphones for over 20 years.  Rarely do I write reviews, but these headphones are FANTASTIC.  Not only do they sound extremely open and transparent, but they have super flat response curve - no tubbiness in the mid bass.  Aside from two sets of pads (which are $5), I have had no trouble with these.  And they are tough...I have loaned them to several of my 6 kids and they have survived unscathed.  THESE are a definite value product!!!!!

This review is coming from someone who purchased this for the following reasons:Casual Music listening, Gaming, and occasional use for movies at night.I went through the Corsair HS1, Audio Technica AD700, and Sennheisers HD555.While I thought the HS1 was decent the other 2 just lacked the bass I wanted.I wasn't looking for over the top bass either. While I understand why gamers likethe AD700, it just had no bass at all, and yes I do have an amp.My experience so far with this pair has been "This is the one". I love the "neutral"sound to the V6. When I first started to use it, my ears did start to hurt butI think I've gotten use to it.

A buddy of mine asked for a recommendation for headphones at the $100 price point. He said he listened to acoustic music and rock music and was interested in some headphones that would block out noise as he is a frequent traveler.  Upon replying to him I realized that I never wrote a proper review of these excellent headphones.  Rather than tailoring a review for Amazon I just copied the email I wrote:The Sony MDR-V6 was the fist "real" headphone I ever got. They have been largely unchanged for years. I actually got my pair for my 14th or 15th birthday.  I used them all throughout high school and used them daily in college. They served as my walking to class headphones/earmuffs which helped make it through some nasty winters in Bowling Green, Ohio. A day did not go by that I did not use them, slam them in backpacks, drop them, sit on them, etc. I beat the begeezus out of them and I'm surprised they still work. I would have not thought poorly of them if they crapped out years ago.  At present, some 15 years later, my little brother is using them and reports no issues. These headphones are well worth the current street price.  Even at the MSRP I wouldn't consider them a bad deal.  The only thing that might ever need to be replaced are the ear pads, which are constructed of faux leather and tend to flake off after about a decade. But those are cheap and widely available.  And honestly, how often does one talk in terms of decades when referring to current production consumer electronics?These headphones aren't really noise canceling per se. They are just big closed headphones that cover your whole ear and that serves to block out the noise. I would say this is marginally helpful in an airplane. You can block out some of the sounds but you know you are on a plane. If your goal is truly to block out airplane noise, buying active noise canceling headphones are the only way to achieve that. The asking price on such headphones are quite a bit more.  The Sony MDR-V6 works to block out some noise, but don't expect miracles in regards to how much sound is blocked out.Ok so they're durable and would make a good travel buddy.  So how do they sound!?!?On the sound the MDR-V6's are overall good. They are very detailed and you will be able to listen deep into recordings and hear things you've never heard before. This is kind of a surreal experience the first time around. I have fond memories of my first weeks owning these headphones because such marked the first time I was ever truly wowed by a sound system because of sound quality and not just because it was loud. I suspect you might want to rip some CD's at lossless quality vs using the typical lossy/mp3 stuff. You'll find that these headphones are not accommodating of poor recordings or low quality digital conversions. If something in the recording is bullhonky, they'll tell you. My chief criticism is that the resolution comes a bit at the expense of neutrality; perhaps too much so.  The headphones possess a live sound. If you could picture an equalizer the lower bass and the treble are bumped up a bit. if your listening preferences tend towards acoustic guitar and rock, this bumped treble feature makes listening fun.  As an example, take an acoustic guitar. These headphones are a trip because you can clearly hear that leading edge of stings being plucked. Think of the intro to the track "Stay (Wasting Time)" by DMB. You'll absolutely love acoustic guitars on these. Where this enhanced treble thing bugs me is if the vocals are recorded crappy and/or there is too much sibilance (think of too much sibilance as an over exaggerated hissing/whistling "S" sound then someone says "little suzy saucer sitting on a thistle"). This is not too huge of a deal but just something to be aware of.... on a long enough timeline it drives me bonkers, but this is more of a personal preference thing.What is also very nice about these is that you do not need an amplifier. Many headphones require an amplifier to sound right. These do not. They will work fine right out of your portable media player or phone.Hopefully these will serve as a good entry into the headphone world. There are many other options to be had and you can get some particularly rewarding sounds out of open headphones (those not designed for travel and that do not block out ambient noise) combined with a dedicated amplifier and a proper digital setup.... dare I say even a vinyl based setup. But that conversation is for another day. Buy these Sony's and have some fun!
summary: Some Friendly Advice On These Great Headphones

reviewText: and terrific sound. You don't need to spend $200+ on the good doctor's  prescription :). These are a very wise, economical, and sound worthy choice.

I've always used the crappy $20 headphones for some reason that end up breaking within six months or so and aren't exactly good anyway. I figured I'd try to invest in a pair that could last a while and with all of the reviews that guaranteed 20 years of life on this pair, it seemed like a sound purchase.When I first got them, I proceeded to listen to music the entire day and could really hear things I hadn't heard before, all the subtleties and such. I could easily focus on any of the instruments and hear everything that was going on. I would recommend for sure.
These are the best headphones I have ever had. I can hear details I had not heard before. Also very comfortable if a bit snug. Absolutely recommend.

You absolutely cannot go wrong purchasing these headphones. They were the catalyst that set me on a never ending quest for headphone perfection back when I first heard them at a friends house when I was but fourteen years of age, many years ago. It took me almost fourteen years to finally obtain a pair of my own, when my wife purchased a set for me last Valentine's Day.I have been through the land of Grado, the realm of Beyer, with visits through Senn country Shureville and so many others, and yet I still find so much greatness in these relatively cheap cans. Sure they aren't as quite crisp as the Beyers I own, or maybe not quite as musical as the Senns or warm as the Grados, but they are the cans I use more than all of the others combined. They sit on my desk folded up neatly, just always ready. My toddler can throw them at the wall and I know they will be totally fine. I can throw them into a backpack and know they will be fine. Even if they did somehow wind up damaged, I'm only out one kite flyer.Buy these headphones, you will not regret it. I assure you of this. I keep them on my wishlist in perpetuity hoping that whenever my wife doesn't know what to get for me for some special occasion, she will just get me another pair. It hasn't happened again yet but I remain hopeful.If you start paying attention to professional sound engineers that you might glimpse on TV, or behind the scenes in some movie or youtube video or whatever, pay attention to what they are using. 75% of the time it will be these unmistakable beauties. 15% of the time it's Beyer DT-770s (also very nice). The remaining 10% it's usually a mix of more obscure Beyers, or more often some nice AKGs. Again, look at what the pro's are using and you will catch these babies staring back at you far more often than not. Trust them, trust me; obtain these.

The headphones sound fine, they are comfortable enough -- but this cord is  a deal-breaker. As other reviewers have noted, it is very heavy due to its substantial coiling -- and as a result it will not comfortably rest on any surface yet cannot be left dangling because it is too heavy! Maybe an example would suffice... if I plug these into my Mac Tower while sitting at my desk, the cord is too short to not start engaging the coils -- which produces tension and then tugs on the headphones -- eventually causing the plug to pop out of the computer. ANNOYING. What's worse is that the cord refuses to rest on he desk either without sliding off because (once again) it is too short and the coils are too heavy. I have to secure it down which is harder than it might seem without duct tape, plus it really restricts my movement.For this alone, I would recommend another set.

Based on all the recommendations on Amazon and around the Internet, this was the best model at my target price. The product actually exceeded my expectations. The sound is superior and the headset is very comfortable. As expected, Sony has not had to update this model for years because you can't improve upon perfection at this price point.
summary: Definitely get what you pay for... And then some!

reviewText: They always live up to the expectations.  Take a lot of wear & tear.  These are the headphones our techs prefer.

These headphones have confirmed everything I read in reviews prior to purchasing them.  I looked long and hard before deciding on these.  I wanted something under $100 that delivered quality sound and got it.  Excellent bass and treble response.  Clarity is great at all volume levels.  I listen to everything from classical to hard rock and these headphones handle it all well.  Couldn't be more pleased with this buy.

These have become the preferred headphones of choice for tracking. I wasn't expecting much when I picked up a pair of these on Black Friday for $40. I've had numerous people google these after using them to see where they can get them in town quicker. These are the real deal.

I waited for these to drop in price before jumping on the bandwagon and buying them. They are comfortable, but your ears begin to ache a bit after extremely prolonged use. The carrying pouch is great-looking and practical. The long cord and heavy duty plug assuages any fears of wear and tear. Paired with FLAC recordings, these rock.

It's not a solid 5 star, BUT it still deserves it. At this price, the sound quality is wonderful. I did burn-in with an app on android, using pink noise. Before the burn-in, the sound is good but not smooth enough. Now it just sounds right. The sound is much smoother. Good build quality. Nicely packaged. A decent leather bag is included.Now the CONS or insufficiency:1. don't expect light weight but it is ok;2. cable is "telephone wire", maybe good for moving around in studio, but ugly and unnecessary for other use;3. the can doesn't hug your head tightly. It is comfy for home use but you probably can't go commuting unless you walk smoothly like a snail.Overall, a great quality headphone for the price. Try it with flac/ape against other can, you will feel the great sound quality.
summary: Great Great Headphone for Home/Studio use, Not for commuting

reviewText: I am a critical audiophile and naturally gravitate to the higher end products.  I wanted a set of headphones to carry in my pack for listening at the coffee shop or when traveling.  I have some megabuck Grados but they are far from portable and prefer a strong amp, not an iPhone.  I tried a lot of mainstream headphones (Beats, Senns, Bose, etc)  but just could not take the audio compromise. So based on the reviews and the modest price I order a set of these blind, and wow.... They are fantastic cans, flat, clean, detailed, deep, non fatiguing.... I am impressed and Sony really did something right here.
The sound's quality Is really good. However the cord is not practical.In less than one hour of wearing these headphones my ears hurt.

Good set of cans for mixing and hearing they sound as it was recorded. If you want something for recreational music listening, these might not be for you thought I don't see why these couldn't be used for that. These have a good rep for a reasonable priced headphone for audio mixers etc.
Amazing buy, awesome comfort, great sound quality. I have no idea what more you want in headphones. The best part is it is not plastic and has great durability.

I purchased these on Black Friday, I use them for my Ipod Touch 4th Generation. The sound these produce completely removed the need to use any EQ settings on my IPod.I mostly listen to Pop, Rock, and Rap so I can say Highs are great, Mids are good, bass is excellent and clear,and no noise distortion.I can't speak to how well the build of the Headphones will last overtime, but so far they seem durable.They are a good choice if you plan on owning a HIGH QUALITY or audiophile version of headphones.The only thing I absolutely HATE is the LONGGGGGGG CABLE. I can't work it with it, it dangles over my legs,jumps up and down with me. If Sony could make a short version cable these would easily destroy, Beats, Souls, Audio Technica and all of the otherhighly marketed headphones.
summary: They sound great and produce accurate sounds

reviewText: I just bought these trying to save a little money over the MDR7506. I have used the 7506 headphones for probably 20 some years now, replacing them when the earcups started to break down(this is my third set). I listen every day to speakers and headphones. I now have both models and can compare them. In my opinion(and please no hate mail) I think the 7506's sound better. They are slightly clearer and produce more air if you know what I mean. Bass is good on both but once again i think it is slightly cleaner with the pro phones. One writer mentioned about the gold plating wearing off of the connector. I plug my phones in and out all the time (for years) and the connector still looks perfect. No wear at all!!. maybe that coonector has something to do with the sound difference. I dont know but if i had to do it all over again I would spend the extra money and buy the MDR 7506. Dont get me worng. the v6 is a good phone but for my ears the other set is the way to go.

These phones have a truly beautiful sound. Excellent range. As a drummer they isolate just the right amount and still allow me to hear my own play. Also, they are quite comfortable and fit me perfectly. The coil type cord is a nice touch.

Awesome, Awesome, Awesome!!! I was shopping for a noise cancellation headphone because I needed to watch and listen lectures online without disturbance from my environment. I read the reviews about this headphone and was really impressed.  I felt confident enough to buy and it arrived today. I have them on as I write, it is Awesome, Awesome, Awesome!!!The pads fit snuggly around my ears while I am enveloped in a cloud of quality sound, also outside sounds become quite inaudible. I love the pouch it came it and the length of the cord. I read some reviews from people who complained that the phones could be delicate so I will be quite careful with mine.Finally, it is real value for my money considering the use. No doubt, my ipod will make a comeback and it will be an early summer for my apple-earphones.
summary: Awesome product, reviews can be useful!!!!

reviewText: Okay. Im not the audio expert nor have i tried out an extensive array of other headphones but i Will say this.The headphones look great as in Yup can wear them around in public without being stoned to death in humiliation.The Sonys sound great as in if you listen to Whitney Houston, Slipknot, Skillex or Jason Aldean at the sweat or highest volumes you Will feel like they're singing or playing personally for you.The Sonys are flat and that just means that you'll hear what is meant to be heard.Personally i use these on a Galaxy Samsung S2 WITH THE POWERAMP app and they work wonder with adjustable bass treble and a synthesizer. I literally love them.Im a very frequent music listener and I have to say that these are comfy as Hell. I can easily listen to 2hrs + with these.I've had them so far for a month and they feel durable. the cable is coiled and beef and the actual headphones are tough.At this price, according to a lot of reviews, these are simply the best.If you're  debating on getting these  i recommend you do, they're definitely worth it.
summary: Frequent listener on cellphone with these.

reviewText: I have used Creative Alpha,World Of Warcraft,Arena,fatal1ty mkii. Then I thought about my purpose.It wasn't really gaming.I am not a gamer first of all.I keep hearing music for at least 5-10 hrs a day.That is why I gave a thought about Sony.Pros:The build quality is just unbeatable with steel-core headband especially the 3.5,6.5mm connectors  and not to forget the connecting coiled wires of high quality. In fact the best of all.I have used it for more than a month now and I feel I am settling down with this.cons:One major one is the way that it crushes the top of ear even after one month of usage. That is something I am apprehensive about if that will keep happening until I change ear cups as suggested.I have pretty big ears, may be that is why.I would update on this as I purchase the 18$ replacement ear cups.Till then, with the initial ones, not too comfortable for more than an hour.With regard to MUSIC I would put forth below comparisons for users to decide,V6 VS creative ArenaAlthough the best sounding was arena I wouldn't go for it again since the large USB connector breaks down pretty easily somehow since 'its too big not to get hit' by hand.I mean the USB connector projects far from the laptop and is getting hit very often.V6 VS creative fatal1ty mkiiSound quality goes neck and neck between the 2. I would rate build quality to be much better in Sony V6 since it doesn't have plastic reinforcement as fatal1ty mkii joints have.It broke down for my friend.V6 VS creative WOWWOW was the most comfortable of all.It is rounded shape unlike others(oval) and doesn't press on the ears.But the sound effects with USB connectors didn't match up to my expectations.Infact I had done a comparison having WOW and fatal1ty connected to the same lappy and it did disappoint me spending 70$ and ending up losing to a 25$ deal-got fatal1ty mkii!!V6 VS AlphaAlpha sounded decent.But I returned Alpha with its plastic core band completely broken within 2 mnths.P.S I use my headset with utmost care.Only then I realized the importance of build quality.Sony V6 doesn't really have the bass that you will dream by default. When I did the below, the bass effects were enhanced hugely.You can also try changing the equalizer for your ipod/iphone.you can try as well.Click on volume icon->Mixer->speaker->Enhancement->check Immediate modecheck Equalizerchoose "Powerful" mode from the drop-down listThe above could be done on any headphone.But Sony V6 has a flat response by default and equalizer/bass boosters work wonders with this!+With Sony V6 there is no deal..or is it?? one can purchase for a std 65$ without regret!
summary: Awesome sound effects but with a lot of uncomfort for big ears

reviewText: I bought these because I have a problem with headphones in my ears.I know Sony's products are normally pretty good, but these are GREAT.I am not a music expert, so I cannot describe the lows and highs, but I will say it makes my Ipod sound great.I would recommend these headphones for anybody like me that has a problem with in ear headphones.Note:They are very comfortable for the long run and the flexible ear covers are replaceable and are on Ebay for a fair price.

I've owned a pair of Sony's MDR-V6 for nearly three years now, and my 'phones have been through a lot. They still produce better sound than anything else I've ever owned, and cost so much less than comparable equipment.The big deal is the frequency response of these headphones, especially in the low frequency ranges. These are the real deal, producing full, rich bass tones while still putting out clear, crisp sound in the medium- and high-frequency ranges. Yes, the frequency response isn't as broad as some higher-end cans, but I don't think most users will notice the difference in sound as much as they will in their wallets.The length of the cord has been something of a joke between myself and my friends. It's long... VERY long. And while it does definitely make the overall product heavier, it's clear this was designed for someone at a workstation, rather than joggers or whomever you see sporting the high style headphones du jour. The MDR-V6 isn't quite the pickup truck of headphones, but they're definitely for getting work done, not for looking stylish.I will say, though, that you may want to look out--some production runs have a tighter fit than others. I've gotten two pair, one from a retailer in China, and another from a retailer in the US. The China pair had smaller ear cups and were tighter, but both had the same quality sound. I gave the China pair to a friend who loved them as much as I have mine.

I've read a ton of reviews on these headphones and decided to bite and get a pair. I have a big head, not a huge head, but, a bigger head than some other guys. Sony should've called these headphones the headlock series! Like another reviewer said, don't discount the tightness complaints. Don't get me wrong, these sounded great and after burn-in would probably be the best headphones I've ever owned. But, I don't think I will ever know because they hurt my head so bad after less than an hour of listening that I had to take them off!Also, I notice a lot of reviewers of headphones talk about sounds getting in. I listen to these at work, so I don't mind knowing when someone has approached my cubicle. I just don't want my songs leaking out to bother other co-workers. I bought a more comfortable pair of Sony headphones (mdr-xb500). They sound even better out of the box than the V6's to me. But, they don't look as good (actually they make you feel kinda of corny like you're in some cheesy B hip/hop movie from the 80s). But, where the V6's seem to excel at keeping the sound in just your ears, the mdr-xb500's seem to excel at just the opposite! I would call them more akin to speakers you wear on your head than headphones!I am still on a quest for headphones up to 100 bucks, with decent bass that are around the ear headphones (don't like ear buds). I also want them to be comfortable since I listen to music for sometime more than three quarters of my time at work with little to no sound leakage. I will take any suggestions on other headphones I should try.Let me sum up by saying that you cannot go wrong with these headphones if you have a small head or can take the grip! Everything sounded crystal clear when hooked up to my lowly iPod touch. They rocked even more when hooked directly to my MacBook. I can't imagine how great they'd sound hooked up to my stereo. I listen to stuff all over the map from r&b; to light rock, to hip/hop to jazz. The only thing lacking for me was deeper bass. It seemed to be a bit light, but, from the other reviews, it seems this would improve dramatically after a little burn-in time.
summary: Like Listening to your favorite band live in a vice grip!!

reviewText: Santa brought me these after I had done some extensive research. I've always been content spending a little extra money for quality and peace of mind; these headphones are one of the rare occurrences when you can get an incredible product at an extremely reasonable price. Lightweight, comfortable and sturdily built headphones with an incredibly balanced sound. Bass is very accurate and complements vocals and instruments nicely. Find myself wearing these for hours on end with no irritation, although clearly head and ear shape vary greatly, the MDR-V6 will be a steady companion of mine for the foreseeable future.

They work great. sound is clear and crisp, they seem fairly durable (ive kinda been banging them around for 6 months and not a scratch on them) and i couldnt be more pleased. theyre comfortable, and i can have them on for hours without any irritation. they arent necessarily ideal for portable listening since the cord is kinda long, but its not a big problem either way. overall, these are awesome. i would definetely recommend them.

These are the best headphones I have ever owned. They are so comfortable and can wear glasses with them. It gets even better than the comfort of them. They sound great, if you are looking for over the ear headphones you should get these. They are great.

The sound that these headphones reproduces is simply amazing. Right away I was astonished by the vast details, crisp vocals and all the little details that was intended to be heard by the artist!For under $100, this is one of the best in that price range, it even sounds better than some higher priced headphones!This definitely sounds better than my Beats, and Bose headphones!These headphones are also very comfortable, feels much more durable than Beats and Bose.Based on other reviews, it seems that these headphones will last a long time!Buy it, don't hesitate, you won't regret it! :)

I can hear everything great sound fidelity. And I would say they are some where between pretty comfy and comfy enough on head and ears. Very happy with them more than I could have wanted from the price range.
These headphones are built to survive pro audio and video workflow.I've been using them for 3 years for audio monitoring and video editing and the cord is still intact.

Here are my quick notes after using Sony's MDR-V6 for a month.For those that are interested, I keep my headphones on my head whenever I'm in front of the computer (pretty much all day).-Sound quality is as good as many of the other reviewers have stressed and there's no need to go further.-Classical music sounds great, but bass in contemporary genres may feel lacking at times and may require some getting used to (really depends on your previous equipment).  I've heard that replacing the original pads with the Beyerdynamic ones can slightly boost the bass, but I can't personally comment on that.-The coiled cables are a bit bulky but not too bothersome.  If you use your headphones primarily for desk work, there shouldn't be any problems.-The pads were initially hurting my ears, so I was considering buying the Beyerdynamic pads to replace them.  After about two weeks, the pain disappeared and I've decided to stick with the original ones.Overall, I'm very happy with the purchase and would highly recommend it.  Definitely worth the price.

I have been using mdr v6 for years.  Great headphones.  So when I find them on sale,  I grab a pair.  These have the best sound for the money. Yes, many people may find them too big and bulky for mp3 players.  But if you prefer good sound over a fashion statement (like beats) you can't go wrong.

I was able to get these headphones for under $70 and they fully met my expectations.  I had been meaning to buy this model of headphones for years now but didn't really have a reason to until one side of my MDR V150 headphones blew out. These are a huge upgrade from what I had - you can really hear the details in music with these, including a wide range of frequency.Pros- Relatively comfortable with good noise isolation- High frequency range- Comes with 1/4 inch jack adaptor- Comes with a carrying caseCons- The coiled wire is connected to left-hand side and if you walk around, you may feel imbalanced weight on left side of headOverall, a great pair of headphones, especially for someone just venturing into audiophile territory.
This is the best 70$ I have spent in a while, not disappointing at all. Lives up to all of the hype.
Plays loud and clear. Works well as a passive noise canceler. Good bass but in a weird way sounds distant. Still a very good, strong product.
i feel like these were a great price for sound quality and comfort.  The only reason for 4 stars and not 5 is that there is no volume adjustment on the cord.
Great sound quality, but the headphones fit kind of tightly onto my head. If I wear them for extended periods I get a headache. Hoping I can 'loosen' them up with extended use.

I've had these since November, and they're great.  They're comfortbale and the sound is the best I've heard out of headphones in awhile.  The cord is a bit long, but it's nice to have when you want to step away from your computer or iPod.

Hello, This is my first review for the Sony MDR-V6 with CCAW Voice Coil.SoundFirst I would like to mention that these headphones sound pretty amazing. I've had bad headphones in the past that had terrible bass or treble, but for me its very well balanced. The only complaint about sound is that if you play any songs that has a lot of treble in it, it may not sound as comfortable in the high ranges. Some people mentioned about a "boomy bass" and I disagree. I think the bass is completely fine (I still need to go hear some hardcore bass drop of a dubstep though). I like bass a lot and I put my iPod with Bass Boost and it still sounds fine without being "boomy" or "vibrating." I listened with my galaxy s4 and that sounded fine as well.ComfortSome people complained that the headband hurts while others say its comfortable. For me, It was pretty comfortable, but not as comfortable as I thought. At first, it's going to hurt the top of your head for a bit, but after you wear it for a couple of days the uncomfortable-ness goes away. Right now after 1 week, I don't complain about the headband at all. Just like any other over-ears it does get sweaty a bit, so don't wear it for too long unless you have air blowing in your face the whole time :P.BuildThe build is pretty solid, but the plastic on the sides makes it feel slightly cheap, but its not much to complain about. It's well built overall and it's portable which is a plus for me.AccessoriesIt comes with a bag that you can put your headphones in, which is pretty nice and unexpected. Also it comes with a 1/4" screw on. Problem I had with this screw on is that when I took it back out, for whatever reason the 1/8" connector bent in the middle slightly (maybe because I screwed it on too tight or something.) I just bent it back with the 1/4" adapter putting it slightly in and bending it the other way and it was fine.OtherAnother thing I noticed was that the cable end doesn't really fit well into my s4 when it has its case on. I have to shove it in a little bit for it to go all the way in. Because it's also with a metal end(which makes it pretty solid instead of a cheap plastic one) I sometimes have problems connecting it to devices like the ipod and s4. But if you just give it a slight push then it should go all the way in. I wish the 1/8" was a tiny bit longer so that it wouldn't have to be shoved in.Pros:- Great sound quality. For the most part balanced.- It's actually quite comfortable once you get used to it.- It's portable- It has the coiled wire so it doesn't tangle so easily- It comes with a convenient 1/4" cable. I use it for my P-155 Yamaha Digital Piano.- It doesn't squish your ears, but isolates a lot of sound if you have sound running through the headphones.- Solid Metal endingCons:- High range in treble can get screechy (but that's if you go really high)- It is uncomfortable at first to the top of your head.- The wire is a little bit too long.- The metal end sometimes makes it uncomfortable to insert into devices like the iPod or your phone.tl;dr: it's very good product for headphones under $100.
summary: Some really nice headphones for a reasonable price.

reviewText: I record interview audio for video/DSLR shoots professionally. My go-to system begins with a Sennheiser MKH416-T short shotgun mic into a Sound Devices 302 mixer (which can power the T-power mic), the line-in into a JuicedLink RM222 then into a Nikon D800, then recording to the HDMI output to an Atomos Ninja.To monitor, I plug my trusty MDRV6's into the monitor out of the 302 mixer, which is listening via its return to the headphone output of the Nikon. With a knob turn, I can then listen to any of the mixer's three inputs directly or to the camera's return confidence feed.If it sounds good in the Sony MDRV6's, it'll sound good in the edit.Yes, there are way more expensive headphones, but I know how the MDRV6's sound, I trust them, and they never break.The biggest problem is coworkers "borrowing" them and not returning them. Write your name on them in large letters.
Very sturdy builtAmazing sound qualityoh and they're also really comfortable..One of the best, if not thee best pair of headphones you could get for less than $100.
I owned a pair of Dre Beats, these blow them out of the water, hands down. Crisp Clean Audio, What else can you ask for?
summary: Beats any high priced headphones by far

reviewText: while mixing i can now hear all of the mistakes i make, and can put out a better product when mixing

The first time I put these on I understood the con of the tightness being expressed by other reviewers. They are pretty tight out of the box, but once you find the right numbers on the adjustable headband and keep breaking them in, the headphone relaxes around your head. I use these a lot as a student at school, so the pads inner seam is starting to come apart inside of the cup, but I wear these for the sound, not for looks.Onto sound, these guys are closed so the sound is not going to breathe, but you really can turn these cans up a good amount before anyone outside can hear them. A plus when you operate in a quiet library like I do. If you like a little more bass like I do(my last headphones were mdr-xb500 Bass Boosters) just turn on the equalizer some. Other than that the sound is very clear. Having had these for 2 weeks they have not failed to live up to expectations and I definitely recommend them to anyone on a budget, but looking for great quality.
summary: Once you break 'em in, you're golden!

reviewText: If you are interesting in a product that will deliver crisp high sound quality these are for you. some cons of the item are that it is not the most portable available however, if you are purchasing to record music or produce pretty much anything that is irrelevant.

The sound is very rich, pretty much noise canceling. However, within 4 months I began to start losing sound in my right earbud when connecting to my iPod touch and Galaxy S3 phone. It happens when I listen to music on the go. When moving, I only need to slightly move the device to hear an effect on the connection between the wire and my device. The sound becomes choppy in my right ear; at times I completely lose sound, and I have to rotate the metal end of the cord to try to get sound back. I haven't fully troubleshooted the problem, but the solution to keep sound in both ears appears to be pulling on the cord. Regardless, I can't always keep the cord pulled when walking around. This is a very annoying and unwanted side effect, and it's becoming more and more difficult to listen to choppy-free music. Because I listen to music so much on the move, I am about to order a replacement, probably from a different company.
summary: Great sound, but wiring issue causes loss of sound in one ear

reviewText: The reviews are spot on. These are the most glorious headphones I have ever used. The sound is incredible, whether watching movies or listening to music. I too have been amazed, hearing dialogue and nuanced sound in films that I've never noticed before. It beats the hell out of surround sound systems. Forget expensive "noise-canceling" styles, I used these on a plane, connected to my iPod and was in heaven for the duration of the flight. The long coiled cord is a welcome feature as well as the screw-on adapter for larger headphone inputs. These collapse quite easily and come with a carry sack that fits into my laptop bag. I use these exclusively now rather than the puny little in-ear styles. They just don't cut it any longer.

I was looking all over for a pair of travel/commuting headphones and forgot about these until a couple of friends mentioned them. Man, am I ever glad I listened!The MDR-V6 is a very comfortable headphone (even when wearing my glasses) and the sound is awesome.  Commuting with them allows me to block out much of the surrounding noise without being unaware of my surroundings, plus the classic look gives me the ability to be one of the few walking around NYC without the ubiquitous Beats on my head.Love them.

Love the sound. I can hear nuances that I've never heard before, and the shape/size of the headphones is just perfect for my ears and head. Nice value too.FYI: I am pairing this headphone with with Fiio E07 Andes DAC connected with my laptop, with DFX Audio Enhancer to further process the sound. The result is sublime ...

I just picked up a set at Fry's at lunch, and agree with the others here that they are comfortable and sound very good. Unfortunately, the soft earcups are very susceptible to any little noise source, including movement of eyeglass frames and touching/scratching your cheek. I really wish that stores would have headphones on display so that you could find things like this out at the store. I also think that the earcups will get hot and sweaty with extended use. So far the Bose TriPorts are the only units that I have found that are comfortable and don't create this noise from rubbing, but I don't particularly like their sound, plus they cost twice what these do.
summary: Great Sound, Comfortable, but Beware Eyeglasses Wearers!

reviewText: These really are great I have only had them a few weeks and I love them! And the price I got them for was great!

I'm using it with a Macbook Pro and an iPod touch. I've had two V6s so far (both made in Thailand in 2012).PackagingThe headphones, the cable, and the pouch don't really fit in the box, and as a result they all show signs of stress out of the box. The pouch was folded twice to fit and got creased, the cable got small dents and the straight sections got crooked, the headband got asymmetrical, the earpads got also slightly squashed. Both units were new, purchased from different sellers, same story. The gold colored box and shiny red cloth make the false and pretentious statement that they accomodate a premium product, but it's really just money wasted on masquerade. A more spacious and simpler packaging is needed.SoundAfter three weeks (about 100 hours) it has finally burned in and the upper midrange harshness that was so apparent in the first two weeks is now gone. The bass is punchy and generally dominant at lower volume levels, the mids are always a bit recessed. From about 1/3 volume, the lower treble and upper midrange starts to come foreward and overpower and from 1/2 i can hear some distortion.I find its sound signature most suitable for electronic dance music, and least for symphonic orchestral music.Headstage / soundstage: Everything sounds to come from either inside my head or behind and lower than my head.Sensitivity and volumeIt's easy to drive, even by an iPod. On the Macbook Pro, 25-50% is plenty loud. On the iPod touch it's ideal: 50% is about a medium volume.IsolationSeals properly all around, but surroundings are hearable at low volume levels. To the outside, in a quiet room, there is very small leakage at 1/3 volume (driven by Macbook Pro).ComfortAfter a week of getting used to, it's only slightly tiring after a dozen-hour stint. Sometimes i barely feel they're on, which is ideal. The clamping force is optimal, it doesn't hurt my head and it won't fall off when i tilt my head forward (it's slowly sliding off when i look up).The cups aren't big enough though: the width is barely ok, but they're not tall enough and so the pads press my ear lobes against my head, which makes them sweat. Otherwise it doesn't make the rest of my ears sweat, but they itch sometimes due to the lack of ventilation. It's warm but not hot. These apply for January weather with low humidity and 21℃ inside; I still have to see what it's like with these on in humid summer 35℃.Design and buildThe only metal parts of the whole framework are the inner part of the headband; and the smaller covers of the cups (with the writing and the label), which is misleading because it's only cosmetic: the inner side of that cover is still plastic.The steps of the headband don't hold strongly enough and so the band tends to gradually contract on my head over the course of hours, effectively pulling the cups upwards. This movement is not noticeable per se, but when i check i can feel it has moved out of setting and have to readjust.The articulating parts between the band and the cups make small plasticky clicking and knocking sounds for slight movements, sometimes even when i don't move my head; it's very annoying and distracting. Both V6s i owned did this (this could be similar to the creaking issue of the V700 and V55 i've read about). I needed to make the joints tighter with some stickers to make them shut up.The cable entry on the left cup (where the cable goes into the strain relief), also made noises when moved, as if they were sticking to and unsticking from each other. I had to disassemble the left cup, move and clean the cable and strain relief to eliminate the issue, which was only on the second unit.Cable and plugBoth the coiled cable and the straight plug are big, heavy and look durable.OverallFor the money, the V6 sounds good, and i really appreciate sturdy and utilitarian design in general. But it's just too sloppy, they clearly don't make these so well they originally used to in Japan in the 1980s.
summary: Pros: good sound, affordable. Cons: design, quality control, packaging.

reviewText: They have a great studio quality sound. No effect, no boost, no flashing. Pure output as recorded. And the price? unbeatable pleasure of earing/dollar ratio.
The sound is great; they really block outside sounds; and gives great battery (one AAA) life! The price was right.
Excellent design, fairly good sound, nothing like I had in the 1980s growing up, those could blow your eardrums and still sound great, guess I would need to spend more than $[...] to get that.

A while ago I spent a ton of time researching nice headphones to buy. These have given me months of pleasure so far and I intend on them lasting for many more. They are comfortable, and the sound quality is great. I wear them for hours on end without even noticing, and if I'm sitting at my desk (I plug them into my laptop) I can get up and walk around the entire room while I am still wearing them. The cord is long and 'telephone'-like so it is easy to manage. These things are built to last, are comfortable, and sound like they should cost $150. Can't go wrong with these.

Quick summary:  Awesome pair of headphones definitely recommend, I picked these up for $50 when Amazon had their sale.I was a little nervous on some of the reviews saying the headphones were too tight.  I'm a decently sized guy and so I thought this might be a problem and waited to purchase them and then finally gave in.Headphones were not tight at all. Fit really comfortably. Packaging was nice, and included a nice bag to carry the headphones in (something I overlooked somehow after reading the description over and over)Don't really need to comment on sound, because every other comment on here is spot on:  Sound is amazing for price.  These can definitely compete with some of my Bose headphones which are upwards of 2x or 4x the price.Will update if something breaks etc.EDIT:  Will not lower stars.  The headphones after 45 min+ create discomfort in the ears that slowly grows into pain.  I don't know if it 100% due to the tightness or the way they sit on my head, but there is discomfort.

I bought these headphones 10 years ago. I don't think I can add much to all of the positive reviews here. Simply put, these are possibly the best sounding headphones on the market. A few years ago, one of the earpads began to tear apart from the inside, so I decided to replace these with another headphone. I tried several, including what I thought would be just as good or better, the newer Sony MDR-V600. But they didn't sound as good. In fact nothing I tried came close to the sound of the MDR-V6, so I kept using them even with the deteriorating pad.These headphones are used by many artists in the studio. If you own the new Rickie Lee Jones CD (The Sermon On Exposition Blvd), look at the picture of her on the back of the CD booklet and you'll see that she's wearing these headphones. Oddly she seems to have them on backwards (left on the right ear). Perhaps they reversed the image, as you would see if you put a slide in the projector the wrong way.As my torn earpad got worse, I thought I'd buy another MDR-V6 since the Amazon price is even better than what I paid 10 years ago. Then I discovered that Sony sells replacement earpads for this model, so I ordered 2 from Sony and now my old headphones are good as new.But I will probably order these headphones from Amazon anyway so that I have a spare in case Sony decides to discontinue them someday. At this price, you can't go wrong. I highly recommend them.

Bought these headphones as a gift for my son after he researched different products and decided on these. I said I thought they would be good, since I bought a pair of Sony V6 way back in 1987, and I still have them! The current design appears to be identical to my pair, so I guess if it ain't broke, why fix it? The only complaint I have ever had about Sony headphones is that the ear cup pad material falls apart after a couple of years or so, but other than that I highly recommend these.

I like everything about these headphones. Sound's perfect, comfortable, enough reach (coiled cable is a Godsend). One thing though, the pressure-against-the-head-after-extended-wearing thing everybody mentions is TRUE. But at least I dont mind one tiny bit; these are too awesome
summary: Pretty much what I expected according to the reviews

reviewText: Great quality in sound and are quite durable. We use a pair at work to monitor Camera sound during interviews and it blocks exterior noise well without completely blocking off sound so you can still hear your fellow crew.Folds down to a manageable size, and comes with a cheapo leather pouch that does the job. For the $60 or so bucks I paid for it I really can't find anything wrong with it or any reason to go for a more expensive model.If you want Beats headphones, take the stickers off the side and use a white sharpie and write a B.Good set of features for the price for sure.

Everywhere you find quality reviews of these headphones (including audiophile sites), the V6 ranks highly.  They sound great for all kinds of music as well as for monitoring audio during video editing.  Probably not suited for audio mixing as these phones are made for great sound, not the sort of flat response you'd probably want for mixing.These phones sit on top of my ears, and as other reviewers have noted, they can get a bit warm and little too snug after a couple hours of wearing them.  However, I don't wear them too long in any one sitting, so it doesn't bother me.
