reviewText: After reading all the praises over these headphones, I decided to purchase them..so know I wonder, I don't know what kind of music you guys listen to, but it's not that these things have not the greatest bass, is that they simply do NOT have bass.I would definitely use these phones for what they were made for at first, which is fidel monitor reproduction or studio works, but on a everyday basis, they just totally don't do it for me.Any reccomendations?

Headphones exist to provide a provide listening experience - so as not to blast other's with your music (or whatever) and to isolate the environment.I've had several headphones over the years - the Koss Pro4A, Sony MDR V150, and some miscellaneous in-ear types.The Koss Pro4A finally wore out, and I figured I would try something lighter.The MDR V150 was a good choice, comfortable, lightweight, and good fidelity (at least to my aging, too-many-years-on-a-flight-deck hearing) and aged gracefully if not well. The problems with the liner are well documented.However, my son grabbed them to wear when playing his online games and that was that.So, I went shopping for a new pair and decided to try the MDR V6.I'm impressed.Some reviewers consider them uncomfortably tight, but I'm fine, and I have a "large head". The cushions are reasonable soft and provide good isolation.It's the fidelity that blows me away for the price.  The volume is good (again, too many years on a carrier deck, I "need" volume) and the bass is smooth and rich without being obnoxious.  The higher frequencies are clear and sharp without abrasive characteristics.The adapter is the "smaller" 1/8" that is common to iPads, phones, notebooks, etc. A bonus is a nice 1/4" jack that doesn't just snap onto the smaller one but screws on tight!  Nice quality touch.For the price?  Excellent, and highly recommended.

These are the best headphones I've ever owned. I bought them for my electronic V-Drums and studio recording, and couldn't be more pleased with them. The "flat" sound is exactly what I wanted. For recording, they can't be EQ'd to death or you wouldn't know what you're really listening to.I have 2 pairs of these, been using them for nearly 10 years, and can't recommend them enough.  Everything from the clean, strong bass to the mids, to the highs, everything is crystal clear.  And the coiled cord will save you your studio/office/home/work every time.They aren't practical to use as ipod headphones I don't think, because of the coiled cord, they're not made to be mobile, walking around town, etc.
summary: Perfect Studio Headphones for Perfect Price

reviewText: I bought the headphone a week ago. And i have no luck with headphones, these seem very good . costly but  is a great value. Here are my thoughts .They  look well made. The  weight for the headphones is not as heavy as some may think. I use them for hours daily.I even walk around with them. being a women i don,t like heavy weight. So i find the weight good. The ear pads are very soft, also replaceable  which you can't do with some. The fit is an over the ear .They look kind of big, but don't let that fool you. I am a women with small ears , they fit nicely . The cord is one sided , and thick. It also looks like a phone cord .I wish the cord was replaceable .  I don't think  I will need to replace Them . The length of the cord is longer than others . That is great for me because my CD player is on my book case near the couch. The sound is great even with the volume at low  sound. You don't need to put it that loud. The balance of the sound is well balanced. can fold them , which is great for draws. Lets talk pouches soft well made  with a drew string. I like pouches in my opinion . I hope this helps you make up your mind.
summary: Lets talk headphones you decide after reading!

reviewText: I dont normally come online to write reviews, but felt these headphones definitely deserved a few kind words.  If you are looking for recording studio quality headphones for 1/4 the price, these are it.  The bass isn't completely overblown like it is in most headphones now a days, and the clarity is absolutely outstanding.  I have very large ears and these headphones fit over them like gloves.  My ears don't get too hot like leather enclosed headphones can have the tendency to do, and I have no problem wearing them for hours on end.  Also, although this isn't a feature of the headphones specifically, they cancel out outside noise fairly well.  I know finding the right headphones can be tough because they are much like a car - you don't know how you're going to like them until you try them.  But the Sony MDR-V6s will not disappoint.

My daughter asked for Dr. Dre Beats for Christmas. While looking at reviews and checking the price compared to other brands, I found the Sony MDR-V6. I also have some connections in the radio/music biz and emailed a friend who started as a DJ in the 1980's and still dabbles in music. He told me he has had a pair of the Sony MDR's since forever.Long story short, I saved a bunch of cash and my daughter LOVES her gift.
it's like a classic headphone but can beat many modern day headphone in terms of sound reproduction and quality.definitely won't regret owning this
summary: simple, nice and it just works

reviewText: When I bought this, I thought I had bought a set of gold plated diamond necklace.  Sony packaged it like it was a limited edition.  I paid 50 bucks for headphones that were mediocre before and this is only around 75.  Very solid sound and great for monitoring, I thought about needing a 300 dollar pair of sennheiser but a colleague said you won't get more out of a more expensive set than this.  I'm not sure what's the difference between this and MDR7506 but I can only image how awesome the professional ones are though.

I am very pleased with the sound of these headphones. It is detailed and well-balanced across the frequency range. I am happy to listen for extended periods and the headphones are comfortable. I cannot comment on thumping deep bass because I listen to the wrong kind of music for that. I bought a pair of these a couple of years ago but gave them to a family member. This newer pair cost much less but sound every bit as good.On sound quality alone I would give these five stars but the construction is a bit concerning. Pulling on the extenders to lower the earcups feels as if it is pulling the headband apart. The old pair extended smoothly. I don't know if quality has gone down or I just got a wonky pair. Since I can leave the earcups extended this is not an ongoing problem but it does raise questions about overall quality. I haven't had any other similar issues so far.
I love the coiled long cord. For me as a musician this is much more practical than the short cords you get with most headphones. Great sound.

As a professional broadcaster, I'm looking for 3 things in any headphone--great sound,durability and a low price, since most people in my line of work aren't rich.  As far as I'm concerned, the Sony MDR-V6 and MDR-7506 deliver on all 3 counts. For more on both 'phones, see my review of the ((ASIN:Sony MDR-7506 Large-Diaphragm Professional stereo Headphones)).
summary: hard to go wrong with these headphones

reviewText: Extended frequency response for harmonics,  thus sound is crystal clear. Also bass response is excellent. Very comfortable on the head and ears. This phone does NOT eliminate ambient noise, nor is it designed to do so.

Bought these on Cyber Monday for about $60. I was very surprised at quality of sound. A little heavier in treble than I was used to but not at all a bad thing unless your a 'Beats Baby' and don't appreciate the songs for how they were intended. They are comparable to a pair of Klipch S4i Headphones priced around $120 I own. But both sound better than many of the $80-160 headphones out there imo.

Pros:Deep bass and crisp treble. A frequency range of 20-30,000 Hz is hard to come by at this price.A bit tight at first, but once broken in, they are very comfortable. I just set some books between them for a day and they felt much better afterwards.Very long cord. I can walk all around my room without taking them off. It's a thick sturdy cord, and it's coiled so the cord isn't just dangling everywhere.Comes with an adapter for larger audio jacks.Comes with a nice carrying bag which are a perfect fit for your headphones and ipod.Want some makeshift speakers? Turn the headphones outward and boom you have some decent speakers to set down for decent listening quality. (Note that they aren't that loud this way though.)After setting up an equalizer, my music experience was twice as good. I feel like I'm listening to all my music for the first time again. These headphones truthfully make me appreciate music more.Cons:Padding wears off after a while and replacement pads appear to be rather pricy.There's a couple rather thin cords that come out of the top of each headphone and go through the headband. The exposed part of this cord seems to be very prone to getting caught or snipped. You can tape them down with electrical tape though, and the exposed part is very short.

I bought these for a trifecta purpose.1)  I can use them while recording music.2)  I can have over-the-ear cans to listen to my mp3's3)  So I can enjoy music again.I'm not single anymore (haven't been for a LONG time), and I don't have the set-up that I used to have in order to listen to music at the volume I enjoyed.  Nor do I drive my car often enough to be able to listen to much more than a few tracks at a time.  Then my wife complains if I turn my music up past 3 on the volume knob.  So I pretty much fell out of the music listening loop over the years.  Music was, and has been a huge part of my life, and I miss it.  Now, with these cans, I can lock myself in the basement, sit back, and be that dude on the old Memorex packaging being blown away in his chair.  These things make music sound SO much better than it does coming through any loudspeaker.  It's like you're right there with it.  These aren't even on the same playing field as earbuds, and those expensive Dre Beats headphones suck compared to these.  After comparing the two, I'm SO glad I didn't waste my money on Beats.  I will likely buy a few more pairs of these so I don't have to keep transferring them from one device to the next.  And I took the advice of other reviewers and picked up theBeyerdynamic EDT 250 Velour Padded Earcushions for DT250, DT280, Sony MDR7506 and V6 Headphones (Pair)to replace the ones that came on it.  They are much more comfortable and don't cause your ears to sweat nearly as bad as the ones that come on it.If you are a true music aficionado, you will not regret this purchase.
summary: Allows me to enjoy music again

reviewText: I wanted a set of headphones that were comfortable enough so I could wear them all day while editing, with great sound quality and durable enough to take in the field.  After talking with several others that have been working in production for years, the V6 kept coming up.  I love these headphones, they are very comfortable and the sound quality is great.  I understand that the earmuffs flake after a while but at $12 to replace them I'm not worried.  I highly recommend these headphones!
summary: Best All Around Headphones at a Great Price!

reviewText: These headphones sound very good and are comfortable. These work fine with an ipod. These are very good for the price.

Man...Prepare for strong emotions.... I'm not kidding...I must say that I love headphones. I have around 14 diferent types of them here. Including in-ear, neckbands, sportproof and others.... :DAll kind of brands.. Apple, Sony, Sennheisser, Samson, Philips and more..... I love to listen rock and roll and progressive metal.I really love pure sound and good bass response. I have a couple of Yamaha's HS 50 reference monitors, I they just deliver  a pure sound with my cd's and mp3's.Weel, after read a lot looking for a cool sound. I pick this reviews here... What a luck!!!Believe in every positive review on this page. This headphone is amazing. The best I've ever had in my life.The sound is crystal. The bass frequencies are perfect. The overall is great. It's a masterpiece!!!If you like a little bit of music, please, do a favor to yourself and buy this beauty right now.It totally rocks!!!Out of the box I plug it to my iphone and just pick one random song  from the Library:Will you follow - from The Revenge album - with Russel Allen and Jorn Lande - I love this music!!http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000V8WU2M/ref=dm_mu_dp_trk5Well, I must say.... tears roll down man... the sound was amazing in all aspects. The music reborn for me with this incredible product from Sony.It is a little bit smaller than my others heaphones, and lighter too. So comfortable and smooth.Now I will listen to all my music from another point of view. The quality is ultra. I'm gonna buy others to get one around in every corner of my house.Hey, stop reading this review, and buy it now!!!When arrives, pick your song, close your eyes and be ready to travel to the heaven with lullabies from Sony whispering in your ears.Well, the cons are: 34 years in my life without listen to a sound like this. Thank God and amazon reviewers to show me the best way to listen my songs!

Been kind of interested in adding another set of headphones to my collection. Mostly used for mostly music playback and some PC gaming. These headphones fit the bill. At their price, how can you beat these?Sound, these have a great sound. Just so you know where I'm coming from...I've been married to my Bose Triport headphones that I bought years ago. I paid $150 for those. Compared to those, soundwise, they're about even, with the edge going to the sturdier Sony's. The sound is excellent at the bottom, mid's and highs. I found the sound level to be even accross the sound field. Very flat. But flat in a good way, as these can produce very good lows, mids and highs. Not any one particular range dominated, which is perfect.Construction is without a doubt, excellent. These things will take a beating. The cushions are comfortable. I have a huge head and I found these to be fine. Not tight or uncomfortable.The only ding against this fine headset is the cord, it's long, thick and heavy. Not very portable. I wish there was a way to mod the wiring to put something like what Bose uses on these, then these would be PERFECT. I believe a different version of this headset has a more portable wire. 3.5mm jack is not compatible with iPhone's bumper case. Carrying case is thick and cheap looking.Overall, if you're a headset aficionado, I think you will appreciate these. A fine headset to add to the collection. Pass on the Beats by Dre, save money and enjoy.**UPDATE**10/21/2013**The cord was really getting to me, so I cut it. Big mistake. I was hoping to just splice the wiring and make the wire shorter, and manageable. When I went to cut the cord and strip the ends, I found these very thin wires. I believe they were L channel, R channel and ground. Well, when I went to touch the ends together and test, I got no audio whatsoever. GREAT, just killed a perfectly good set of headphones. Well, long story short, I was able to solder the ends together, insulate the solder with electrical tape and fix the headphones. Worked like a charm. I wouldn't recommend this to anyone. I lucked out. I thought this set was cooked for sure.

Best investment if you are into music. Perfect when listening at home or watching you favorite movies. Acoustic sounds are amazing. You can hear every little detail of the sound. If you are into hip hop because of banging bass in your ears then look somewhere else.
summary: never think twice just buy it!

reviewText: Sound quality is as good as I expected.Would definitely recommend it if you are looking for a good quality but lower end price range headphone.

I bought a pair for record monitoring about 20 years ago and liked them so much I bought a second set before they were discontinued.  The retailer I got them from is long gone but these babies are still available.  Not that I need them, they still function perfectly.  I keep one on the computer and one on the stereo.  They are not the best sounding cans I've heard as I own a set of Stax.  BUT they are the best monitors I've ever used.  A little hot/harsh above 10KHz but that's what you need to hear what you've got.  They can smell any clipping.  The Stax earpads have gotten flaky but these Sony's have aged well.  They get dropped, ripped off my head etc. all the time, no problem.  They fold up compactly in a travel pouch and plug into anything.  I wear them for hours comfortably.  I have other Sonys, Sennheisers, Beyers and others that I can't listen to anymore because of these.  There is no better value that I know of.
It sounds great. And over the last year, It has proven to be quite sturdy. Easy to store in the bag that it comes with. I highly recommend it.

I tried those from a colleague of mine, comparing directly to the current "king of cheap cans" $20 Senn HD201. Very comfortable closed cans, nicely fit the ear. Soundwise, they are too bright, lacking mostly in mid-bass (100-500Hz area). I'm not a bass-head at all, and these seem to have some of the typical deep/DJ bass. Sound is just plain thin. Otherwise they are louder than Senn 201 at the same volume setting, so I guess they are more efficient.Not bad for 70$ if you listen to light jazz of acoustic; there are better cans otherwise.
This headphones are really comfortable, it's quality for the price it's top notch. I highly recommend them.Best Headphones I've ever had, mind blown by the sound quality.
Loved the larger V6s a few years ago but as for sound they are great, a bit smaller but lighter which is nice. The only problem I see is one of the ear protectors comes off more than usual.

Wonderful! The specs looked great. After receipt, I tried them out with my 5 Star iTunes playlist. I had been using Etymotics ear buds, but wanted a longer cord and an over the ear style. The Sony beat them hand downs. I had originally ordered a pair of Audio-Technica ($148.00). To me, the Audio-Technica muffled the bass sounds a bit and didn't give me the crisp highs that I had expected, or was used to. I returned those and ordered the Sony MDR-V6 (about $85), and couldn't be happier! Better than the Etymotic ear buds - solid bass - but not too much., and nice crisp highs. Also, they are a bit more comfortable than the Audio-Technica, and a lot less expensive! The Sony's are solid!
summary: Wow, Just Wow - Better than Headphones at Almost Twice the Price

reviewText: I don't care what you hear about headphones from other manufacturers.  These are and have been the real deal for years.  I worked for years in broadcasting and music.  These are the best deal of any over the ear headphones.  Clear highs, detailed midrange, great accurate bass not the muddled sound people want these days.  There is a reason why these and the similar 7605s are used by professionals.  They are still the best, most accurate phones on the market especially at the price range.  I still have my originals I got back in the 80's and am buying another pair which will last another 20 years.

This is my first expensive headphones, and the voice is definitely better.However the first 10 minutes of listening I heard secondary ring in the background. I thought it's broken. But it didn't happen again.

I was going to buy the professional alternative of these headphones so before I did I read some of the reviews and there wasn't much of a difference I believe the only difference was the 1/4 plug is gold plated and this one isn't but these headphones are worth every penny. I use it for video editing and they rock hard.
Use this because of my baby.  I like it.  But after 2+ hours of usage, my ears get bit tired.

I just got these recently after reading all the reviews here.  The others aren't lying, these headphones are unbelievable.  I find them extremely comfortable, and don't think they feel heavy like others have said.  The build quality is top notch, and feel like they could last for the 10-15 years that others' have.As far as the sound goes, they seem to do better with real music than fake.  Basically, if you're listening to classical, jazz, acoustic, vocals or classic rock, I can't imagine anything could ever reproduce sound better.  I've listened to Led Zeppelin for 20 years, and now I'm re-listening, hearing (and feeling) subtle sounds I never heard before.  They'll almost bring you to tears as you go back and listen to your favorite albums.Where they seem to fail is with fake music, such as rap, hip hop, or anything else created with synthesizers or computers.  If that sort of non-music is your thing, you may be better off with the Dre headphones.  If real music is what you listen to, you absolutely have to buy these.
summary: One of the best things I've ever own

reviewText: These headphones are LEGIT.Sound quality: pure eargasmBuild: design is very good, everything looks very durable and doesn't look cheapCord: Long thick and coiled (oh yeah lol ) which means its likely not to break but it also means its kinda heavy :/Comfort: pretty comfortable considering my head is abnormally large and I wear glasses. I've tried the bose triports and i think those ear pads are somewhat softer and more comfy. If you live in a extremely hot area then your ears might get sweatyI also love the  collapsible design.

The headphones themselves have great sound quality, are comfortable for long periods, and are relatively cheap.  Additionally, the sound is very well contained, so they're very nice when you don't want to bother people near you with your music.  As a bonus, they come with a nice carrying bag and fold down for easy transport.

there's like almost 1000 reviews at the time of writing this.  I can only say the quality it very good.  I have ears which approach a size only talked about in National Geographic.  So the one issue I have is the pads are too small.

These headphones are amazing. I'm coming from earbuds, which sounded fine to me, but they're nothing compared to these. I got them on sale at $40, which is an absolute steal in my opinion. Highly recommend these headphones, especially for heavier rock/metal music.

I was very disappointed, thinking I would have to get another set and hope that it is half as good as this one. To my surprise, they are still for sale on Amazon, and for less than what I first paid for them!  I have ordered myself a pair.  This set sounds awesome, much better than my boyfriend's $300 headphones.  Sure, those have more bass, but these sound more natural and clear to me. reviewText: I used to be a music producer for a few friends who are djs and this headphones are the best sound quality I have ever heard... honestly, at least try it, you don't have to be a producer or a music expert to notice the BIG difference to headphones that are not studio monitors. And the may not be noise canceling but they are very well made so you won't hear anything unless you are behind an airplane.

As the hundreds of others here have testified, the Sony MDR-V6 headphones are true classics--well made, great sounding, and long-lasting. As to the last point, I purchased mine from a discount electronics store on Canal Street in NYC around '88 or '89. I replaced the coiled cord with a longer, straight one from another pair of Sony cans that I didn't like as much, because I prefer floppy and loose over bouncy, springy cords. They've traveled with me around the world several times, monitored home recordings and a wide variety of prerecorded music, and handled it all with aplomb. I had to replace the earpads once because of the ubiquitous flaking, but that's a very small price to pay to keep a quality headphone such as these going for almost a quarter century! Thank you Sony, it's good to see you still do something right (i.e. make these), in case I ever need to replace them for some reason!

There are some fakes going around, so rest assured that the ones sold here on amazon are real.I got these for a great price on Black Friday. Even at the current price, they are a great buy. The sound of these headphones are so much better than all the others I own. Most importantly, the audio levels are higher, so I don't have to crank up the volume as high on my stereo receiver.Only two negatives:1) Even after using them for over 1 month, they are still a bit tight on my head. Maybe it's just me, as I have a large head.2) The adjustment for the cups tend to slip after putting them on and off. No biggie, as they are numbered and can be put right back into the same spot.

This is my first "professional" set of earphones.  I use it mostly to listen to recorded webcasts and lessons while avoiding distractions.  The pads are insulating enough to block out most of the unwanted noise (TV blaring in the other room, people chatting on the phone, etc.). The quality of the materials used, as well as the cord is quite good for the price. I do recommend this product.

I've also used them to listen to music, and have found them to be quite a pleasure!If I were to nitpick, I'd say the coiled cord is a bit cumbersome due to its weight. If you are looking for headphones that completely surround your ears, are soft, and have great sound quality, these are perfect. The collapse and fit into a soft case for easy portability. Does not hurt my bald  head and just as important, the sound is not overruled by the boom, boom, boom base...this is thankfully not a headphone for rap...just a nice, comfortable, inexpensive, well made headphone...if I had two more ears I'd gladly buy another.

They sound fantastic and feel very comfortable after watching 2 hour long movies or listening to long music sessions while working around the house.Keep in mind, like most headphones, they require time to "burn in." Out of the box the highs sounded off and bass was mediocre. After a week of listening the headphones sound fantastic and keep getting better. Remember this when purchasing these headphones. I listen to music at work 6-7 hours each day working on the computer. I had what I thought was a pretty good set of Sony headphones ($30) that was a lot better than the cheap headphones I had been using.  After reading the reviews on the Sony MDR-V6 Monitor Series Headphones with CCAW Voice Coil, I decided to upgrade. I got these refurbished for under $50 and I can hear nuances in the music that was not there in my other headphones.  They are comfortable enough to wear all day and I do not have to turn up the volume as high as the other phones to hear the music as clearly.  Very pleased with the purchase.  I considered an even more expensive Sony set that was also well reviewed but don't see how I could have liked them better than I do these.  They also fold up nicely to fit in my computer case without worrying about them getting damaged from fitting awkwardly with other items in the case, something I have had issues with before with headphones of this size.  I will not hesitate to get another pair if these get stolen or lost.  It would be hard to go back to what I used before, the difference is that noticeable.

So my Sony MDR-V600s died an ignominious death with a cut cord and completely deteriorated ear pads.  I'd read lots of good stories about the V6s so decided to take the plunge.  I figured if Sony has been making these for over 20 years there had to something inherently "right" about them.  And there is.  I use them almost exclusively with my PC using a HiFiMan USB DAC/headphone amp (available here at Amazon), and the sound is so superior to the aforementioned Sony cans.  The ear pad rot is solved for as long as I live by purchasing some Beyer pads as replacement.  I know there are better headphones out there.  I would have loved some really good AKGs.  Money gets in the way sometimes.  Highly recommended.
Love these have done well and still have great sound and quality just as good as good if not better then the hip hop brands

After owning the Sony MDR-V6 earphone for 2 years I have just bought my second set for my wife.  My original purchase of this earphone still looks like brand new but my wife was starting to use it and hence the purchase of the second one.  I am hard of hearing and so I use it while watching TV or playing music.  The clarity of this headset is super and I can virtually hear everything that goes on during the broadcast.  It has made my TV viewing so much more enjoyable.  I used to miss about 50% of what was said in TV shows or movies on TV and this is not the case now.  Interestingly enough my wife, who has normal hearing, has found that wearing the headset increases her enjoyment of the show as well.Both purchases were made at Amazon.com and I highly recommend not only the Sony MDR-V6 headset but also making your purchase at Amazon.  Shipment was free and went without a hitch.

Sony MDR-V6 Monitor Series Headphones with CCAW Voice Coil its very nice come in a beauty box, sounds very well and eliminate almost all external noise, but when you use it in a Ipod, get the volume down of indicated by the device, in my case an Ipod classic 7th generation. by the other hand the sound its good and the headphone is Very robust

reviewText: I've had a pair of Sony MDR-XB500 headphones for a couple years and I've been pleasantly surprised at the sound, despite years of my holding Sony in low regard.  After reading up on MDR-V6 (apparently a classic design, dating back to the 80's) I took the plunge.  Glad I did.Word of caution: As stated elsewhere, these are "monitors" and as such they will faithfully reproduce your music, without coloring or enhancement.  In this age of compressed digital music, that means you might have to accept that some of your (older?) MP3s do not sound nearly as good as you thought.  This is not the fault the MDR-V6 - it's just accurately rendering what was always there.  Only now you can hear it.The first thing I noticed switching from the XB500 to the V6 was the altered bass presence.  The 'XB' in XB500 means 'extended bass' (or 'enhanced' - I forget which), and the headphones are designed to give that 'boomier' bass experience.  The V6s don't boom, instead rendering the bass deeply and tightly.  Swapping between the two a few more times revealed the XB500's increased bass performance was the result of trading off 'muddy boominess' for detail and accuracy.  The good news is you can easily coax the V6 into duplicating that boominess by adjusting your equalizer's bass settings and overriding the V6's naturally flat response. In short, the V6 can emulate the XB500 far better than XB500 can do the opposite, and this would be the case with any other headphones that feature a bass-heavy signature.  As for the mid and upper frequencies - same as the bass.  Everything is there, clearly articulated and balanced.  If something doesn't sound good, the problem lies somewhere before the signal got to the headphones.As for comfort, the MDR-V6 is lighter than it looks, is adequately padded and stay's in place without feeling like it's been clamped to your head (a deal killer for me when I tried on a pair of Sennheiser HD-280 Pros).  The collapsible design makes it easy to transport, but the great price means you won't care as you can just buy extras to keep at work or wherever and save yourself the trouble of packing them up.My one gripe - and I admit to having no valid justification for this - is the long coiled chord.  When plugged into my Samsung Galaxy Media Player, the headphones dwarf the player, and the 9+ foot chord is far more than required to reach a player that is most likely in my pocket.  The MDR-XB500, on the other hand, features a flat chord less than half that length with an "L" shaped plug, all of which is better suited for a portable player.  But I wouldn't pick my headphones based on their chord style, and the MDR-V6 sounds great on the portable player, so I'll just live with the chord and remind myself that the V6s are monitors, not ear buds, and sound as different as they look.
summary: Great value - beats headphones costing 3-4 times as much.

They have lasted over 2 years so far. The only thing is that my chihuhua dog also loves it! ( She eats the headpads). Very solid headphones not like the soft crap they sell today. My brother's $200 headphones can't even beat my headphone's sound quality.I recommend these headphones over %120!

reviewText: I love this, the sound quality is very nice and it fits super comfortably. It far out performs any beats in sound quality and comfort. Some people may find the cord a little long however

PROS: Great Sound, Quality parts, decent amount of base, it will probably last me a long timeCONS: After wearing these for a long time (2+ hours), it's a bit uncomfortable to wear.  I have a relatively small head, so I thought it might not feel too "tight", but the ear cushions don't completely go around the ear, and some discomfort is caused.  The coiled cord needs to rest somewhere, otherwise it does seem to be slightly heavy on the left ear cup - just rest the cord on your lap.  I will look into getting the velour pads that others have mentioned in the future.OTHER: Slight discomfort aside, it's a great sounding headphone and does a great job at isolating surrounding sound.  In fact, I thought it was such a good head phone, I purchased a second one for later use - in case I lose this one.  My old headphones have been SONY and Panasonic, both were great, but plastic head band would crack after much use and I didn't know how much better sounding these V6s were until I tried them.  If you're considering getting these, I'd say go for it!
Great Product. Works well and the packaging that it comes with is very convenient. I definitely recommend this product to anyone.
Im a drummer and harmonic singer and for what I need to hear when recording and for just playing music on my computer, these are perfectly crisp and feel good on my head.

The quality of the material may not be the greatest. But these are extremely comfortable headphones that produce sound equivalent, if not better than, most headphones that will cost you over $300. I wear my MDR-V6 for hours at a time while studying or just listening to music for enjoyment and the sound is flawless to my ears. I listen to symphonies, operas and many varieties of heavy metal. I highly recommend these headphones for listening to any of those three genres of music as they make the music sound exceptional.

I've owned a lot of headphones over the years.  They've mostly been the cheap variety that come with portable units (Walkman, portable CD PLayers, portable radios) - most work OKm but the sound quality certainly hasn't been the best.I've also had "good" headphones for my home sound system.  I've used them to monitor recordings I was making and for just private listening.  These included headphones from Radio Shack that were Koss knockoffs where the liquid in the pads dried up.  Most recently I had a pair of Sony MDR-600's that I found in a local store and thought sounded pretty good.Then they broke and I found ecstasy in the Sony MDR-V6's.  When I first bought the '600's, I checked the reviews at the time.  Many said that the '600's were the replacement for the retired V6's - some moaned about the '600's quality compared to the V6's.  I'd already bought the '600's, and thought they were great, and I got a number of years satisfactory service from them.After a move, I dug my V600's out of the box they were packed in to find that the pads had deteriorated to non-usable status.  Despondent, I checked Amazon and found that the '600s were still available so I immediately ordered another pair.  That was last fall (2009).I'd barely gotten 6 months' service out of the new '600s when something happened to the connector that allowed the right earpiece to fold.  It kept coming apart.  After some investigation, I determined that they were still under Sony's warranty, and have sent them out to be repaired.Meantime, while poking around on Amazon's website I found that the V6's were once again available as new.  Researching further I found many glowing reviews and decided this time I'd do it right and order the V6's.  Once they arrived, I found audio bliss.Recordings that I was well familiar with suddenly sounded new again.  Details in the recordings I'd missed were suddenly apparent and my joys of listening to music have greatly increased.Maybe there are some really expensive headphones out there from other brands, but for what I'd call a value price, this pair of Sony MDR v6's has me all excited about my music collection again.The reviews that talk about the tightness and the "hot ears syndrome" are true.  Being a closed headphone, they fit around the ear and outsiders don't hear a thing, so I consider the tightness a plus.  "Hot ears"? - A small price to pay for the exquisite sound.I'm not sure what I'll do with the V600's when Sony returns them.  I'll do a comparison for sure, maybe keep that older pair in the bedroom for nighttime listening.  But for sure, the V6's will be my main goto headphones for years to come.

I purchased these headphones 20 years ago and loved them. They were comfortable, and I was impressed with the sound quality; true tone, nice soundstage, no additional coloration to the music. I don't know how I lost them then, but I have been looking to replace them since, and after shopping the big box stores, nothing sounded quite as good as I remember.To my surprise, they were never discontinued by Sony, so I purchased them Christmas '09 through Amazon, and after trying them out again after 15 years, they sound great! Just like before.If you really REALLY appreciate the quality sound of your music, don't be afraid to purchase these. They sound great at a fraction of the cost of other headphones out there.Thanks, Sony, for holding on to the classics. If it isn't broke, don't fix it!
I bought this slightly used for $40 on amazon, considering these are normally $100+, and are so highly spoken of, I highly recommend them. I'm very happy with this purchase.

The headphones had great sound quality, while it lasted for a very few days!!!Got the headphones January 22, and as of today (March 1) the right speaker is dead and I barely used them at all(only on weekends).I hear people saying the MDR V6 has good build quality, but there's no way I can believe them. All the wires are in place. I even open it to see if it was a connection issue. But no, all wires are connected. It can only be a Driver Unit defect.Terrible product.90 bucks flewed away!Bought mine from market place seller  “Electronica Direct”.Unfortunately  I can't give 0 stars! Stay away from this headphones!
