I love these things so much. They're so comfy and have an excellent, loud, clear, sound. I got mine with the Beyerdynamic Velour replacement pads and it is perfect. Noise isolation is great, the soft texture feels very nice, and they just look professional. A+ on quality, now let's see how long they last.

This is the first headphone set I have ever tried for longer than  5 minutes . I guess it takes some getting used to because my ears hurt after watching a TV for a couple of hours.Maybe it was because after I put them on and then leaned back on my recliner which is extra plush with a pillow back headrest , the head band slightly pushed on my ears so after an hour they were painful.I fixed this problem by readjusting them after my head was already on the headrest. Either that or I have become accustomed to the headphones ? I think the sound quality is not as good as the Bose headphones I tried at Fredmeyers . But a review site that had both Bose & Sony MDR-v6 Headphones on it , rated the Sony MDR-v6 as better in sound quality ?
summary: Sound quality 5 stars comfort level 4 stars

reviewText: The have great sound quality.  Perfect for mixing and just listening to anywhere!  I would definitely recommend these to a friend.

I've never owned a quality pair of headphones. Ever since I was a kid and jammed on my Walkman, I've always sprung for the cheapest pair I could find as price was more expedient to me than quality. The most expensive kind I've ever bought were two sets of $30 cans from either Sony or Panasonic, each of which broke less than six months after I bought them because they were cheap and shoddily-made. For the last five years, I've primarily subsisted on the set of white earbuds that come standard with all Apple products. After accidentally sending my current earbuds through the washing machine for the second time, I threw them away and thought, "I think it's finally time to upgrade."But what to upgrade to? For weeks prior, I had been enticed by headphones by Beats by Dre and Bose, easily the most recognizable and popular headphone brands today, and they were indeed a step up from the Apple buds in terms of sound. However, before I dropped $300 on a new pair of phones, I did some research on Amazon, and boy howdy, was I glad I didn't just pick "what sounded nice" in the store. Not only was it consistently made clear that the quality on Beats and Bose models were not all that great, it was also made apparent to me that one could obtain a superior set for less than a third of the price. I researched hard for a week, hemming and hawing between the MDR-V6, the MDR-7506, and the Audio Technica ATH-M50s (twice the price of the other two at $160), but I finally settled on the V6 for a nice primer into the world of audiophilia.Many other reviewers make the note that both the V-6 and the 7506 have been around for decades and are both widely used in the TV, music, and radio industries thanks to their clear, even sound (and, probably, their low selling price). Even fresh out of the lovely gold box with red velvet interior trimming (a sign that you're about to embark on a real musical journey very soon), they sounded heavenly compared to what I've been used to. I'm not yet through the fabled "burn-in" period yet as I just received these two days ago, but if they get any better than they are already, I imagine that I'll experience something similar to Dante ascending the staggered tiers of Paradise.To get the most out of your listening experience with these headphones, either listen to original sources like CDs or vinyl or, when copying from these sources, do so in a "lossless" format like FLAC or Apple Lossless. Like most people, I had zero idea that when songs are converted to MP3, they are greatly compressed and lose their original quality. Listening to my collection of MP3s and comparing them to lossless sound, it was as though I was listening to a great-sounding band from behind a glass window -- I could hear them just fine, but the sound is somewhat muffled, and there are background effects that are cut out. Lossless songs, on the other hand, sound much richer and fuller than MP3s -- almost three-dimensional. With headphones like these, you're really doing yourself a service by updating your library to lossless as I'll be in the process of doing for the next several months. True, they can be anywhere from twice to four times their tiny MP3 size, but given how cheap and plentiful hard drive space is these days, I'm really not complaining.Also, with the V-6's, you'll really begin to appreciate both professionaly-produced modern recordings and older music that has been remastered. For instance, I listened to the '87 version of U2's "The Joshua Tree." It still sounds just fine, but since it's such an old CD, the sound seems very flat and 2D. With newer or remastered music, I was elevated to a new level of audio listening. Hearing Jimi Hendrix rocking his Stratocaster on "All Along the Watchtower," the luscious opening piano notes to Fleetwood Mac's "Songbird," or the discordant, gouging riff that ends Nine Inch Nails' "Hurt" as though everybody I'm listening to is there in the room with me is quite the experience. For years, I had no idea that music could sound this good.In terms of the make and build of the V-6's, I'm extremely happy. Gone are the cheap, dinky molding of the headphones of my youth. These are made with a much stronger, durable plastic, and they feel like they're made to last. The cans themselves are comfy, and I don't experience any of the head-pinching that some get from the headband. Note that these aren't totally noise-cancelling, but they do let you rock out while lying in bed next to someone who's sleeping. Many, many times already, people having been talking to me, and I've had to kill the sound and take them off in order to understand what was being said.About the cord: It comes either coiled or straight. I chose coiled because, well, it just looks gangster, like you know what you're doing (which I barely do, but anyway). It's also 10 feet long, which negatively rubs individuals' respective rhubarb. Honestly, I'm a tall guy at 6'3", and I've had my fill of tiny cords that yank my head down even though I've just got my music player tucked into my pants pocket. I appreciate the extra cord and the added ability to move around even if I'm plugged into my computer.Everything considered, I'm very, very happy with the Sony MDR-V6. Maybe one day I'll spring for the Audio Technica ATH-M50s to see if they're that much better, but for right now, I'm pretty well set.
summary: Like listening to music for the first time

reviewText: Best headphones in the world. Save your money, don't by the Dr. Dre headphones. They are only of minimal quality above these ones. I listen mostly to jazz on my walking commutes and on loud bus rides and for practicing music with. I've had mine almost 6 years, only needing to replace the ear covers as they wore down.

Listening to my old music with these headphones sounds like listening to new songs. I finally hear the small variations and imperfections in vocals and instruments that makes the music come alive. I don't give them five stars because at "loud" volume, the bass sometimes doesn't quite hit as hard as I'd like. They feel great, often times I forget they are on my head at all. These are the first "nice" pair of headphones I have owned. I am a mechanical engineer, and I chose these over others for their good reviews, price, and looks.

I spent a lot of time researching and reading product reviews before settling on this headphone. I was not disappointed. It has better than average quality and it sounds great. My only complaint are the ear pads. My first look at them made me feel that they will not last long. They are not deep enough to prevent earphone from sitting on my ears. I don't wear them for extended periods so no problem for me.

Just like the title of my review says, I've had these since 2009 and haven't had a single issue with them. Sony knew they hit the ball out the park with this model and have kept them in stock. What you get is a high quality set of head phones with a very durable coiled cord and a very convenient bag that has come with me to trips around Europe and back. While they're not the best for noise canceling for when flying (not really intended to) they do make up with great sound, a punchy bass, balanced mids and highs and all without the need for an amp, but don't get me wrong, using an amp is also a great option. The specs are:Impedance : 63 ohmsDriver Unit : 40mmSensitivity (db) : 106dB/mWFrequency Response : 5Hz - 30,000HzHope this helps.
summary: I've Had These Since 2009. Still Going. Specs Below.

reviewText: I love these headphones. The sound is superb. Bass, Treble, etc... It's all super good. In the airplane they are just about noise canceling. The only beef I have with these is they are a little loose on the head. I'll take it though. I have used them with a Droid Phone, and I don't think they are quite loud enough sometimes. However, that is just the phones issue I bet.
summary: Great Headphones. Fit is a little big.

reviewText: So happy with these headphones.  Definitely very good quality for the price.  Love the long cable, sound quality, and comfort.  Much more reasonable in cost than higher priced brands.
Every recording studio in the world can't be wrong.  Well spec'd, extremely durable, and relatively inexpensive.  What more could you want in a pair of headphones?
summary: There's a reason it's the industry standard.

reviewText: The PurchaseI did a lot of research before selecting these headphones back in October. I read dozens of reviews on several websites regarding high end Headphones. When I narrowed it down to two models I decided to let the Amazon reviews decide which I should trust. After reading Amazons reviews & seeing there was a 1 year warranty I selected the Sony MDR-V6.The GoodFrom the moment I opened the box I was impressed. All the trimmings that came with these headphones were top notch. The second I put these on I was in love, They felt amazingly comfortable and sounded perfect. From the headband to the ear cups they are very sturdy & feel pleasant. I have never owned high end headphones before & these seemed to be worth there weight in gold. I have heard reviews knocking the base & other aspects of the sound & I totally disagree with them.The BadLike I implied earlier it was love from first sight, But like all young lovers I thought it would last forever. It did not... It lasted all of five months. It was not a slow decline, There were no warning signs. One day my partner in crime was delivering the sweet sounds of Tobias Sammet & the next a single earcup was delivering the sound. I was distressed assuming somehow I had damaged my headphones and I reached to take them off my head & as I did they were playing perfectly. So I un-stretched the top potion of the wire and half of my sound dissapeard. The wiring had some how failed. Over the next day I without stretching them I lost sound in both ear cups & then regained a distorted whisper from both cups.The UglyWhen I attempted to begin the process of redeeming my warranty I was shocked to find out that It only had a limited "Parts only" Warranty & I will be required to pay 39.99 to potentially get a "Similar" model or a  "Refurbished" replacement. I was planing on giving them a five star review 6 months from purchase date, Instead they get a one star review. A faulty product is not worth its weight in complimentary mints. I have not finished the return, Once I do I will update this review.UpdateI called Sony & even though it took about an hour of talking/waiting the people working at customer service were top notch. The three people I talked with were very nice and helpful. They helped walk me through the return process and waived the 40 dollar fee. I'm not sure If it was my particular circumstances or if its always their policy to waive a fee if someone complains. I sent in my headphones in and in less then a week I received a refurbished replacement for them. The replacements have worked great since I got them. So I'm changing my rating to four stars.

Original review: Don't get me wrong. I love the sound of these headphones. However, the earpads are cheap. They fall off a lot. It is hard to get them back on because they slip. Sony ruined a great product with cheap details.Update 5/25/2013: Two people commented with information about replacement earpads, and I plan to get a pair of those. I'm impressed by the number of people who love these earphones. Thanks for sharing information on Amazon to help others make purchase decisions.
summary: Earphone pads fall off frequently, but that can be fixed

reviewText: Sony mdr-v6 headphones are just what I expected from a company like Sony, they fit well and sound excellent. The cable stretches over six feet so don't even need extender cable. I highly recommend if you want headphones like we used years ago. By that I mean over the ear style and good craftsmanship.

I've been using my pair since 1987...only needed to replace the original pleather covering for $20.  But otherwise, they've provided outstanding sound and comfort over the years.  Do yourself a favor and remove the iPod headphones once in a while and plug these in...it's nice to welcome back bass into headphones--something those little white earbuds tried to make us forget.  I know there are plenty of other headphones out there, but you won't go wrong with this set.

There has been a degeneration of Sony products.  These headphones are cheaply made (wiring is not concealed) and are not as comfortable and well made as my Sony MDR-V600 headphones that are more than 12 years old. Fortunately Sony still sells replacement earphone covers for the good headphones that it formerly made.
summary: Not as comfortable as as the headphones that Sony formerly made

reviewText: I bought these to replace my aging Bose TP-1 headset with dry rotting earcups, and boy I am glad I did.  I use these primarily for studio work, so I was very caerful in making my selection.  The Sony MDR-V6s sound phenomenal, offer a great balance between mid and high frequencies, they are built solid, and fold easily.  The earcups took a little getting used to, but once I got them situated comfortably on my ears, they feel great.  After careful consideration and much research, I am hands-down pleased with the Sony MDR-V6 headphones and would buy them again.

The price was excellent for the most comfortable studio headphones on the market. The sound quality is superb, though the problems are usually in the ear covers and where the wires connect with the headphone.

I can not say enough about these headphones. you will hear things in your music that you never knew were there. I had set of massive Cerwin Vega speakers that did the same thing and I would say that these headphones put out the same quality as the 500.00 dollar speakers did. The best part is the fact that you can listen to music at any volume level and the bass sounds good. I have a pair of the cheap 20 dollar sonys and they sound ok but if you want to hear the bass you have to rock out to the max. The base on these headphones sounds good at any level. Also unlike the Beats iv listen too these phones sound great with Heavy Rock music as well as with Rap. If you would like to listen to your albums the way the artist produced them these are the best phones you could hope to find in this price range. They even manage to surpass some of the more expensive brands.

GOT THESE EARPHONE TODAY AND WAS IMPRESSED BY THE QUALITY OF THE MATERIALS. I WAS A LITTLE WORRIED, HOWEVER, BY THE EXPOSED WIRES CONNECTING EACH SIDE OF THE EARPHONES.  THESE EARPHONES SOUND VERY GOOD WITH SOLID BASS AND OVERALL CLARITY. THEY DID SEEM A LITTLE HARSH ON THE HIGH SIDE, BUT WERE VERY COMFORTABLE TO WEAR.  WHILE I LIKE THE OVERALL SOUND OF THESE EARPHONES, THEY ARE NOT QUITE AS SMOOTH AS MY JVC HA-DX3 EARPHONES, WHICH I CONSIDER THE VERY BEST I HAVE EVER HEARD.

Sure, there are better and worse headphones out there, but, for the price, these are tough to beat imo. My son is a computer game fanatic, and I thought that he'd eventually want to upgrade from these. However, after two years of use, and replacing the worn out ear pads, he's still happy with their performance, to my surprise, as he often wants the latest, and greatest, but is still very satisfied with these. Hmmm, no wonder many radio stations around the country, use these as well, imo, they are a proven performer.

Bought for my Nephew as I have a pair that was purchased in 1989 and after replacing the pads are still wonderful.He really likes them and I rarely see him without them now! (He's 15)He's using them with his iPhone, iPad, and notebook.Hopefully he'll get 35+ years out of them.

The MDR V6 headphones are the best. Do not confuse these with the V600.  I have had mine for 25 years! Its amazing that these still exist unchanged over all this time. The sound is crisp and clean. When you wear these, it seems that the sound is originating from the center of your head and radiating outward to your ears. I just bought a second pair with two sets of replacement ear pads in case Sony stops making them. All good things come to and end, so Sony will eventually stop making them for reasons that will be unexplainable. When I picked these out at the store originally, I listened to about 25 sets of headphones on the rack and then picked the best sounding one. I have yet to hear anything better. My studio monitor speakers and my $1500/pair floor speakers can't beat the sound experience. They are very light and comfortable. I wear them in bed.They are not good as studio monitor tools if you are mixing music, however. The sound is too pure. The sound you get on these will always be better than what you get on anything else, and so your mixes will be dissapointing on real speakers. For mixing and music creation work, get something imperfect.My recommendation: get these while there still available, don't look any further

I have had many headphones over the years with some costing $100's and others being cheap. This is the first set of over-the-ear headphones I have had that are both very good and not very expensive. These Sony's have solid bass without being muddy and well balanced highs without being too bright. I like them and highly recommend them. If you have SRS audio lab on your computer, you can watch movies while listening to these headphones in simulated surround sound and disturb no one. Try watching The Matrix with these on.
summary: A good set of headphones for not a lot of moolah is hard to find

reviewText: I purchased these after looking into the difference between these and the Sony mdr7506,  There is none except these do not have the gold plated jacks.  They sound great! I have many other sets of headphones and these are by far the best.  I thought the others where great until I heard stuff through the v6s. You will hear things in your music you never heard before.  They block out noise and are very comfortable on my big head, yet they fold down for easy travel.

I have owned these headphones for somewhere between 10 and 15 years and they sound as good today as the day I bought them.  I have not treated them the best.  I toss them in the drawer, I toss them in a basket.  Sometimes I fold them up and sometimes I don't.  I don't know what some other reviewers have done to their headphones but mine have been rode hard and put away wet, and still look and sound terrific.  They sound great cranked way up or very soft.  I use them for my ipod, my stereo, my computer and my TV.  The only thing that has gone wrong is the coiled cord has stretched over time and is a bit awkward to deal with. I can live with it.  I have owned some Bose triports and have listened to many others while browsing around audio stores and these MDR v6's sound as good or better than anything else I have tried.  I recently gave my son the Boses' and I kept the Sony MDR V6s'.  They are made with quality materials, fit well, don't get hot or heavy and sound excellent. The bass is accurate, full but not overdone. The mids and highs are crisp and balanced.  By the way, in comparison to others in the market today they are cheap.  I'm guessing mine will last several more years but just in case I'm going to snatch up another bargain set and stash them away for the day the music dies.  I have enjoyed these headphones every time I put them on and in my opinion you can't go wrong with the Sony MDR V6!
summary: 10 Years Use and they're still the ones I Prefer

reviewText: These are some of the flattest, clearest headphones i have used.  For me, that is a good thing.  I don't like the bass heavy headphones(beats by dre type), when I am listening for clarity in a song. The only fault i can find is that they don't feel very comfortable after wearing them for about an hour....but that might just be my big pointy ears!!!!  I think you can't go wrong with these if you want a good listening experience that isn't low frequency heavy!!!

PROS:1.) good price at 70-80 bucks!2.) very comfortable to wear3.) fold up for easier storage4.) single coiled cord on left side5.) coiled cord can stay short or stretch easily to 8-10 feet6.) replaceable ear pads7.) oh yeah, they sound GREAT (as good as the senheiser hd 555's that i returned and got these)CONS:1.) Nothing really2.) maybe the pink/red sticker on the ear cups that i removed :)3.) ear pad fell off soon after i got them, but i stuck it back on4.) umm.....i don't know if this is me or not, but i seem to have to crank the volume up pretty high (75%-100%) on my devices to get the optimal sound.

I have owned these headphones for 14 years and have used them almost daily. They are quite simply the highest quality product I have ever owned (actually, to be totally honest, they are tied for 1st with my Makita chop saw, my Milwaukee Super Sawzall, and my Mag-44 Skilsaw). They could even be said to be too good - they will clearly portray every detail in the sound, meaning that you will hear the weaknesses & background noise present in your sound card, media player, etc. I have replaced the ear covers twice and the inner lining of the head rest peeled years ago, but I am still very pleased. Don't even look at any other headphones in this price range unless you need skull-pounding bass, in which case you would do well with either the Sony DJ headphones with swiveling cups (don't know the model number off the top of my head) or Skullcandy products.

I use these headphones for all my PS3 gaming and movie watching (output to Sony stereo), my Nintendo DS, listening to music CDs and varying quality files on my netbook, and practicing bass and guitar (the 1/4" adaptor comes in handy!). Sound is always solid, not perfect for everything but really good for anything; as many have said before, you get out of these 'phones what you put in. I like that I can plug straight into basically any headphone output and rock (or soft-rock if necessary); the uncolored response gives the V6s good versatility in my opinion; i'm not interested in artificially-enhanced bass or anything, just accurate sound.In my research I've found that a lot of these headphones from the early 90s are still kicking around with just an earpad replacement. The cord and plug are sturdy, which is important to me because I have been burned (not literally) by cheap cords in the past. I wish the earpieces could be locked into place instead of flopping around... wouldn't be hard to twist them laterally, so fold them up when not in use. The loops of cord above the earpieces might get taped/glued down or ziptied, because if they get snagged (could happen on a guitar tuning peg or something. I have this kind of luck) it would be ugly. I have no problem wearing em for 4+ hours at a time, but eventually my ears and temples start getting sore. By then it's time for a break from vegging around anyway. I will be putting the velour replacement pads on to see what happens.Headphones are a pretty subjective subject, so your mileage may vary. Try some out at a store if you can. I bought these because I found myself living in headphones a lot and wanted to ditch my cheap buds and clippies for an affordable, versatile, comfortable, workhorse set. If you're an audiophile you probably want different sets of cans and amps for everything, but if you're a no nonsense dude like me you want something like this. I give them 4.5 stars.

Purchased this set for my father who has difficulty hearing.  He likes to listen to music on an MP3 player while mowing the lawn.  These work well, he says that they sound great and block out a lot of background noise.  He is very please with them.
Love the fit, the sound quality, and the old school style.
Definitely a great pair of headphones. The cord is a little bit longer than most headphones on the market today that are designed for walking around town, but they are definitely enjoyable.
summary: Not super expensive, definitely worth the quality and the sound.

reviewText: I used to make music at home and have used various models of headphones at night for quiet mixing. I've also used some for gaming and movie watching.The MDR-V6 are the best I've used so far. I'm not claiming to be a pro. These might be mediocre overall if I were able to compare them other 'cans' in the headphone world.All I know is that these sound healthy. I can hear a deep level of bass. It doesn't rumble your ears but you can hear very low frequencies. For example, if I pop on some DJ Magic Mike (that Miami bass music crud), I can hear all the low end sounds for the most part. Deep rich sound overall.These days I mostly use these for late night movie watching while my son is asleep. They do the job very well for me.My only miniscule complaint is the fatigue on my outer ear from the cans pushing in against them. I can get a couple hours in before it becomes irritating, sometimes 4 hours or more if I have them placed perfectly over my ears. This is normal though and all headphones do this.
summary: best headphones I've personally ever used

reviewText: Nothing really beats these for the price. They are better than any other sub-100 dollar headphones I've ever used. In my opinion, they're better than the overpriced, overbassed beats, but of course that's not saying much. Even with my broad range of music (Jazz to hip-hop to rock), I haven't had a moment when I've been disappointed. Their bass is clear, but not overdone, and the treble and mids are equally clear. Good job sony!

These are some of the best headphones you could ever buy. Don't buy into the hype and get those rapper headphones, these are the ones even the pros use. All levels are crisp and clear, while there is a good amount of bass it does not drown out the mids or highs at all. If you care about music or hearing exactly what you are listening to then these are the headphones for you.
Audio is crisp and clear and design is very comfortable. Even more comfortable when paired with the Beyerdynamic EDT 250 Velour Padded Earcushions.

I have a hard time finding headphones that fit nicely and feel comfortable for long periods of time - due to my large head size.  These headphones not only sound terriffic but they are also very comfortable.  Super soft covers on each ear piece and the stretchy cord is a nice touch too.  This set feels good in your hands, and on your head, the quality is obvious and its a well made product.  I used these on a long set of flights recently and was able to watch many hours of movies and TV shows before I started to feel any discomfort while wearing them.  And that is really saying something!  I highly recommend these for general use, even if you have a large head.

For the price, you can't beat these. I'm an audio nut. These headphones are balanced. Very versatile. Great quality and comfortable fit. Can't see a headphone beating these out (for the price). They sound like $300+ headphones.
summary: Excellent. For the price, these can't be beat.

reviewText: Sparkingly true sound reproduction. No thump, bump, warm, cool, sounds added by others. Just the straight sounds to modify to your own personal taste. Studio monitors. OUTSTANDING!!

I've owned two pair of these headphones over the years.  This pair was a gift for my grandson.  There was a problem with them when I received them.  The insulation on the cable was pulling away at the earphones.  I returned them and Amazon immediately replaced them.  If I ever need another pair this is what I'll buy again.

These are excellent, and well worth the purchase price.  The construction is well done and will last much longer than other versions Sony has done with flimsy plastic located just above the hinge.  Far sturdier and well-made.  Sound is excellent for $50, cord is long and the whole assembly is not overly heavy.  Just wearing the headphones even without sound does a fine job of blocking ambient noise.  I far prefer these to earbuds and I also prefer this over the top style versus some lighter versions that rely too much on ear shape or the like.  I can lay my head back on a cushion with these and relax.  I also use them in the office and the cord is long enough to reach everywhere in the office without strain on the neck or the cord.  Buying another for home soon enough.
summary: Much better than their other versions

reviewText: Most comfortable headphones I've worn in a long time..  Night and day from my previous set.Sure, the sound quality is awesome, that much I expected....... but the comfort... amazing.  I can see myself wearing these for hours without a thought.Anyone else who says these are uncomfortable either has a really large head and doesn't know it, or simply isn't telling us.  These have room to spare on my head and my head isn't small... I"m 6' 220lbs...Either way, these are awesome.  Definitely would recommend these to anyone.

I first got a hold of my first pair of Sony MDR V6 Monitor Series Headphones in the late 90's.  Oddly enough, it cost about the same back then as it does today. The sound was phenomenal.  You actually had to lift the headphone to make sure the bass was not coming from the room.  Not that the base was unusually loud, it was just that is sounded so real.  These were studio quality headphones that were actually used in studios.  You would see these Sony headphones in practically every music video that was shot in a studio.Fast forward about 10 years, the headphone craze starts up. Every audio company want to break into the headphone market.  Sony adds newer models of headphone that still can't live up to the MDR V6's,  I decided that I wanted to replace the Sony MDR V6 headphones that had gotten lost long ago.  Used MDR V6 headphones were selling for over $150 if you could find them at all.  So I did a little research and found out that although there was a demand for these headsets, Sony had discontinued the MDR V6 line anyway. Luckily, the reason that I could not find the V6's was the when the headphones were first re-issued, they sold out immediately. Although I had to wait months, I finally got my replacement Sony MDR V6's.So what did I get for all this waiting?  I received a true studio tested headset that has a sound so clear that you wonder whether its actually coming from your headset.  Unlike some other headphones, the V6's did not artificially increase the treble or base.  These Sony's were designed to be studio reference headphones which required them to have a flat, unmodified sound.  In my opinion, these headphones are classics that arguably outperform newer and more expensive headphones.
summary: So good that they brought back the Sony MDR V6 headphones after discontinuing  them.

reviewText: Base is clear, They are comfortable and the package even gives you a bag for storage and portability. Worth the $50 bucks

Pros: Solid punchy bass, nuetral mids, clear highs. Got these for $19 ($49 minus $30 Amazon credit).  Great bass without having to push in-ear buds into your canals deep enough to make a tight seal.  Sound just as good as my $350 Shure ear buds.  Well recorded and mixed music really does shine on these.Cons: The coiled chord is a little heavy - wish it was detachable with a shorter straight chord for use with iPod. They make me want to listen to all of my music over again.  That I didn't get a second set while they were on sale for 49 dollars.
I bought these as a gift because I had bought these very same headphones for myself years ago.  I love them.

I just got these yesterday, had them on for almost 8 hours. That's how long it took to get the least bit of soreness for me, and I wear glasses as well. I don't have a small head either, average to large I'd say as I'm 6'2". The sound is amazing and getting better, very clear, uncolored, excellent performance. After reading some of the reviews here - re: bass: it gets better as they burn in. It is there, but soft relative to the rest of the range as many have said - however it's getting louder and clearer as time goes on. Re: noise intrusion: Very little outside noise gets in especially turned up slightly. Given the burn-in period - slamming the volume knob immediately upon opening the box would be a bad idea, in case anyone is contemplating that. Don't be stupid and ruin a perfectly good set of headphones, as well as your hearing. I would definitely purchase these again if I needed to, they are excellent and especially so at the price. Easily the best bang for your listening buck. Buy these and you won't regret it.
summary: Easily the best headphones I've used. Ever.

reviewText: I saw these on head-fi.org in a head phone shootout at different price points.  I now have these and the Sennheiser PX100.  They are both very close in sound but since the PX100's are so much smaller and lighter I would pick them over the Sony's.  I would buy these again as well as the PX100's.  The PX100's where my first foray into quality headphone sound.  Next on my list is the Audio-Technica ATH-M50's at the $100 price point.
Maybe nit Senhiesers but they are very good phone for the $.  This is the second pair I have owned in 25 years.  The first were destroyed by a new puppy in the house.  NOT DOG PROOF!

I bought these because I wanted a quality pair of headphones for travel and commuting, but didn't want to shell out a lot of cash. I returned them after two days of testing them out. Here's why:Pros1. Very comfortable.2. They fold up nicely. It comes with a convenient carry pouch.3. Under $100Cons1. I did not hear the "punchy bass" people were talking about in the reviews. I like to be immersed in my music. I want to feel like I'm inside the song. But the bass in these phones couldn't deliver that feeling, as hard as I tried to like them.2. The highs are too high for me. It hurt my ears.3. The cord is way too long for commuting. There's no way to coil it up and have it stay coiled. This makes traveling on the subway with them very awkward.Some music I typically listen to (so you get an idea of the sound I was looking for):- Radiohead- Grizzly Bear- Wilco- Fleet Foxes- My Morning JacketIn summary, I think these are great for sound technicians who need to hear every click and scratch and need the extra long cord so they can move around the studio. They're sturdy and extremely comfortable. But if you're looking for a pair of commuter-friendly headphones with deep sonic immersion, I don't think these are for you.EDIT: I respect these headphones for their longevity and their devout following. They just didn't fit my lifestyle of commuting daily and listening to the kind of music I listen to.
summary: Very comfortable; Treble is grating, Lacks bass immersion

reviewText: It was exactly what I was looking for! Quality and performance was excellent. Am using to practice my guitar quietly.
summary: Great headphones for monitoring my music

reviewText: I can't say enough how much I love these!Just W-o-W!This specific pair of cans are exceptionally great for its price...!They are not at all uncomfortable with my big ears.. haha. They do get quite warm after 2-3 hours of usage, but for its sound, I can bear with that!Great pair of cans :))
sounds good. kinda makes my ear ache if i put it in wrong cuz i got big earsother than that its perfectarrived on time and all

These Sony headphones are a good set of headphones and were steal!The one thing I liked is that the cord was half straight, half coiled. Whenever I use these for DJ'ing, I can move around pretty freely without worrying that the headphone jack will pop out.One thing that I read about and that happened to me is that when I kept the headphones on for about 10 minutes, my ears would get hot and feel a bit sweaty.The padding for the headband doesnt feel that padded when you touch it, but when you put on the headphones, it would feel somewhat comfortable.The one conveniet thing is that the headphones flip upside down, but I usually don't use that feature. Also, the extendor of the headphones is metal, so you don't have to worry about the extendor breaking, unless you abuse the hell out of it.A second thing that I worry about is the exposed wire. Between the headband and the earphone, there is a wire that is exposed and out there. It looks pretty frail to me, and if it ever gets damaged, you have to get another pair of headphones, unless you bought a warranty.Onto to Sound!Overall, the sound quality is pretty good. I usually listen to hip hop, dubstep, R&B;, and house music, and the sound quality is pretty good. The mids are clear, the highs are good, and the lows are full. The one thing I hoped forFinally, one thing that I hope Sony will adapt to is the concept of a detachable cord.Overall, these pair of headphones are very good
summary: Sony MDR-V6 Monitor Series Heaphones with CCAW Voice Coil

reviewText: I was looking for a good set of headphones. While researching online, I noticed that the MDR-V6 kept showing up as a recommended product on several consumer review websites. The price was lower than most recent headphones offered by Sony and other brands.So I took a chance and ordered a pair. I am not an expert on headphones, but the MDR-V6 sound great to me. They deliver a sound that is balanced. The bass is not overwhelming like a lot of headphones that I have sampled. I listen to a variety of music....country, rock, bluegrass, blues and some gospel. I also use them to watch DVD's.The MDR-V6 are more than adequate to satisfy my needs. They have been around for a long time and are still recommended. That fact alone prompted me to purchase a pair. I'm very glad that I did.John Brooks
summary: Very good performance at a reasonable price

reviewText: I have a set for work and one for home.It does not totally cancel out noise, but still pretty good.For office privacy, consider installing a Welcome mat at your door. It does wonders.
Great sounding headphones that have a stylish, classic, no frills look. I recommend them to anyone who does not mind having a pretty long cord.
Beautiful sound.  Very clear highs and solid bass.  I also have Sony noise-cancelling phones.  I love Sony products.  Very dependable quality.

I produce digitally composed music. These are an absolute for anyone that makes computer music, just go ahead and add these quality, comfortable, crisp sounding headphones to your studio.No need to look around at other brands or cheaper/more expensive ones, these are the headphones you are looking for. Trust me.Check out my old tunes at  . Bunch of new songs droppin' in January. My soundcloud will improve now that I have these headphones.
summary: Was gunna be 4 star... but then I couldn't find anything wrong with them.

reviewText: These have good sound, but more importantly, they are durable.  I have now had these at my desk for nearly two years, none of the 3 other sets I've owned have lasted as long.  My chair has arms and they catch the cable and pull these onto the floor at least once a week.  They have held up, and look like they did fresh out of the box.  The pivot points are all metal hinges/pins and that helps the durability.  I'm not an audiophile, but I'm not a chump either and they sound great to me.

Of course, any audio situation is a matter of personal taste--but--I suggest anyone try these who wants to hear what headphones can be.They have the best bass--the purest highs and they are comfortable for listening over a long period. Be aware that these will go very loud--far more than most--so be wary when you listen a lot.I have had a pair for around 25 years--and I have replaced the ear pads--and they have worked fine always. I paid $100 when I bought them--around $210 in today's dollars. This price is exceptional. I was going to buy another pair--but saw no need. Professionals use them. I have had many other good ones--but--these are in a class by themselves. You will not be disappointed.Another good choice is the Sennheiser HD202--my second favorite pair and a bargain.And I hope all of you realize that "ear buds"--are just wrong--useful only in unusual circumstances.

My dad owns a pair of these exact headphones, and has owned them for as long as I can remember. They still work great, and this new set that I just received sounds nice as well. The sound is tight, with good separation and the bass is pretty punchy. The sound isolation is pretty decent. These are a nice all around pair of headphones that will not disappoint someone who is looking for a versatile pair.
summary: Great value for a quality pair of headphones

reviewText: Happy with Sony MDRV6 headphones, use them with my keyboard. No problems with hearing the sounds of music. Light weight, and easily fits over the ears.

I'm not quite an audiophile or expert to say I can accurately give a statistic that proves these are the best, but I'll share my personal experience. I absolutely love these cans. I didn't want to review the day after I received until I used them on stage, in the studio, etc. I now can say these are one of the best cans you can get for your money for a clear signal with realistic sound.They are very sturdy feeling and can compact nicely to stow and go in their included travel bag. The ear muffs (if that's what their called) won't last forever, but that is the reality to face with any padded phones. It happens. Sony sells replacements to solve that problem, guaranteeing you can keep these phones for a long, long, long time. Additionally, the coiled cord is a HUGE plus in my opinion. The cord can extend a good 10+ feet fully extended. There isn't much pull either so the cord can easily be extended without needing to "break it in". I can easily walk around and not feel the pull on the phones, which to me is huge when walking around adjusting gear when playing live or practicing. Also as a standard professional set of phones would, it includes a screw-on 1/4" adapter which is also a huge plus to me. This ensures I can know when I roam about that the phones stay plugged in and I can focus on performing.The phones are surprisingly excellent at blocking out sound when over your ears. I actually have to take one off my ear when playing live to hear across stage because it silences other sound out so well. But for everyone looking to be immersed into the sound at the moment - be it a film, music, video game, radio, video monitor, etc, these literally place you in the studio or right where the microphone was placed in the musical recording. They have a great range of sound so when I use them to take apart keys or strings, I can hear the bassy lows and shrilly highs. On a guitar it has the same effect. Greatest sound reproduction I've come across... And have no reason to look for anything else.Be warned, these are not bass boosting (over emphasizing, in my opinion) Beats audio headphones. So if you're looking to shake the dust and wax out of your ears, don't get these. These produce sound the way it is, no extra enhancements. But for the rest that want a clear signal for monitoring, performing, tv, etc - these are the cans for you.

I tried 3 different sets of professional headphones before settling on these --- I really really like the Bose Triports, and they're probably the most comfortable headphones I've ever worn --- but they're ridiculously flimsy and I read many reports of them breaking.  These Sony MDR-V6s are old workhorses, durable, amazing sound quality, and nearly every bit as comfortable as the Bose Triports.  They have a good deal of bass without being bass heavy.  Very realistic sound.They fully fit over the ear and block out a good deal of outside sound, and they fold for easy travel and storage.  The coiled cord is a great touch.  You don't need a headphone amp with the MDR-V6s so it's easy to listen to your iPod, etc.  You don't get a gold connector (not really an issue), but you do get a 1/4" adaptor.  I picked these up for $75 here on Amazon and they're every bit as good as headphones twice that price.  Very highly recommended.

Moving from basic ear plugs to these, what a world of difference. Especially considering that my earphones pretty much cost the same! I could see some of the comments that with lots of listening, your ears good get a bit sweaty, but the BT earpads for a few more dollars should fix that.

In an ideal world i would give these headphones 4.5/5 stars and subtract a half of a point for the comfort issue, but because i am still able to enjoy these for about 2 hours before i feel like my ears need a break whilst studying, they will get my 5 stars. i have had them for over a year now and the cushion on one of the ears has finally started to break down a little bit, however note that these have been used for >500 hours.
Didn't buy these on amazon, but had to come and pay my respects. I noticed after buying these that a lot of radio programs would use these headphones.
Excellent headphones. I use them at my home recording studio and they are great at keeping the dynamic sound when you are listening. They are also durable.

These are really fantastic and are probably the best value of any headphone.  They're not just a value, they hold their own against 'phones in the $150 range.  They are super comfortable, constructed well (the cord seems like it could be a little sturdier, though), and give a pretty true-to-life sound experience.  While they don't sound exactly like you're sitting in a concert hall, it's not far off.  Instruments are accurate with clean high notes (Cymbals, sopranos, harp) and nice bass that avoids muddiness both in electronic music and in classical (bass drums, bass singers, piano).  The clarity of voices when listening with these headphones is greatly improved--as a singer this is tremendously important.  The music I'm hearing sounds like live music.It's crazy how much of a piece you miss when you're listening on cheap headphones/equipment!  So many cools sounds that you hear live, but never when you're listening in the car or at home or on the bus.  Not anymore!I bought these as a gift for someone else, but I think I'm keeping the first pair and ordering another.

In short, these are incredible. If you are looking for great sounding headphones then you have very few reasons for these not to be them.I was a little bit skeptical about these since they are so affordable compared to so many other high end headphones. The good news is that they produce extremely clear, rich, full, and balanced sound while being very comfortable over long periods. The build quality is great and includes a coiled cord that doesn't weigh down.At the same time that I got these I also purchased a set of Philips Citiscape for $115. Not only do these sound better but they are more comfortable and more affordable (the only thing I like more about the Philips is that it has an inline mic for taking calls - which is really not the focus here but could be for some). Also much better sounding than Beats headphones and at less than a third of the price for a comparable pair!I do hear though that the ear pads will eventually start to flake off. I can neither confirm nor deny that at present but I will be sure to update this should it occur.

I wear headphones a lot. As a student I spend a lot of time listening to music, playing video games, or mixing stuff I've made. Essentially between the hours of 3pm and 12pm I am wearing headphones. So I take a lot of stuff into mind.Pros:Really comfortable, they can sometimes leave your ears a little sore afterwards, but while wearing them I can wear them for ages.Good Sound: For the price the sound is fantastic and I'd recommend it highly.Foldable design is pretty coollong cable.Cons:No Bass: My big complaint for these headphones in general. I just don't feel the pounding of the bass on these. Now that might be my problem because I really like loud music, but that's why it lost one star.

Nothing anywhere can beat this headphones for this price. The sound quality along with the long but coiled cable make this perfect for whatever you need. They can also take quite the beating and work just fine.

This first night I got these, I just went through my music collection, listening to my favorite songs and thinking "Holy s***, I didn't realize that that instrument was even in this song" and "listen to the rasp in his breath, it changes the whole feel of the piece".Seriously, I think I had forgotten how amazing music is. Every time I listen through these, I remember.
summary: Reminded me why I love music

reviewText: These really can't be beat by anything else in this price range. They're quite comfortable (thinking about replacing the vinyl ear cushions with velour ones as the vinyl ones make my ears a bit sweaty after extended use..). I won't go into audio quality as there are plenty of reviews that do that. The build quality is superb. The coiled cable is sturdy, and the plug weighs almost as much as my cell phone! The included adapter screws on very securely. I ordered a few headphones when I was deciding on a pair and these beat out the XB500 as well as comparable Sennheiser and Sure headphones.

I have a collection of headphones, but now by far this is my favorite, very comfortable in long use. Highly recommended. On the go they are lightly and when not in use, they fit in the pocket of my regular jacket. I love them, the sound is crystal clear. And for that price nobody can beat them.

I've had these for over 2 years and they're still top quality! I would recommend to anyone. I use them for listening to music and for amateur music production in FL Studio. Many times my ears are ringing they get so loud, but over the years the quality has not diminished, they are comfortable, and durable.Would recommend to everyone.
summary: Great quality over 2 1/2 years still powerful!

reviewText: Deep, powerful,  realistic, extremely impressive, clean and clear bass ... free of any thumping, booming or unnatural boosting of the lower frequency octaves. Does not artificially enhance the bass information in the source material... but knocks your socks off when the music contains powerful and stirring low end bass notes. The "mids" and "highs" are crystal clear, smooth, and perfectly reproduced. Overall the "sound" of the MDRV6 is very rich, natural, well balanced, and free of any audible artifacts. These headphones do everything very very well, and as far as I am able to perceive, do absolutely nothing false or wrong. They can faithfully reproduce any genre of music and never "strain" or exhibit any sign of unwanted compression, or distortion, even at ear bleeding sound levels! The "mids" have beautiful "presence" and clarity... the "highs" are a joy to hear and never strident. Very comfortable to wear. I have owned my Koss 4AA's for decades and the Sennheiser HD280 pro monitor "phones" since they were first released, in all, I own about 8 different models of headphones and the MDRV6  is now my preferred and absolute "go-to" headphone of choice by a mile.
Comfortable to wear and great sound. I have no complaints but I would love a noise canceling option but I'm sure that would have increased the price significantly.

I have done a lot of research on headphones and wanted something practical. I even went store to store testing out headphones from bose (great performance but very pricey), beats by dre (these are a joke), sol (very uncomfortable), and found out that the sonys performed a lot better. When I found out that these headphones where on sale on amazon I just knew I couldn't pass on these. Haven't regretted my decision since.

I purchased this product because my brother had a pair. We are both musicians, so we use his pair mainly for writing, recording, and mixing.But I needed something more comfortable and powerful than those terrible earphones that come with iPods for my leisurely listening. These are comfortable, with the around-the-ear design clamping down on the head and actually isolating a good portion of the sound (and I ride the bus for 2.5hrs a day so I can tell you how nice it is to block out the noise). I also use them at home to watch movies, and the sound is crisp, clear, and well-rounded. I listen to blues, hip-hop, funk, pop, and electronic music. They do the lower ends justice, and the mid-range POPS.I recommend these cans for any music aficionado, whether you play it, write it, or just love kicking it and listening to it.
I am really just comparing these to earbuds. Sound quality is great. They are pretty comfortable and have a long cord.

Hardly a step up from my $15 MDR-ZX100, which actually give a better sense of surround sound than these things despite the slightly better fidelity and clarity of the V6. I listen to music loudly and to get completely immersed in it and these don't do it for me at all, partly because they just sound too harsh and too mono. The comfort is excellent though. If these were half the price I bought them for I'd rate it 4 or 5 stars, but honestly compared to the cheap $15 pair I have this is a disappointment.
They sound great! Some people complained about them being too tight, but I thought they fit very nicely on my head.

i got these because i needed something for the audio of my PS3. also have a pair of Shure SRH440s, but those are too heavy for longer term use. i chose the V6s because they are the highest rated/most popular headphones on Amazon for under $100. plus, they have been around for over 20 years and earned high praise from pro and home use alike. in my opinion these are, hands down, the best set of full size headphones for under $100. you will not be disappointed, and if you are, there is probably something wrong with your ears. comfort is 9/10. headband is wide and distributes weight aptly. enough tension to stay on your head, even while bobbing around, but not too tight to smash your ears. ear-pads tend to heat up. this can be addressed by the velour pads from Beyerdynamic. sound gets a 10/10. with a freq. range from 5hz-30khz it's hard to throw something out these can't handle. great sound stage too. i have them paired with the FiiO E5 portable amp which, to me, gives plenty of power. iPod is sufficient as well. i want to get a Turtle Beach DSS as well for simulated surround. should be great. so, for everyday home use these are unmatched. i'm not a musician but music sounds fantastic and studio use would most likely be handled very well too. good stuff from Sony, as usual. will be listening with these for as long as possible, which should be about 20 years. sound investment for anyone.

As a graduate student in the sciences, I spend a substantial portion of my time listening to music while working and doing research.  I spent a great deal of time pouring through reviews on various headphone fanatic websites and many of the reviews on here.  My initial conclusion was that I should go ahead and purchase the Sennheiser HD 555s, which I did as part of an awesome deal during Black Friday.  Unfortunately, despite their amazing sound and great look, the Sennheiser HD 555s were open ear and actually quite uncomfortable.  Unlike most people, I have a slightly larger head, so I ALWAYS end up extending the headphones as far as they can come out of the headband.  The Sennheisers simply had too much pressure on my head, actually causing a small bit of pain after a wearing them for a while.There are essentially 4 factors I look for in a great pair of headphones:(1) Excellent sound reproduction in a wide range of frequencies (especially great bass)(2) Very comfortable for long periods of listening (while wearing glasses)(3) Closed-ear (so that I don't disturb people nearby)(3) Semi-PortabilityI ultimately returned them and replaced them with the Sony MDR-V6s.  I was definitely somewhat skeptical that these smaller, closed-ear Sony's were not going to live up to the Sennheisers.  Let me tell you, THEY DO.The sound quality of the MDR-V6s is amazing.  Granted they are only 76$ headphones, they make the music come alive and I'm honestly hearing new parts of songs that were lost to other inferior headphones.  Their bass reproduction is fantastic, with a claim that they can actually go down to 3 Hz, as opposed to the typical 20 Hz cut-off of most headphones.  I'm a definite bass-o-phile, so I know my bass.  You can crank it up and not even hear distortion at very low frequencies.  In addition, you cannot hear any sound outside of them when you are wearing them.  Much to my surprise, they are very comfortable (even with glasses on), much more so than the Sennheisers, and the pressure on my head is much less.  They are also built very study, more so than it appears the Sennheisers were.  Lastly, they fold up very compactly and even come with a nice leather carrying pouch.  (Funnily enough, they came resting on a bed of red silk in their original packaging; very ostentatious Sony).The only negative aspect that I can find at the moment is that your ears get a little warm after a while, but this is often the case with most over-the-ear headphones.  In addition, I prefer cables that aren't coiled, but it's not a big deal; it's actually often convenient.Bottom line: great value, great sound, comfortable, portable.  If you don't own a recording studio or DJ professionally (although I imagine some use these), you cannot go wrong with these.  I thoroughly believe based on the many reviews that they will bring many years of pleasure.

I listen to all kinds of rock from the 60's to today. I love these headphones they provide a very balanced sound and really represent the sound the way the bands had intended when they were mixing their stuff in studio. These have really breathed new life into a lot of my music collection. I would definitely have to recommend them to anyone trying to get great sound from their music.
summary: Wonderful Headphones for Rock and Roll

reviewText: First of all I'm not a musician,director or studio engineer( just a really big music and entertainment fan) and have tried several headphones and actually owned about 4 headphones in the same price range as the V6(and a lot of much cheaper ones) in the past  and while the ones I liked  were great in their own right, the Sony MDR V6s are the best sounding headphones I've ever listened to. The sound is very even and natural yet extremely detailed and not at all "lifeless" or "boring" to listen to. They have a really deep, smooth,rich yet accurate bass sound and have crystal clear treble and mid range.Overall, there may be other headphones that cost twice as much that sound better but for the price when it comes to sound, the Sony MDR V6s sound absolutely flawless for the money and they are a true bargain. These headphones are not only beautiful to listen to and come beautifully packaged they are also very comfortable and durable. I have had these headphones for 5 years and haven't even had to replace the ear pads yet and I can listen to these headphones for hours without taking a break. The V6s are very similar to the 7506s in sound and appearance but I think the V6s are actually clearer and even more detailed to my ears.It can debated by people that they sound the same but to my ears I can honestly say the V6s sound better to my ears and they have an even longer cord than the 7506s so buying a headphone extension cord is not necessary.Overall, I would definitely recommend the V6 to anyone looking for a great sounding,durable,accurate and affordable set of headphones.
summary: The MDR V6s are Sony's masterpiece and an industry standard.

reviewText: Excellent quality.  Great sound.  At the price, better than more expensive brands and models.  Wife says very comfortable and easy to wear.

I have had my MDR-V6 for probably 6 years.  They are truly an excellent value.  The price is just right, and the sound is superb.Don't mistakenly buy the MDR-600 or V600.  They are a different headphone, which I have used, and can confirm that they do not sound as nice as the V6.  Everything is muddy sounding on the 600's, whereas the V6 are among the most crisp sounding headphones I've used.Highly recommend.

I purchased my Sony MDR-V6 headphones in my very early teens (if not earlier) after reading a review in Stereo Review (I believe). Since then, they've gotten tons of use and I've seen them everywhere. I've gone through 3 or 4 cords over the years and they're finally falling apart. I wanted another pair but settled (ha!) on MDRV600's, which are very muddy - all mids. They're going back today to Best Buy and I'm getting a new set of V6's from here -- I can't believe Sony has kept this model alive so long. These are incredible 'phones. Trust me.For alternatives, get the following:http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000AJIF4E?ie=UTF8&camp;=213733&creative;=393177&creativeASIN;=B000AJIF4E&linkCode;=shr&tag;=swiclu-20&linkId;=IRBSUAR6ER2W4QD7Fairly comparable of its range....
enough said, this is purely amazing.  The spectrum of sound it gives, brings a new experience to your whole collection.
Love them, sound fantastic, easy to ware.  I'm a programmer and I ware them for about 6 hours a day every workday while listing to music.-James

I bought these headphones for my husband. I was looking for ones with good and detailed enough reviews but still affordable for my budget. Due to his business, he travels pretty frequent and the noise from the surroundings in a plane, especially in very long flights, sometimes can be very disturbing. These don't cancel noise 100% while no plaing (Zvideo or music) but they do pretty good while playing; he can listen pleasantly his music (very good base), concentrate better to read or work and even help him to rest some. They fold nice to carry 'em, they look nice. He finds them still comfortable after more than 6 months using them, they don't hurt or bother him when he falls asleep; we were surprised of how long the cable is, but that helps they don't pull when he moves. He always take 'em with him, he really likes 'em. The only reason i don't give the 5 stars is because not 100% noise-cancelling so they are not excellent, but they are very good.
summary: Very functional for travelers, good price, look good

reviewText: These are my all-time favorite headphones: they hit a perfect balance between price and sound.Their sound is great, reproducing it in a balance way.  Too many headphones try to boost the bass (often to unreasonable levels) in order to sell to home consumers.  These, however, have a nearly flat response, reproducing all kinds of recordings realistically.  (And if you do want extra bass--which is admittedly nice on some kinds of music--that is what the EQs are for!)As to comfort, I find them perfectly comfortable, and my head is even bigger around than most people's heads (as is evidenced by having to get x-large hats).  On many occasions I have had to wear them for long periods of time, usually through big deadline driven programming sessions, so that I could tune out all the distractions around me and just get stuff done.  At no time did I find them uncomfortable to wear.

I had these headphones for about 15 years and I have to say the sound quality is excellent. The fact that they are still looking good means they are well made.  If you have a chance to buy them then don't hesitate because you will not get a similar value for the price anywhere.  About two years ago I ordered the replacement pads from Sony and just installed them yesterday, and now the headphones look like new.  As for the fit, they are comfortable but tight and after a number of hours I can see why some people complain about sore ears.  There is a slight difference in the older headphones according to the specs because the older ones used a Samarian cobalt magnet and these don't so maybe the cobalt was not as easy to obtain any more.  Now they are almost the same as the MDR7506 but with a better audio range so why pay double the price?  Now my only decision is whether to buy another pair when I have a fine working one.
summary: A great value that can't be beat

reviewText: I first bought these to go with a Discman many years ago. I review lots of classical music CDs here at Amazon and if I listened to them all via loudspeakers it would probably drive my wife nuts. So I often use these headphones instead. Another reason I do that is that I find that the sound they deliver is a clear analog of the sound I get from high quality loudspeakers. I find I can wear them comfortably for as long as I'm listening -- and sometimes that's hours at a time -- and never have the urge, as I do with other headphones, to take them off because of physical or aural discomfort.More recently I got an iPod -- my kids went together for my birthday and bought me the fanciest iPod available! -- and I find that these headphones are MUCH more comfortable and acoustically accurate than those darn earbuds that come with the iPod. I do notice that these headphones apparently have greater impedance than the earbuds; that is, the volume control has to be turned up a bit to get the same volume as delivered by the earbud. But the improvement in auditory accuracy and comfort is more than worth it.Thumbs up on this tried-and-true classic set of headphones.Scott Morrison
summary: I've Had My Sony MDR-V6s Fifteen Years and They're Still Wonderful

reviewText: I've had these headphones on at a reasonable volume, and I cannot hear people directly in front of me talking to me.  The sound quality is excellent.  I want an extra pair because my husband keeps stealing mine.
summary: Excellent Quality Sound, Can't Hear Outside Sounds

reviewText: So I received this product on time and with no damage to the package...Solid materials, the workmanship is very solid as well.  Performance-wise, so far these headphones suck.  The first time a plugged them in they sounded alright, however there was this hiss in the background.  Keep in mind I use these for tracking and practicing, so not very loud on the sound levels and I have excellent hearing so I know when something is awry.  After about 5 minutes the headphones became really washy, almost like listening to the ocean in a conch shell.  I tried everything from adjusting EQ to having the volume at 10% and still they hiss and pop like crazy.  Some tones don't even register, they literally sound like waves crashing in the ocean and the right earphone physically POPS at low tones almost like the sound of a fridge turning on.  Do yourself a favor and PASS on this junk. I'm going to try to return them to Amazon and get another pair, but until then...one star...move along people nothing to see or hear....
summary: Ehh..I think I got a lemon...

reviewText: I have bought many headphones and found that these sound more professional than my most expensive headphones. These cans are legendary in the audio world. With a flat frequency response, they are very EQ friendly. These headphones will definitely tell you the quality of your music so it is best to have your MP3's with the highest bitrate possible, or use FLAC whenever you can. I have read that some people are disappointed with the sound, it is not the headphones!!! It is your music source and the equipment used. It is best that you have some kind of headphone amplifier or good audio gear to drive them as ipods and the like do not have the power to properly push them.These are my go to headphones when I want to have a good listening experience.As a last note, Sony has quietly retired the MDR-V6's after nearly 30 years of service!!!! I ordered an extra pair just in case and I also have the MDR-7506 as well but prefer the old tried and true MDR-V6.Get them while you can and beware of knock-offs!!!
summary: Get them while you can-They Sound Professional

reviewText: I borrowed these headphones from a colleague and fell in love with them and had to buy my own. I have been deejaying for almost 9 years now and have to say that these are some of the best for the money for sure. They are very comfortable. I love how my entire ear fits inside the cup. The sound quality is great. The bass response is very very nice. I am definitely very happy with these. Highly recommended.

Theres are  the best headphones I've ever had. I need to replace the cups around this time, but they produce the most amazing sound, and block out noise without fancy noise-canceling technology. The coiling cord allows you to walk away from your computer as well as having your mp3 player far away such as in your backpack.This is an assured 100% satisfaction product. The only investment you'll have to make is 6-15 dollars to replace the ear cups, but this is minor compared to the amazing quality you get!

These headphones are great, when buying these headphones don't expect major hardcore bass because that is not what they are meant for, they are evened out and have a very clear pleasant sound balancing all of the sounds in music, videos, etc.

I've known of the mdr-v6's for quite a while now.  It's a very old model that's still being produced by Sony.  That alone tells me that it's a good product.  I've known people who swear by these, and I really didn't pay too much attention since I didn't believe such inexpensive headphones would be any good.  After purchasing the headphones, I was immediately impressed by the sound quality.  Much much better than I expected, especially at this price point.  At first the highs were a little too sharp, but after burning them in (about 50 hours of use), they've mellowed down quite a bit.  It won't put out as much bass as some of the newer headphones like Beats, but the overall clarity on these are much better.  I've also used Senn 280HD's & ATH-m50's, which are more expensive headphones, and I can honestly say that the price/perfomance ratio on these are much better than of those.  I also think that the sound is flat-out better than the 280's, and very close to the m50's (so close that it might just be subjective).  Overall, I'm still stumped on how good these are, and how much I enjoy using them.Install the velour ear pads from Beyerdynamic.  They make these so much more comfortable for long stretches of use.

Have no doubt MDR-V6 is one fine piece of acoustic equipment. However, they're tight around the melon and after 4 months of use I had to tighten the screws on the fold-out hinges. But, they sound a-ma-zing, VERY nice. The sound is so clear that as I listen to them at night, there are moments when I instinctively check if they're actually plugged in and I'm not blasting my stereo aloud waking my neighbors. Some reviews say they have no bass - NOT TRUE, NICE BASS. Really, take my word for it, if plugged into a device that provides decent sound these headphones leave little to be desired. Great sound for under a buck!

A basic summary of what I think are pro's and con's for these headphones.Pros:- Comfortable for prolonged listening sessions- Superb sealing, minimal sound leakage- Free carrying pouch- Earpads replaceable with Beyerdynmaic DT250's for maximum comfort- Folds for easier and convenient storage- Neutral sound (may see this as a con)- Easy on the wallet ($65 on B&H;, Amazon)- Coiled cord- Retro styling- Amplifier is not necessaryCons:- Default pads flake easily- Exposed wires susceptible to accidental tear/fray- Inconvenient for moving about- Neutral sound (may see this as pro)- Replacement headphones are the Sony MDR-V600's (?)- Sony brand name may turn off some consumers- Retro stylingI've owned these for 6 months, and can safely say these are some of the best headphones in the <$100 market. The retro design is nice, and the neutral sound helps me point out details that I haven't noticed before. I would avoid these if you're looking for a bass heavy product, but overall a good buy. Great if you're a casual listener, or Junior Audiophile.

A relative bargain when compared to "fashion lifestyle" headphones.  The Sony 'phones were always known for being quite good and these out perform many costlier headphones.  The ear pads will fall apart after a year or two, so expect to have to replace them.  This happens to most headphones with this type of ear pad.  This isn't unique to Sony.
summary: Far better than most 300 dollar headphones.

reviewText: This is a very good headphone for listening and djing. Even though it hasn't many articulations, the sound is very good.

Bought these for my husband who listens/records music constantly. While they have a good sound quality, the material covering the ear phones part has begun to separate, exposing the padding inside the ear phone. We are disappointed in the quality of the product.
I'm very happy with this headphones, however I can't take them to my office. I just enjoy them in my bed and feel in a concert. Great seller, beautiful sony package.
According to headroomdotcom, these phones are remarkably flat in frequency response. They sound great. No complaints. Small feeder wires look delicate, but sound is really good.

Very natural sounding w/ a hint of warmness.  The soundscape on the MDR-V6 is very nice if you are into the more natural vocal spectrum.  Some may say the bass is weak, but that is not the case.  I believe this are tuned for more accurate music interpretations.  The bass is fine in the highs & mids, in the lows is where you will feel bass a little flat in the lower registers.  A lot of headphones now-a-days have been overly tuned to be bass-heavy to satisfy the younger ipod/mp3 generation.  For this price range, these headphones should be considered as a top choice.  After the burn-in/break in period, this headphones keep sounding better.  The fit is great, initially a little tight but will stretch for a comfortable fit the more you use it.  The pleather/leatherish earphone covers are quite soft.  Long term use will cause your ears to get warm/hot and maybe a little sweaty, but that is typically with almost all closed-ear headphones.  I've had my V6s for over 6 years now and it still looks brand new.  If I need to buy any replacement parts, at least they are fairly cheap (sub $20) and plenty.  These headphones are far from perfect, but at $75 they are a steal.  Highly recommended.

This is actually my first set of studio monitors. I've tried out other headphones like Bose and Beats by Dre and the Sony MDR-V6 simply blow those out of the water. This headphone gives a flat response, meaning that you will be hearing the track the way it was intended to be heard. Other headphones will produce a more artificial sound (extra bass, etc.) I did a lot of research on these headphones before buying them, and let me tell you, after 3 minutes with these bad boys, I understand why these are a music industry favorite. The sound is just amazing and the construction is pretty solid.
summary: Amazing headphones!!! Basically a steal at this price!!!

reviewText: The sound, comfort, and price for these headphones is out of this world. Forget the Beats, forget the Bose, these headphones are the real deal.

I just purchased my second set of these. The price was great and now I have one for home and work.Love the sound and the sensitivity. I used to use these at my college radio station. Prior to the Sony, I used and still have a set of AKG KDF240. For the application of the broadcast board, I had issues hearing with the AKG (needed more amplification).I use these with my iphone and computer and have no issues with loudness. So have used this type of headphone for over 20 years. Glad to have a second set. I also replace the original cup padding with velour pads, now they are comfy too.  Beyerdynamic EDT 250 Velour Padded Earcushions

I bought these headphones in 1992, and unlike most of the rest of the stuff I squandered my money on back then, these were and continue to be the real deal.My earpads have flaked off their coating like everyone else.  But no need to buy new phones, you can order the earpads from sony.com or some specialty audio stores:MDR-V6/MDR-7506 Ear PadPART: X-2113-124-1PRICE: $6.00 (US)

I was looking for a pair of headphones in the $50-$150 price range, and after reading many reviews (both from Amazon customers and elsewhere) I settled on these. The primary selling point for me was the sheer number of owners who've had these for 10+ years and still swear by them.It's absolutely true. The sound quality is simply amazing. I listen to a wide range of music, from indie rock to hip hop to classical, and these headphones consistently produce clear, rich sounds that captures the subtleties of background instruments/voices without losing any fidelity at higher volumes.Beyond audio quality, the phones themselves are sturdy and look like they can withstand years of heavy use. The materials are at once durable and comfortable, but some folks (with wider heads like me) may feel a bit of strain after extended use (an hour or more) because these do sit a bit tighter on the head.All told, this is an excellent product that's withstood the test of time. There may not be a better pair of "over-the-ear" headphones at this price range.

I have been a headphone fanatic for thirty years and have owned and used a variety of headphones over those years, to include Stax SR-5, Sennheiser HD-424 and HD-580.  The Sony MDRV6 excells as the best value of any headphone that I've ever owned.  They are especially good at producing natural-sounding deep bass, and the overall octave-to-octave balance is excellent.  The sound quality is all in all comparable to other headphones that cost considerably more.The MDRV6 is especially well-suited for travel due to the collapsible design, and for noisy environments or for quiet environments such as a library where the sound emitted by open-back headphones would distract others.The MDRV6 is not quite as comfortable as some other headphones, but the comfort can be improved enormously by replacing the pads with the velour pads from BeyerDynamic.  The pads that come on the MDRV6 have a non-breathable cover, and significant additional discomfort is caused by the way that the thin foam cover is glued to the pad around the inner circumference of the pad, which prevents the top and back of your ear from slipping into the space between the pad and the face of the headphone.  This forces the pad to rest on the back of the ear, which compresses the ear and eventually becomes uncomfortable.  I read on a web forum where several people had replaced the pads (which eventually come apart) with a velour pad made by BeyerDynamic, and after I did this replacement on my one pair that had a damaged pad, the increase in comfort was so great that I immediately did the other pair.
