The Sony MDRV6 headphones are best I have tried in the $100 range.  They are more comfortable, than my Grado SR225i cans that cost twice as much.  The only con for me is that they come with a coil cord instead of a  straight cord which would be better for my listening setup.

This is the second pair we bought - 1 for each son.  The sound is great - cancels out all noise.  Older son has had these for 2 years now younger son has a pair.  They say they will never go back to just ear buds.  The sound quality is excellent, music comes through very clear and younger son uses them to game.  Says the sound is superb.  They tried a friends Bose that was 3x's the price - liked the Sony so much better - friend wants theirs.  Would recommend for anyone who wants clean, clear sound at a great price.
summary: Great sound at a great price

reviewText: only complain is that the cord is so long it becomes heavy and gets tangled.  probably good if you are a long ways from the player, but annoying when you are using a personal music device.
summary: great sound and comfortable to wear

reviewText: Very rich sound for the price.  Have owned this product for several years and the sound is spot on but the earpads flaked badly and fall off repeatedly which is a pain in the ass to deal with.  See many similar complaints.

First of all, I'd like to say, the packaging is very nifty with the red velvet.Now, second, the sound. At first, when I first tried it, it sounded weird on my film soundtracks because I wasn't used to it, but after getting used to it I wondered what the heck I had been listening to with my last headphones. These new headphones make songs from a month ago sound too good!Third, the the ease of use is flawless, except sometimes when you take them off and put them back on, you might have to spread the earcups out as they like to be together.Fourthly is the comfort. I was thinking of giving this a four star, but decided not to. The reason why, was because the COIL. Yes the coil. That long cord. If you late it hang down next to your chair, it sometimes causes to send a beat back to your headphones. Not a sound, but you feel it, and it's annoying-- so I try to keep my wire on top of the desk. I might coil it up later when I feel like it. Other than that, it's perfect, except it does kind of block out sound so, if someone is calling you, forget it >.< lolEDIT after over a year of use:The sound quality is great! Sometimes the wire can get in the way because of its weight, but if you keep it on the desk, which is really easy to do, there is no problem. The earpads are comfortable too. But there is a problem with this device. Despite its pros, the earpads aren't very strong, and replacements are even worse, AND harder to put on. The earpads that came with the device lasted 6 months. This is good. However, replacement pads I bought didn't last long at all, 1-3 months usually (one or both earpads). I've had to buy like 6 replacement pads. I admit, I might not be putting them on EXACTLY right, which I intend to take every precaution when buying a deluxe version pair, but still, the internal gradual ripping of the material covering the inner foam just keeps happening. Like I said, when I get the deluxe pair, I will try my best to put it on perfectly, but I'm still hoping for the best.

These headphones sound amazingly good and are even better considering I got them for around $70 (Refurbished).They fit very well in my head and I can use them for hours. They also fold and come with a pretty nice carrying bag.Would definitely purchase again!
The quality is Good , the service is good. I will recommend it to my friendsI am very satisfied

first thing is ... i  just bought this headphones and the sound is perfect...bass, middles, and highs are in the spot totally leveled... the earpads are very confortables...the coiled cable is one of the things i like cause i can move around when im djing.... im psytrance dj...first time i try this was lastnite on big open air party and they ve worked fine....advise... dont go to expensive cause this headphones have what you need for dj or ipod...

I read other good reviews on this one, the price and the brand made me go for it. Good quality headphones, with excellent sound. No noise reduction but excellent isolation. I use it on my home studio and on the road to listen to music on my Ipod. The are bulky for the road, but i do not care the extra load. Highly recommend.
Comfy, great sound, great bass, completely drowns out any sound on the subway for a great relaxing ride!

I am a producer for House/Techno music. Graduated with a minor in Music. 10 years of experience dealing with recording, producing and mixing. These headphone broke down on me after 1 year. The right side stopped working. I loved it but now i'm moving on to the Shure SRH440.I own an MBox 2 PRO as my interface for the headphones. The MDR V6 are very good but for me it lacked on bass since i tried plenty of times to produce and mix with them (even thou your not supposed to mix with headphones) and when done i would listen to the song with my studio monitors and it comes out with too much bass, hence i do not have a sub-woofer. Mid's high's  are clear and crisp.You wont be able to hear anything around you but the music your listening too. I had many situations where i had to be hit on the head since i could not hear anyone calling me. I recommend it but be very careful since it might break down like mine did.comfortable? well i always got bothered at the top of my head after 1 hour of listening... Just my experience.

As a radio broadcaster it is vital to have quality headphones while on the air. I purchased these headphones in 1994 and I have to say they sound as good in 2013 as they did in 1994. Nice rich sound and comfortable fit. I replaced the plug and need to replace the ear pads now, but it still works. great. These are headphones that can outlast most radio careers. If you're looking for a quality set of headphones, get these and you'll never have to buy another set of headphones again.
This was a gift and the receiver loved it.  He uses it at work and doesn't bother his fellow office workers.

I initially bought two cheaper headphones(Panasonic RP-HT21 & JVC HA-RX300) believing that I would be wasting money if I bought a more expensive set.Boy was I wrong. I picked these up in the Black Friday Week of deals for 39.99 and could not believe what I was listening too. My Music Never Sounded this Good through my Mbd integrated audio before. The BASS was Clean, Accurate and Not Overpowering, The MIDS were Clear and the HIGHS were Crisp without being overly bright. The sound isolation is also pretty good.I'll admit at times it feels like a clamp on my head and I currently have it pulled down where I can see 5 notches on either side to fit. The Ear cups also might not fit around people with big ears but by no means are these small.The headphones come with a 3.5mm adapter, a leatherette carrying pouch and is equipped with a thick coiled cable.As good as these headphones are, I do not know how they will survive on the go (It Can be folded into a more "portable" size but they label them as a Studio Monitor headphone and they have wires that are exposed around the headband)If I knew they were this good, I would have bought more of them and sooner.
summary: Worth the Money Over a Cheaper Set

reviewText: Good things:-High quality flat sound (better than most higher priced headphones)-Very comfortable-Good isolation-Can be fold for travel-Very cheapBad things:-Earpads fake leather tear out apart easily (But you can solve this buying better earpads such as Beyerdynamic EDT 250 earpads)
Its a decent headphone for the priceAmazing soundFor indoor use is perfect but for outdoor like using with iPod not to good the cable is to long and curly

I initially liked the clarity and detail of the sound, but after a few uses the midrange/upper midrange started to hurt my ears.  Even after adjusting the eq...some reviewers at Head-fi described these headphones has having problems with sibilance, and I agree.  Now I can't even listen to them, its like listening to fingernails on a chalkboard. Going back to the warmer, smoother sound of my fav ATH-M50's.If you have tinnitus or sensitive hearing, these may not be right for you.  I returned mine.Nice build quality, compact size, paid fifty bucks on sale.
Amazing headphones, I'm not the most experienced when it comes to headphones but I did a bit of research before buying and I have to say I am very satisfied with these.

I've used the MDR V6 headphones since 1986, adding the 7506 in about '97.  I've tried others, but still have't found anything to take their place. I have  four sets of each type and just ordered three more 7506. We send them out with live sound systems and location recordings and my techs can choose any headphone they want. They always choose the Sonys.We have been using headphone softies (actual product name)to cover the ear pads with. They are washable rayon chenille covers in a couple of different colors. We sometimes have headphones on for hours at a time. The headphone softies make it much pleasanter. Cool in warm weather, warmer in cold weather. After more than twenty five years using these 'phones, we aren't about to change.
Great headphones for the price, and fit comfortably have no problem now...Well worth the purchase priceI'm happy thank you very much.

I needed to replace a pair of AKG 'phones that had finally broken after about 10 years, and remembered the MDR-V6 that I'd owned in the early '90s - what a surprise to see that they were still being manufactured!The current production model seems to be exactly the same as my old MDR-V6 - they are comfortable for about an hour, and then start to feel a tad heavy (the open-back AKG model was especially light), but this is probably more of a personal bias on my part, since I just don't enjoy wearing headphones for hours & hours.At some point, I might experiment with the BeyerDynamic replacement cushions, but I'm not in any hurry.Sound quality is really what makes these guys such a value. I used to own a pair of Koss electrostatic headphones, and while they certainly had their good points, this inexpensive Sony 'phone easily betters the Koss in extended low-frequency response, and bass integration. I don't hear any sort of peakiness with the MDR-V6, and they maintain that smooth response at lower volume levels, which is important to me.To sum up, these are easily the best-sounding headphones I've experienced at anywhere near their price. They're well-built, reliable, fold nicely, and have a single cord instead of a yoke - highly recommended.

I bought the headphones for my brother as his Christmas gift.  The headphone was torn on the side.  Not bad enough to need to be returned but I was concerned that it would get worse.  I quickly returned the items, got my refund and ordered a new set for my brother.  Great produc, he loves itt!!!

Previously owned a pair of Bose noise cancelling headphones that did a good enough job but tended to get uncomfortable after a while.  These headphones do just as good a job of cancelling out the world around me and sound fantastic but are FAR more comfortable than the other pair I had before.  Really glad to have picked up this pair.

Wow. Just wow. I'm a 22 yr old with a crazy obsession with sound and music. Audiophile? Maybe. These headphones are so perfect in every way. The sound is so crisp, clear and clean, the design is awesome and simple and the materials are very high quality. They are so comfortable even for my sensitive ears. The bass is just absolutely perfect, not choppy or muddy at all. Forget the Beats, forget the Souls by Ludacris, save yourself the money and get higher quality at half the price. There's no surprise that these have been so widely used for almost 30 years. The included adapter is perfect because it allows me to use these cans in my iPhone and home audio system which is also 100% Sony, I just love their audio hardware.

I've had the MDR-V5 headphones for 18 years now (yes, eighteen). Nothing that I've tried comes close to them. They're still like new, with perfect sound for audiophiles. The little problem with the plastic cover of the pads flaking out was easily solved: I peeled the whole thing off, which leaves a soft fabric, very comfortable to the ears. If the MDR-V6 are anything like them, that should be the way to go.

I'm a fairly big guy (6'2", 250 lbs), so I was a little concerned about some of the comments regarding comfort. But the headphones fit perfectly, are very comfortable, and drown out external noise very well.  Sound is among the best I have ever heard, and the long, coiled cable seems very sturdy. They are a little on the warm side to wear, but that is to  be expected with over the ear headphones. I've had these for only a couple of weeks, but I think I will  be very satisfied with the quality of these headphones, especially at this price. I'd much rather have these at $60, than "trendy" Dr Dre's or whatever for $200!!!

my last set MDR V5, broke at the screw;scotch tape made them usable again, but finally i had to give in-when the cups shredded-im not cheap-just THRIFTY!These seem to be stronger-as I really abuse them-almost thinking of adding the scotch tape NOW-to reinforce them;The sound is as about as good as it gets-but how can i know?Is there a law of diminishing returns for headphones sound pleasingness-subjective?As I go over the latest offerings, i can see none that rate higher than these-all at 4.5 starsI try to 'weight' the negative reviews # of 1 stars + # of 2 stars + HALF the # of 3 stars total, VSHALF the # of 3 and ALL of #4, 5s;A model can have a 4.5 rating-but if the bottom 3 total are significant-i stand backI was thinking that since ive had these for 8? years-that technology MUST have increased to make a better sounding set of HPsIve noticed shocking price drops since i last visited a few months ago;But since all I need are new earcups why not spend <$20 rather than $70-100?Esp in this economy-yes i know when my choices are multiplied by the millions we see Black Friday turn into Black XmasMy ONLY question is why these did not have the gold plate plug ins?I saved the outer larger gold plug in from the broken set, but of course the benefit might be lost since the smaller silver plug still must go in first

I really enjoy having bass back in my music. These MDR-v6's are excellent quality and also work well when used with my iPad.

After close to 20 years I broke down and got my second pair of my MDR's  my first two MDR-600 witch I have are the best headsets you can buy.  The MDR-V6 is the same just a bit smaller and lighter  for the price I am absolutely blown away $40 they should be well over $100 and I paid more than that two decades ago for my old set. For the price I paid for the Sony MDR-V6 they are just as good or better than the more expensive one.

To remove the coils from the cable:1. Immerse the cable in boiling water for several minutes.2. With your left hand, grip the cable near the headphones with a towel that has been moistened with boiling water.3. With your right hand, pull the entire length of the cable through your gripped left hand.Repeat this process until the cable is straight. Do not use too much force, as doing so may tear the cable sheath.(I also installed theBeyerdynamic pads.They are an essential upgrade; they make these headphones much more comfortable.)

I've purchased three pairs of these. I've just ordered my third, only because I keep giving them away to people that I care about.  I care enough that I want them to hear music closer as they were meant to be heard.  I own Grados, high end Denons, and tried all the popular Senns, AKGs, etc.  It's a very personal choice, headphones.  I like the Grados for their sound: articulation, detail, staging... comfort wise, not so much.  The cord twists at the Y, and above the Y.  The foam is somewhat fragile if you're not careful.  Other than that, the Grados are spectacular - I just prefer them to any others that I've heard before including the $300+ Sennns.  But I'm not writing a review about the Grados.The Sony V6 are comfortable, with a closed design.  They're also more compact, better for travel.  If you're going to own one pair of headphones, these would be it.  I own several others, but I've ordered another pair of the V6.  Why?  Comfort.  Ease of use. Great sound, more on that in a minute.  The cord is much more manageable, the foam is comfortable, and the pressure is just right.  These are ideal for the computer, and efficient enough to listen to a verity types of music powered by my portable MP3 player.Sound: It's almost up there with the Grado 60, and better in some ways.  While it lacks the detail and articulation for classical music and jazz in comparison, the staging is fuller when listening to pop or dance.  I've stopped using my $179 DJ style Denons all together.  I use my Shure in-ears for working out.  Plan to use the V6 for travel, PC and just general purpose.  I'll still use the Grados (I've given many of these away as gifts too) time to time for classical and jazz.  And I was ready to plop down some money on some Senn 595s due to all the positive reviews... surprisingly, when I tried them out I preferred the sound of the V6 and Grado 60/80s at less than half the cost.  I'm sure many will disagree, but it just sounded flat in comparison.  The lesson learned?  Go try them before you go on faith of other's reviews for something like $200+ headphones.  On the V6, for $65 - I don't think there's a better buy, and chances are, you'll be happy with the way these sound.  Then again, it's just another review, but a favorable one.  In any case, I wish you good hunting.  On a related and different note: Home speakers, before buying the typical name-brands from the big box stores, I'd suggest trying Andrew Jones designed Pioneers (excellent for price) and the Epos line before you buy anything.  Both excellent buys, different price segments but both are worth auditioning.  Take a CD, and listen to them before making an impulse buy on anything else.  I share, because I ended up selling my brand-XXX after listening to them.

To begin, the sound on these is very detailed, and it will play your music like it is. If your music is a poorly recorded track, it will sound poorly recorded so I recommend feeding these "studio monitor headphones" the highest quality sound files you can. The bass can extend deep and low yet remain tight (not flabby), the mids are well balanced and have no artificial coloration to them, and the highs are all there. I auditioned these at a store before I bought them, and preferred them to the Audio Technica M-50's, Grado SR60's, Sennheiser 280's, and even some amped Sennheiser HD650's. And these Sony V6's don't need amping at all because can be easily driven by an ipod and get get really loud.I don't think these have a perfectly flat response, they are a little bass and treble heavy to my ears. I believe everyone's ears are different, and for me, I agree with the reviewers that say the treble can be harsh. And because of this, I could not crank the volume without the treble eventually becoming fatiguing. But since I still loved the sound and clarity of these, I tried to see if I could change this. I went to the craft store and bought some thin felt for a few cents, cut it to proper size and then placed it between the headphone drivers(speakers)and the ear pads. This cut down the harshness without changing anything else, and now I decided I will be keeping these.Another modification I had to do relates to my ears. My ears are big and poke out, and these headphones were very uncomfortable because they pushed on my ears to much, since they do have some clamping force for sound isolation. I found another simple solution for this: you cut some thin strips of cloth from a t-shirt and push them in the crevice under the pad that goes around your ears to give more space between your ear and the drivers, thus making them rest around your ears up against your head, and not ON your ears. You don't want to shove too much material in there or you start to lose some bass and could maybe tear the ear pads if you get too crazy. Just a half of an inch width by six inches long folded in half "hot dog style" worked great for me. I found I didn't need to upgrade to the Beyerdynamic pads after doing this, and now these are comfortable for hours and this saved me twenty four dollars. Since the headband has a metal spine through it, I was also successful in carefully bending it outward to provide less clamping force on my larger than normal head.The sound isolation on these is great, and I actually love the coiled cord which helps from keeping the cord ripped out of the headphone if it gets snagged on something. They are built very well, but I do not like the small wires exposed on the sides which I think makes them vulnerable to snag so I will have to be careful. I think these headphones are as good as you can get for $70, if you want better you are going to have to start spending a lot more money. Just make sure you buy from a refutable seller and make sure you don't buy fakes, which are out there in abundance. These headphones are great so I wrote this review- to let you know there potential and to show you how you can improve them with simple, non permanent mods if you are inclined to try them. I hope Sony never stops making these.
summary: My favorite headphones, after a few small modifications

I use this pair on a Yamaha YDP223 digital piano. I've used several different pairs on the same digital piano, and never imagined how good the sound source was until I plugged MDR-V6 in. The treble notes are transparent instead of being metallic (which I always assumed was the way Yamaha sounded).Yes, it's a bit old school in design, and the thick coiled cord is heavy. But it's pretty comfortable to wear for an hour or two. It also seals external sounds quite well.Everybody who owns a digital piano should buy one.

It's hard to write a review for these headphones without seeming like a shill. I must say however, that I cannot give them a sufficiently glowing review for their many strengths. Since I bought them nearly a year ago, I have used them almost constantly with my computer for listening to music, watching videos, and playing games. I have had to replace the pads in that time, but they're otherwise still in good shape and still absolutely essential to my ears. The sound coming out of my old speakers just doesn't compare, and I rarely use them these days.These headphones are well-known and widely-used in the world of audio production for very faithfully reproducing sound. There are no special tricks here, just a very flat, very wide frequency response curve. What this means for the casual listener who isn't used to that, however, is that you start hearing the texture in your music that you didn't know was there. For under $100, if you've never experienced professional-quality sound output, you owe it to yourself to get a pair of these headphones.Besides the extraordinarily-good sound quality, I've since found these headphones to be fairly comfortable, and I wear them for long periods at a time. The coiled cable is actually pretty convenient, and it tends to stay out of the way all on its own. They're also almost as sensitive as a pair of earphones, so you can generally use them with a portable music player without an amplifier. They're somewhat effective at sound isolation as well--good for shutting out distractions.All in all, extremely impressive. I will never do with less again.
summary: A must-have; incomparably superior to consumer speakers.

reviewText: OK I have had this unit for a few months...At first I thought it was a revelation.The most realistic flat and detailed unit ever herd.Then I realized that the mids are slightly recessed ANdThe highs were fatiguing after extendid listening.So as revealing as these units are, they are not the end of your journey on headphones.I myself still have them but end up using the audiotechnica es7 as the es7 is just the best

I have used the Sony MDR-V6 headphones for about 20 years now and I just ordered another set. I always suggest these to others looking for great quality headphones and never have I had a complaint. I also had a friend of mine that works in sound editing try my pair after he stated he bought a great set of Sennheisers and he immediately went out an bought a pair of these and has not gone back.You'll not find a better "bang for the buck" than these headphones. Don't waste your time looking anywhere else, Sony has it dialed in. Why else would they keep making the same headsets for this many years? When I got my new ones I could not tell the difference between the set that was 20 years old and the new ones. Not one little thing! They are one of the few companies that "didn't fix it because it wasn't broke" like so many companies do. You'll have to pay 3 to 5 times as much for comparable headphones and then you may not like them as much.Buy them, you won't be sorry!
summary: The Best You'll Get For Your Buck!

reviewText: The Sony MDR-V6s were the first really good headphones I owned. After about 15 years of use, the foam padding was a bit run down. After doing the exhaustive search for the best headphones, I bought a pair of Sennheiser HD580s (I also own Etymotic ER-4Ps). Comparing the HD580 to my MDR-V6s, I would say that the MDR-V6s are better for two reasons. 1. The MDR-V6s are more comfortable to wear for long periods of time, and 2. The MDR-V6s have a telephone-like cord, which is easier to deal with than the straight HD580 cord. The sound quality was very good on both headphones, and about equal. I ended up buying new foam pads for my 15-year-old MDR-V6s, which made them feel like brand new headphones. I also bought a second pair of MDR-V6s, and shelved the HD580s for now.Do not buy the MDR-600s by mistake. I have never used them, but I have read numerous reviews that state that the MDR-600s are inferior to the MDR-V6s. You can still buy the MDR-V6s, but they are harder to find. I bought mine at millionbuy because Amazon did not have them in stock. For some reason, the MDR-V6 product name at Amazon magically changed to MDR-600, even though it is an entirely different product. I am not sure why this happened.The audioreview Web site has a great collection of headphone reviews.

Love these headphones. They are lighter than what I expected. They fold up nicely for portability. Feels like solid construction and parts that will last.  Sound quality is amazing. Great value for the price. We ordered another pair for my husband the same day!  I can't believe I waited so long to ditch my earbuds for proper headphones.
summary: These are great! Bought a second pair for husband!

reviewText: I bought my current pair of MDR-V6 phones about 25 years ago, and they still are the best sounding headphones I've heard, and they still sound as good as they did back then. To solidify my confidence in them over the years, any time I've seen any documentary or video of a rock group that showed any band members or engineers in the studio, they were always using the MDR-V6. If it's good enough for the pros, it's good enough for me. The amazing thing is that the price really hasn't changed much. I think I paid about $50 or $60 for mine. Anyway, I guarantee these headphones will not disappoint.By the way, I noticed that Amazon suggests a headphone plug adapter as a paired purchase with these. I don't know why they would do that. Unless Sony has changed something, these come with that. It has the standard (home stereo system) plug which unscrews to reveal the smaller (portable player) plug underneath it.I've read other reviews about Amazon pairing items that don't even go together. Don't assume you need it.

I bought these, and all the 5 star reviews are true!It has a nice fit, and I was pleasantly surprised by the quality!  It even comes with a small leather bag to keep them in!The sound is very good! Especially the bass!I also really like the fact that I don't have to have the volume high to listen to music without hearing other people or the tv in the background.overall, VERY nice headphones!

I love these headphones.  The sound is clear and the seal around the ears is really good.  It drowns out the background noise at work very well.The only con is the cord is a little bulky.  Wish they were the tangle free flat type, however I  can deal with it.  Apparently  sony has been making these since the 90's, and hasn't changed them.  I'm ok with that!
Great Headphones. They feel great, they sound great, I have no complaints. I basically use them for everything. I've looked at everyones positive reviews and I am not dissappointed at all.
summary: Best headphones for a Good Price.

reviewText: I bought these headphones based on reviews by other Amazon customers - ready to return these cans in a flash if they were not up to snuff.  I'm an audiophile and want to hear music with details, with a nice coherence, with voices that sound as natural as possible, with the sounds of instruments having depth and character....you know - MUSIC!... as close as possible as it might sound if the music was being played live in front of me. I play several instruments and have been a techie setting up sound systems for orchestras at performances ( it is wonderful to be backstage listening to an orchestra from whichever perspective you choose by moving around; near the woodwinds, the brass, the percussion- so I know what instruments really sound like up close).  I don't have the usual audiophile desire to hear the performance from 20th row center.  I like a piano to sound just like one sounds when you are sitting at it playing it, mechanical sounds and all.So....do these deliver?  I a word - yes.  It's a very much "you are there" experience.  What I do to make up for a subjective very slight bass deficiency is just bump up the EQ reproduction of the bass just one notch in my MP3 player to get the slam associated with kettle drums or the grunt of basses (like in the first minute or so of the Alegro Maestoso...the beginning of the 1st Movement of Mahler's 1st Symphony ...love it!).  So, I totally enjoy these Sony V6's, my daughter voted overwhelmingly to get these over the Sennheiser HD 280 Pro's because of the relative clarity when playing through her Nano...we bought both but kept the V6 - returned the Sennheiser ( she only records at the highest quality possible and she has a good ear).  For the price, and in the "closed" category ( love to wear them around very noisy New York City while being blissed out by soft music)- can't be beat and most, most  enjoyable.  Highly recommended.

I love these headphones. I'm a big music connoisseur so quality is imperative to me. These headphones deliver no matter what genre or intensity you throw at them. The only problem I have is that I wish they were louder. Don't get me wrong, they are loud, but the quality is so good I just want to completely drown myself in it.
NICE PRICE BUT LESS NICE SOUND.I AM NOT SO SHURE THAT THE SONY MDR V6 ARE SO GREAT LIKE MANY OTHER HERE THINK.NICE SOUNS. THIS IS ALL.THANK YOU.
summary: NOT AMAZING. NOT GREAT. JUST NICE.

reviewText: These headphones have great sound, are super comfortable, and do a great job blocking out outside sound.  They could probably stand to have the styling upgraded though, as they look a little out of date compared to newer designs.4/29/13 Update:  Although I am still very happy with the sound of these headphones.  I am going to take off two stars because my earpads already wore out.  I've had these less than a year and use them very VERY lightly.  Although there are many replacement options available, wearing out in less than a year with the light use only that I've put on them is inexcusable.  Now I'm going to have to try and figure out Sony's warranty service, not something I'm looking forward to.  On the plus side, I've found these to be very good for the airplane - they really do block out a lot of outside noise.

Excellent sound quality and faithful reproduction, better than anything I've ever listened to. When I first got them, I re-listened to my whole collection just so I could pick out all the bits I'd missed out on before. Blows away Beats and Bose and whatever other overpriced brands are out there. At first, these were a bit uncomfortable. I replaced the pads with some velour ones that I also bought from Amazon. Now, they are much more comfortable, and seem to be better at blocking out sound, both ways (good for when you want to listen in a quiet room). I think they look good too, they aren't bulky like some other models. Nowadays, after breaking them in and the velour pads, I will occasionally fall asleep in my bed with them on, and I don't mind keeping them from when I wake up to when I go to bed (I am a heavy music listener, if you can't tell)I mostly listen to metal and classical, but this plays just about anything really well. I do have to mention that these headphones reproduce music perfectly, which also means less bass compared to other phones (Beats) that intentionally inflate bass (which in my opinion distorts music that doesn't need it). If you have an equalizer on your audio player or computer, it's no big deal at all. When I listen to hip-hop or electronic music, sometimes I jack up the bass, and these headphones can put out a good thump.

I was just looking for quality headphones that had a phone coil so I could easily reach for things without worrying about accidentally unplugging them.  Lo and behold, my friend who works in media pointed out that these headphones were available, and after reading mostly raving reviews from other Amazon users, I had to get them.They are comfortable on my ears, and more importantly, the sound that comes through these is excellent.  They also do well in blocking most outside ambient noise.  I'm looking forward to using these as long as they last.  Bonus: They fold easily and come with a handy pouch as well as a screw-in 1/4" adapter.

The sound quality of the Sony MDR-V6 is phenomenal with a good balance.Unfortunately, if there are any issues it is a HUGE hassle -- which makes me want to never buy a Sony headphone again.I only use my headphones at the desktop and keep them in their case otherwise. My replaceable foam earpad began splitting at the seam causing the white inner foam to be exposed all the way around the inner rim.I contacted Sony chat support about getting the earpad replaced (I am still under warranty). After 40 minutes in text chat they told me they couldn't help with parts replacement and made me call customer support phone line. Customer support told me I needed to send in the headphones (purchase box/shipping), pay a $29 service fee, and I would be given a refurbished pair of headphones. All this - while under warranty, keeping my headphones in perfect condition (minus the earpad), and only needing a new earpad.I told them I should not have to send in my headphones AND PAY for it, when I am under warranty and only need the new earpad. They then told me I could pay them for a new earpad for $7+ dollars + shipping.I cannot recommend buying these unless you are ok with a company NOT adhering to a warranty and price gouging at every point OR knowing that you may have to pay for replacement parts even while under warranty.

These are nice and clear, flat sounding headphones.  Good separation and balance.  They do not, to my ears, go down to 5hz as advertized.  Though the bass is clear it is lacking for both mixing and listening.
summary: Nice Headphones, Flat, Light on Bass

reviewText: Overall I like these headphones, but I they are not what I expected.  Many of the customer reviews online (not Sony's description) mentioned how amazing they are at sound isolation--like not being able to hear someone speaking right in front of you, or hearing music while you play acoustic drums even.  I was shopping for headphones specifically for use with an electronic drum kit so that I hear all the drum sounds and music tracks over the thumps and stick hits on the pads.  The customer reviews were BS.  These phones have essentially no noise isolation at all.  If I crank up the music to the point of getting an immediate headache, sure, then I don't hear my stick hits on the pads or the base pedal movement, but that's not isolation.  That's just drowning out ambient sound, which any $10 pair of headphones can do.  My in-ear buds do better at noise isolation than these over-ear phones that cost 4x as much.  With my iPod or laptop playing through them, I can still hear my girlfriend talk or my phone ring with only minimal dampening of the outside sound.  Even with them blasting, I can still hear my stick hits on the high-hat pad and swing of my cheap kick pedal.  I don't want to have to damage my hearing just to hear all the elements of a track without the manual noise.The construction quality and sound production are great, but it doesn't meet my specific needs.  I didn't need a hi-fi set just for listening to music, so overall I regret going with this set at this price.Good points are cool-factor, quality build, great sound. One truth in the customer reviews is that you start to hear elements in songs that you never noticed before--even in your favorite records you've heard dozens of times.  Pretty comfortable too, but for drumming they get hot  & sweaty quickly.  One negative is the weight of the coiled cord.  Can't really prop it out of the way b/c the weight of it plus the coil pulls it back.  I'm glad it feels sturdy and well made, but the cord gets in the way while I'm drumming no matter how I try to position it going to the drum module.Sony MDR-V6 Monitor Series Headphones with CCAW Voice Coil

I spent a long time researching headphones. I truely appreciate quality sound, but I'm cheap so I didn't want to spend a lot. Well, for under $100 these headphones couldn't be any better. Absolute clarity with incredible richness and punch. I love these headphones!!!

I've owned or borrowed many budget headphones. Some of the following that I can remember off the top of my head are:Audio-Technica M35Koss PortaproNoontech ZoroSennheiser HD280Panasonic HTX7and more. All of them were in the $40~$90 range, but they don't come close to the sound quality of the MDR-V6.The bass is punchy but not overbearing and the treble is appropriately loud. Overall it gives a relaxing mellow sound. Perfect for those who listen to lots of ballads, pop/modern-pop, most rocks, and breakbeat style music.It's still great for other genres like rap and hip-hop but the bass may get slightly overpowered for those so you may have to mess with the equalizer in your music player to listen to them.The build quality is great as well as since the earcups and the band connecting them are sturdy and can take unprecedented abuse. I've read some other user reviews stating that they've use this headphone for 10+ years and it's still going strong.However, it's not a perfect headphone. The three (minor) downsides I've found are:-Headphone needs a little breaking-in as it was uncomfortable to wear for long periods of time for the first 4~5 days.-Not ideal for outside use because of the coiled cords. When coiled the cord is 2~2.5ft but when stretched it can go from 6~7ft.-I've read some reviews that the stock faux leather earpads will deteriorate in 3~4 years. Replacing the stock earpads will cost you $10. Or you can be like me and ditch the stock earpads and buy a better, longer lasting earpad like this for $20 and not have that problem in the first place:B0016MF7W2Those minor problems are overshadowed by its strengths however. Overall the sound that's projected is comparable to some headphones over the $100 range such as the Audio-Technica M50, entry level Shures, and Beats headphones. If there's a headphone that you think sounds better than this in the sub $100~150 range (other than its cousin the MDR-7506) notify me, because I have yet to find one.5/5.
summary: Best sub-$100 headphones I've ever tried.

reviewText: I've owned both and there is no comparison. First off, this is a truly great pair of headphones in the $70-$120 range. They have a very flat frequency response which means the lows, mids and highs pretty much get equal billing. This is fine for me. Because they were made more for studio monitoring rather than casual listening, some might feel they are lacking at the low end, but I think they just represent the music more faithfully. If you need to adjust the bass up higher, then go for it. They can handle it, and much better than the MDR-V600's which produce boomy low quality bass. The low frequencies on these are much tighter and more defined. Middle frequencies on these are great as well. Little to no coloring, vocals come through great. Middle frequencies on the 600's are pretty awful. It's like someone turned the treble up to 11. I don't know how else to put it. The one criticism I have of these is the poor quality of the earpads. Not only do little black flakes of fake leather start to come off after moderate use, but they completely came apart at the inner seam on mine, exposing the foam inside. I know I'm not alone in experiencing this and quite frankly It's a little baffling why they have not addressed this issue in the 25+ years this model has been available. There are lots of options as far as replacement pads go, so despite that I would still highly recommend these on the basis of great sound quality.
summary: These are not the MDR-V600's, and that's a good thing.

reviewText: I bought these after reading over a hundred reviews for them, and I agree with the consensus that they deliver a flat, uncolored sound with tight, but not boomy, or overpowering bass. By the way, I've owned the Sony MDR-V600's for a couple of years now thinking they had replaced these, but they are actually more of a consumer model that seem to be comparable in terms of price and specifications, but are actually quite inferior to these in my opinion. These have been used by Musicians, studio engineers, and on air talent for 20 years now.
Worst piece of junk I ever ordered from Amazon.had them 2 weeks used then 4 or 5 times.the right side stopped working.no loose wires I could find.don't easy your money!!!

I purchased these after being well reviewed for using with an electronic drum kit. These headphones performed as described: excellently. The range captures all the sounds from the low bass to the high cymbals without issue, and blocks out a good amount of outside noise. The coiled cord is a bit weird to get used to at first, coming from using a set of headphones with a long cord that hit the ground, but once used to it I didn't give it a second though.Definitely recommended.

I'm a big (6'3" 200lb) guy with a big head and big ears and these are exceptionally comfortable.  Not too snug, not too loose; nice, soft earcups.  Sound quality is excellent; nothing tinny or poppy about the sound so far across any listening volume or tonal range.
They don't cancel the outside noise.

I have been a fan of Sony headphones for 20+ years now. I purchased a set of MDR V3s back in 1991 and I still have them today! The MDR V6 have a very open and transparent sound coupled with warm natural sounding bass! Also, the ear pads are replaceable available from Amazon!

I had some reservations after reading some of the reviews; however, after listening to the first song I was blown away. The quality has to be the finest I've ever owned - hands down. . I'm not sure what others were referring to, as far as comfort goes - they're very comfortable. These are definitely going on my Christmas gifting list this year.Pros:  Exceptional sound quality, reasonable price, nice packaging, good comfort, and excellent noise reduction.Cons: None so far.

I love hip-hop/Rap/R&B etc. These are great, and i know they'll just get better with time. I got them early too! & With a lot of research, i chose these over the Mdr-7506. For weeks i've been researching and debating (w/ myself) which headphones had 3 Features: (Plain n simple) (1)Sounds great (2)Lasts a long time & (3)Not too flashy. THESE between the MDR-7506, Audio Technica ATH-M50, Sennheiser HD-280 PRO, and the Shure SRH440. The others never lasted, while the MDR-V6 last for YEARS. Oh and yeah, i would never pay $300+ for headphones that could break easily(Beats), so PRICE was a big part of my decision.

I bought these to monitor vocals from a Sony M10 and boom mic during amateur filming, and to double as a portable set of cans for casual listening.When they first arrived I plugged them into my soundcard and listened for about an hour. I was satisfied but not thrilled the way that so many others have been. The V6's are legends but I didn't see what all the hype was about. I mean they sounded good for the price, but not to the degree I was anticipating. Bass is very good, treble is very sparkly and bright, but the mids are unacceptably recessed, and even at times sound hidden, or veiled. Treble was riddled with sibilance too, not good. Now, at home I typically listen to AD-700s which have incredible mid-range. Furthermore I understand that the V6's get better and better with burn-in. We shall see. At this point I was just meh about the V6's. Then I remembered what I really bought them for.I brought up some high-bitrate voice recordings that are stored on my PC. WOW. These cans have incredible detail. Very, very analytical. I auditioned almost everything in the low-end pro monitoring segment (i.e. Shure SRH440, ARK 8400, AT M40fs, etc. etc). For pure analytical work such as vocal tracking none come close except maybe the Shure's which are so bass shy that they are almost a non-consideration. So bottom line is if you are in the sub $100 segment for the same reasons as me then you want these. If you want JUST good phones for listening on a bus or in the library I'd get Audio Technica M40fs or M35 which are less power hungry, more comfy and have a slightly more engaging overall sound. But for a good multi-purpose headphone with no compromises in vocal detail and an impulse-buy price point these simply can't be beat, and after all these years.
summary: Good for listening, amazing for tracking

reviewText: This is a review for non/ semi-audiophiles and casual music listeners looking for the best deal headphones in this price range.These are classic headphones. Studios have been using them for years and EVERYONE in the music/ producing industry immediately recognizes these babies. And if you look for it, you can find them everywhere too.BUT, what if you're just in the market for some good music headphones? You're not an audiophile per se, but you do enjoy good sound.Well first of all, you have to understand these are "studio" headphones and the sound is "uncolored" and "flat". Yes the eq is flat. A lot of manufacturers "color" their headphones with extra warmth or bass. If you've owned Skullcandies, their sound is heavily bass emphasized. Same thing Beats by Dr. Dre, a very warm sound. The MDR-V6's don't have any of this extra coloration. Their purpose is to playback the natural, original sound of the recording. And in that regard, for the price, these CANNOT be beat. They have pristine clarity. And you will definitely find things in your music you have never heard before. The whole sound spectrum (bass, mids, treble) is perfectly represented. In other words, the quality of the sound is phenomenal, for any genre of music.So if you want to hear your songs naturally as they were recorded, stop no further and click "Buy Now".But what if you're more into bass-rich headphones, like Skullcandy. Or what if you were impressed with Beats by Dr. Dre or the Bose at the Best Buy sample booth. Those are warm headphones, and if you were expecting to find something similar to those at a fraction of the cost, these may not be for you. Sure the quality of sound of these Sony's is infinitely better than the Beats or Bose sets. But it is definitely not the same "type" of sound. The sound curves are completely different. Like I said before, the MDR-v6 is flat while the Beats and Bose are warm/ bass heavy.But do not waste your money on the Beats or the Bose. The sound might be impressive, but it really is cheap bloated bass. The MDR-V6, while it doesn't have as much impact or quantity, the bass is much more clear and tight. The quality is a million dollars better. Still, if you were looking for that warm type of sound (for hip hop and those sorts of genres, although the MDR-V6 do fine in ALL genres, some hip hop/ rap fans might prefer a more colored sound) you can find even BETTER headphones for the same price as the Sony's.There are plenty on the market, but a quick look on the Amazon top sellers and I found these.Sony XB500: $49 Amazon-Wonderful alternative to the Beats or Bose sets. Phenomenal bass and mids. Treble is also very present. No muddy/ bloated/ leaky bass like the Beats, but even more in quantity and impact.JVC HARX700: $54 Amazon (little bit more bass than 900)JVC HARX900: $60 Amazon (900 has a better soundstage i.e. better gaming/ movie headphone)Panasonic RP-HTF600: $33 Amazon (super budget)In-Ear Buds:The Klipsch Image S4: $79 Amazon-Similar sound spectrum to the Beats/ Bose except with a much better quality of sound. No muddy/ bloated/ leaky bass, but just as much in terms of quantity and impact.Brainwavz M2: $54 Amazon (similar sound signature)Meelectronics M6: $15 (super-super budget, only downside is the fit may not be for some/ takes getting used to)Those are my recommendations. Although ALL in ear headphones break after a few months/ years, which is something to keep in mind. Headphones tend to last much longer. In terms of durability, the MDR-V6 lasts decades according to many accounts.So if you are looking for the best quality sound for under $100, the Sony MDR-V6 is and has always been the KING!But if you are looking for a bass-heavy thumping set(the MDR-V6 do thump, but maybe not as much as the Beats you heard at the Best Buy display), if that's the case you might want to look for a more warmer sounding model (XB500 is my first choice recommendation- for $15 dollars cheaper too on Amazon)=====Note: if this is your first foray into the hi-fi audio world and these are your first headphones, you must realize that studio headphones like these are unforgiving to the source. Unforgiving means they will playback any and every single sound/ static in the source file. If you've downloaded most songs legally through itunes, you should be fine for the most part. But if some of the mp3s in your collection have been downloaded illegally, you might find that they sound significantly worse than before. Why? Because it might be of really low quality. The static noise and any other imperfections will be made apparent.I recommend you look into lossless audio formats like FLAC files. If you are using iTunes with an iPod/ iPhone, ALAC is the format you should use. ALAC files are much bigger, but are much higher quality than mp3. There is an option in iTunes to rip CD's with ALAC instead of mp3. You will notice the difference. Either that or make sure your mp3's are 320kb/s.Some headphones require an amp to pump out the best sound. These headphones don't require much to be driven. It works fine in just my iPhone. It's unnecessary but it would always benefit. But a better DAC would greatly improve the sound of a portable device/ laptop. If you are in the market for one, I'd recommend the Fiio E7. It's a portable amp/DAC combo. The sound difference is very noticeable. And it has a bass-boost EQ which is very good (don't put it at maximum though, it starts to distort a tiny bit there). It actually produces that "warmer" colored sound I was talking about before. So this could be a solution if you don't mind spending another $89. But if you're willing to spend that much in total ~$150. The Audio Technica M50 might be a better deal? Well, that's a tough question. But my personal preference still goes to the MDR-V6.

When I started a new job that required me to move from a sound-proofed private office to a cube, an audiophile friend recommended these headphones. I've been using them now for several months, and they are by far the best pair of headphones I've ever owned. They're well-built, comfortable, and possess an excellent range. I find that I can wear these headphones for far longer than many other models I've used in the past (I guess you would call this less "ear-fatigue").My only frustration? I realized after a few weeks of use that my workplace is noisy enough to require noise-cancelling headphones. However, I won't fault Sony for that since I deliberately did not purchase a noise-cancelling model. They still sound great.One more thing: I can't guarantee that this will happen with you, but I actually received my headphones from Amazon the day after I purchased them—even though I did normal delivery. (It obviously depends on luck in regards to where you're located and where they're shipping from.)
summary: Professional quality headphones for an average joe price

reviewText: I have been searching for headphones for over a year now and got these MDR-6's in the mail today and I am already hooked.  I imagine they will be even better once I get them broken in.  For the cost these headphones are unbeatable.  There are better headphones out there but they cost at least 200 dollars more than the MDR-6's.  Unless you are working in a professional studio and need top of the line, these headphones are awesome.  They have been around for over 20 years and people still love them...I think that says something.  If you are looking for studio headphones for a good price...these are UNBEATABLE!!!
Best thing to sit on my head. Ever. Deep bass and sweet tweeting treble and after hours of listening, my ears feel fine.mike
These classsic head phones have a solid flat response excellent for mixing.  also very comfortable for extended periods of use.

Great headphones.....they work well with Ipod, computers, stereos...basically everything.....amazing sound....quite comfortable although sometimes a bit hot....highly recommend these....only downside is that they aren't nearly as Stylish as many other closed headphones out there, and no noise reduction.Mike, Toronto, Ontario

I went in to Fry's looking for a $15 set of headphones that were on sale for half off, but the sales rep steered me towards the SONY MDR-V6 headphones instead, advising that in the under $100 price range that they were hands down the best of what they carried and were constantly sold out. I wondered if this was due to exceptional quality (or just because they push those on anyone looking).I've only been using the headphones for a few hours now and must say I am initially blown away. I have listened to 2 CD's that I just listened to yesterday and had decided to get rid of as I really didn't care for them. Suddenly, listening to them again (because they were nearby) I don't want them to end and have decided to keep the discs. It's pretty amazing when a pair of headphones can completely change your mind about music you really didn't care for originally! I know the headphones will sound even better once they burn in a little, so can't wait to hear how these can possibly get better!I have a pair of Roc Nation Aviator Black headphones from Skullcandy at home that I really liked. I have not compared them side by side as of yet, but would rate these close if not equal to those at this point.I will have to update my review after using these for awhile.

I was browsing Amazon for replacment pads for my MDR-V6 headphones when I was prompted that I had already purchased these headphones 7 years ago. So I decided to review them now. First, this is my second set of MDR-V6 headphones. The first pair I purchased in 1986. 26 years ago and I still have them. They still work and I only bought the second set because I stepped on my first set and it is taped together. Definately not for outside use. But hey, after 26 years on my first set and 7 on my second set with super-heavy use these are the best cans at any price. They sound great, they are light and comfy and are durable. They will take some time to "burn-in" but once they do they will sound great, a tad "bright" but great. They also take a sick amount of power! I have used both pairs to the extreme and they never once blew. Sometimes I just crank my stereo through these headphones and use them as speakers without fear of them blowing.

I have only owned these for a short time so I cannot comment on the longitivity questions others have brought up, but the sound quality is outstanding. I am using them for both casual music listening while working on the computer and sound editing with FC Pro. They work almost too well at times...can't hear anything else around you.
summary: Simply wonderful....best price/performance I have seen

reviewText: This Sony brand, MDR-V6 headset model has been time tested by professionals for a score of years. Even with all of the post-modern digital upgrades to various media playing sources, this headset is professional grade, it's so versatile.One of the great benefits of buying the new but older model is that the cost is much lower than newer models; however, the quality of sound is exquisite. I use mine for both academic digital video sound monitoring while I am filming since the jack is standard size and fits right into my JVC digital camcorders.But, inside my home, I can also plug this headset right into the jack of my television and have the equivalent of surround sound without anyone but me hearing it since the ear covers cover my entire ear and are very well cushioned for both comfort and blocking in the sound I want and blocking out the sound I don't want to hear.By the way, even amazon sellers sell inexpensive extensions to fit universal size headset plugs so that an individual can walk a whole house while listening. You can't do that with cordless headsets that go out of range~
summary: One of the great benefits of buying the new but older model is ...

reviewText: First, the sound emanating from these headphones is simply wonderful.  They are not boomy, but have clean and tight bass as well as crisp highs, and everything in between sounds equally as nice.  The cord coils nicely and doesn't tangle, entering the left side of the headset and with a very nice strain relief at the plug on the other end.The "funky mechanics" that I refer to are related to collapsing the headset and the adjustment of the headband.  The headband adjustment will not maintain position and slips while putting on or taking off the headphones.  I also find myself being (overly?) careful when collapsing/expanding the headphones, but maybe that's just my paranoia considering the cost.The sound quality is without par in any headphones I have ever had and I would definitely buy another pair IF these don't fall apart mechanically within the next couple of years.

These headphones sound really GREAT! Compared to Grado SR-60i and Philips SHP2700Great bass, great details... not too demanding about the source.Can be used as portables - great sound isolation... only the cable is pretty heavy. But I like the cable (coil) and threaded 6.3 mm plug adapter.The only drawback is that the hard cover over the driver inside the can (either metal or plastic), is not too deep ... at least for my ears or head. Therefore first hour is quite comfortable, second is pain in the ear, and third one... I did not try, too much pain of the ears.I'd love them if only cavities for ears were deeper.PROS: great sound, great looks, folded design, threaded adapterCONS: no comfort / pain after longer use
He says these are classics and will always be perfect for his sound work needs.  He hopes these will always be available.
summary: My son is more than pleased with these headphones

reviewText: These are the headphones my program director swears by. I had a pair in the past but one of the other DJs I worked with broke them. I knew I wanted another set of the same ones but went the refurbished route to save some cash. They're like brand new and I'm totally happy with my purchase.

Purchased these before deployment to Desert Storm in 1990. They were in almost constant use all summer as they were loaned out when I wasn't using them. I don't give these the TLC they deserve, my kids use and abuse them. They've been carried around in duffle bags and backpacks with no case. Had to replace the ear pads with some microfiber-style ones from Sweetwater. They do sound great. Will not hesitate to buy another pair if this pair gives up the ghost. I paid something like $120 way back then.
summary: Owned for pair for over 20 years - nearly indestuctible.

reviewText: I've gone through a lot of different headphones, all I've loved for different reason but in the end I decided to stick with these. They don't do anything bad in my opinion. Also I'd recommend you buy the velvet ear pad's for them.

These headphones are amazing.  Metal construction, rich sound and very confortable.  I have been through Technics, skull candy, allen heath and panasonic headphones; by far these Sony's are the best.  Beautiful sound and a simple design that is sure to stand the test of time.These are perfect for a traveling Dj.  Headphones get tossed around and break easily, but these sonys are very sturdy.  Throw them in your bag and hop on the plane with confidence that they will emerge unscathed.
summary: Metal construction - great for traveling Djs!

reviewText: I bought these to use while playing our digital piano. I first tried them out on a receiver and they sounded bad. I expected this from the comments here.I set the head phones down and played a pop station through them all night. The next day they sounded a lot better. They now sound great for the piano or recorded music.
These phones are really comfortable. I have flown overseas and worn them for hours at a time with no problem. They sound really good and for the price, I don't think you can beat em.
summary: Sweet sounding for a great price.

reviewText: I have owned these headphones for approximately seven (7) months.  The headphones were well treated, but developed extreme static and moments of no sound.  Apparently there is a short.  SONY's web site and 800 number are impossible for service.  DO NOT WASTE YOUR MONEY!

These are awesome. You can definitely notice a difference between these and cheap headphones. The bass on these is great. I looked into headphones alot when buying these, and people said they were the best avail. under $100.Buy these, you wont regret it.
summary: Best headphones I have ever owned!

reviewText: These headphones are clear and crisp.  They fit pretty snugly, so they stay put, even if you go out for a run.  My only gripe with them is that the metal part where the audio jack goes is so big and heavy that the sound will become distorted if the wire moves around too much (even as light as walking around with your iPod in your hand), but I'm guessing these weren't made to be moved around.

Best headphones I've ever used. The sound reproduction is perfect and destroys some of the $200+ headphones I've tried.The stock ear cushions started wearing out after a couple of years but they are easily replaced with the Beyerdynamic EDT250 ear cushions which provide better comfort and noise isolation.

I was a owner of the MDR V-6 headphones back when grunge was in its heyday.  I loved those headphones and they lasted me longer that any other headphone had since. They are very solidly constructed, with a strong cable and plug.  Sadly though, after about 6 years of use, I broke them due to too much commuting and sloppy handling during my college years.Since then I have tried Sennheiser, Bose and other brands but nothing truly rivaled the rock-steady sound that my Sony V-6 cans had put out.  I went through a phase where I was big into noise reduction and wasting batteries for uninterrupted sound, but not necessarily the best sound reproduction.  For me that has grown old now.  After breaking my last noise cancelling headphones on an international flight, I suffered with earbuds for a little awhile before looking for a replacement headphones.  Missing the MDR V-6's, I was hoping to find a used pair on EBay but much to my delight they are still sold on Amazon!I've been reunited with the MDR V-6 for about 6 weeks.  These headphones sound wonderful listening to atmospheric compositions with a lot of layers and production detail, a prime example being Type O Negative's October Rust.  There are no tinny sounds or odd echoes like I've experienced with other headphones.The V-6's also have a nice comfortable fit and do not leak much sound.Listening to hard-driving rock and metal, there is always enough space for all the instruments.  Nothing I've listened to sounds crammed together or too distant.  That is what I love most about these headphones.  The percussion is distinct and the guitars shred but leave space for the vocals.  The bass is persistent and clear but not overpowering using a normal/no EQ or loudness/digital amplification.  Albums sound the way the artists and producers intended.  Cross-channel effects sound wonderful too.  These headphones are the best substitute for a quality home stereo system.
summary: There's a reason they still make these.  Thank you Amazon!

reviewText: Pros:Great sound Clear, crisp, and bass is perfect not over saturated to the point where you cant hear the music.Cheap for its qualityBuild is solid and not very plasticy like othersNot tight on the head nor does it fall off from being too looseCons:I have encountered none

I wanna start off by saying that I did not get these through Amazon, they were bought straight from Sony. But what does that matter... These are incredible headphones. I have them paired up with the velour pads from B&H;, as well as the FiiO E7 headphone amp/dac. In my opinion, it is a match made in heaven. I always have these hooked up to my desktop, and I look forward to sitting down and using them each day. I do use them every day, and for many hours a day at that. When I was looking for headphones I wanted something that sounded flat, monitors. And this is exactly that, there is very little coloration in any audio. These have been amazing even before they broke in a few years back. I listen to many different genres of music, and different kinds of audio. Music wise, they belt out everything from Dubstep, to Classic rock, to metal, to 80's. All of which sound stunning, assuming the quality of the file is high enough. Listening to uncompressed classical music, or anything uncompressed is a dream. Anybody who watches ASMR videos would really appreciate these, crazy clarity and definition. Movies sound just as good on these bad boys. Games? No problem, everything from FPS, to racing, to RPG, to RTS all sound great... Really immerses you. Binaural audio is plain insane with these. Like I mentioned earlier, I wear these for many hours each day, and it is rare that they begin to make my ears sore, but when they do, i just adjust the position of them on my head a little or take a break from them. But overall comfort is great. I expect these to last many many many years as I treat them like a piece of china. I read lots of reviews of these before getting them that people have had them for upwards of 15 years. I want to buy 5 more pairs to cover me for life, they are just that great. I have yet to hear ANYTHING that compares. Then again I have yet to listen to really expensive audiophile cans, by like high end sennheisers, beyerdynamics, Audeze, AKG, or HiFiMAN. But when in comparison to anything sold by a brick and mortar retailer (as well as apple store) this kills everything. I never want to part with these.My apologies for the lack of direction or organization with my review, but it is late and I wanted to get my thoughts of it online for other people to see. Oh, and I have had these for 3-4 years, can't remember, and they are in as good of shape as when I got them
summary: Just a fantastic set of cans

reviewText: These are great headphones.  They are a little expensive, but the sound quality is great and I do not get a headache.

I originally purchased these headphones for my Medical Transcription course in order to be able to hear what was said crystal clear. It works amazingly for this and every other use. I listen to music from my ipod, computer, etc.  Songs I have listened to for years sound even better. I'm able to hear things in these songs I didn't even know were there. Just the right amount of bass/treble ratio make everything i listen to through these headphones awesome! When my family found out how good these were, they ordered 2 of them for christmas gifts and we're thinking about getting another pair for a spare. For the price, (not to say these headphones are cheap quality in any way at all)these are the best value i've ever seen.

Simply the best head phones for the money. Had them 20 years and they're still the best phones in my collection. Wish Sony would put such quality in their NC phones. Have a pair of MDR-NC8 and they are garbage.
summary: far out finally good hphones from Sony

reviewText: I've heard a lot of different headphones, some costing as much as $500. These headphones stack up well with anything there is out there. They are truly a pleasure to listen to. The only issue is comfort, but that was fixed with some $20 after market earpads. I've owned my V6s for around 5 years and they are still a go to in my headphone collection. These cans turned me onto audiophilia, and my collection has seriously grown. However, these will always have a special place in my heart. Yes there are better sounding headphones out there, but for $70 these things are unbeatable. I prefer these more expensive headphones like AudioTechnica ATH-M50s and every Beats by Dre model. These are perfect for hiphop and electronic music. The sub-bass is wonderfully overstated and vocals come through crystal clear. The soundstage isn't particularly large, but wide soundstages are elusive in headphones under $300. They have a nice monitor sound and can benefit from a USB DAC. Although, they are very easy to drive and sound wonderful with iPhones or iPods. Durability is the high point of these cans. I have beat the crap out of mine and they are still completely functional. I know they will be around for a long time. I can't recommend these headphones highly enough.

I'm not use to put 5 stars but this product deserve it.I was having before this one the SHURE SRH240 wich are really good and beautifuls headphones.The sound was very detailed too (maybe not enough bass but good anyway).But it broke in about a year, it became just mono because of poor quality of the plug.The plus MDR-V6:* Light & Strong* Adjustable pressure on the ears* Very very detailed sound, you can hear things you was not able before with other headphones* Flat frequency response, Bass Medium and Treble are perfectly audible at the same intensity* Perfect for monitoring* The jack plug looks robust and easy to fix if a problem occurs.* The jack plug is naturally a 3.5mm and you can screw a half inch (provided of course!)* The package and the design.Minus:* Coil cable, even if it's convenient, I use it also to listen to music in my everyday life and that's not really convenient (but for studio it's perfect)* I don't have large hear but if you have large or long hear, those headphones are a little bit tight.I really recommend those headphones with an excellent ration Quality/price !!
summary: Very Detailed sound , light but strong product

reviewText: I received these headphones as a gift in 1985, 28 years later they are still used by me on a daily basis. I have had all of the earbuds that come with the iPod or iPhone, and those are great for just using phone etc. But when I want to listen to music at home I always reach for the Sony MDR V6 headphones. I have had the same problem as others with the ear pad cover disintegrating but that has not at all affected these headphones. Oh one other small problem thru the years was a cat chewing through the cord. So I had to cut out a small piece of cord and reattach it to the headphones. But even with that small tragedy still has the best sound I have heard in headphones.

Of course you can spend a ton of money on amps, DACs, and headphones. This pair of headphones will deliver 90% of the quality of super high end gear at about 10% of the cost.I also own the ATH M50 and I'd recommend the Sony MDR-V6 (unless you're into more bass heavy things). The Sony's are also more comfortable. They don't feel as sturdy, but they're very well built too.Unconditional recommendation.

I've been using my MDR-V6 headphones almost every day for the past month or so, and I really like them.  I listen to all kinds of music, and have been quite happy with the sound.I wasn't sure if my MP3 player (Sansa e280 w/ RockBox) would have enough power to drive them, but I've had no issue with the volume or sound quality.For on ear headphones, they are relatively comfortable.  The head band does not provide excessive pressure, but after a couple hours I am usually ready to give my ears a short break.  The ear pads are comfortable enough.I wasn't sure if I'd like the coiled cord, but after using it, I don't think I'd want to go back to a straight cord.  It's thicker than a straight cord, but it makes it easier to manage when I'm working at my desk.  The information card that came in the package proclaims that the coiled cord gives you an "action radius" of 3 meters.Overall, I am happy with the headphones, and I would buy them again.

We live in the age of online product reviews.  It's great to have some resource out there that helps us to make decisions.  But it's also exceedingly frustrating as things are never clear cut.  Especially when it comes to headphones it seems.  I spent a lot of time researching the options.  I wanted good sound for around $100.  It was the usual back and forth, "these are the best headphones ever" - these are the worst headphones ever, and uncomfortable.........."I finally decided on the Sony V6's.  Meanwhile, my wife knowing I wanted headphones went out and got me the Dre Solo Beats for Christmas.  I have to say, they looked great, had nice little touches, but the sound was not good.  Bass was way to pumped up and the rest of the music sounded stifled.  I apologized to my wife, thanked her for the thought and returned the Beats.I now have my first choice in the V6's and they're everything I wanted.  Great clear sound with plenty of bass.  It is true that you'll want to listen to your favorite music all over again.  They also seem comfortable enough and I have a big head.  Audiophiles can squabble and I'm sure there are better sounding headphones at some top end price point but these have truly remarkable sound.  You can stop pouring over the reviews and just get these.
Unlike headphones intended for listening to mixed music, which often over emphasize low end response, these headphones provide a well balanced response for mixing music accurately.
summary: Excellent flat response for accurate mixing.

reviewText: After eight years, it was time to replace my old Sony headphones. Instead of buying some newly designed headphones, I decided to go with the vintage/respected Sony MDR-V6 model. I'm glad I did! The sound is nice and crisp with good response throughout. They could be a tad bit more comfortable, but I think I'm just grieving the loss of my old headphones... I'll get used to these.*Separate note: The seller that I bought these from (through Amazon third party --- initials E.E.) was terrible. The shipping was slow (not "express" ;) ) and when I finally got the package... there was A CLUMP OF HAIR attached to the headphones. Not just a strand... a CLUMP! It was disgusting. A few deep breaths and a half a can of Lysol later, and it's all good.

I am not in the music industry but when I'm listening to music, I appreciate the lyrics more than the rhythm. I suppose I like storytelling. I purchased these because of the high reviews. I am tired of replacing headphones and have never spent more than $30 for a pair. I feel like the lightbulb was turned on. I'm currently listening to Bob Marley and I can hear all of the nuances of the whole recording. Listening to music has a new meaning with these headphones. I am one happy customer.
summary: I can finally understand the words!!!

reviewText: 2nd pair I've owned! They last forever, sound great, and are very affordable. Can cause ear fatigue on your sixth or seventh hour of continuous use. All the delicate parts are metal instead of brittle plastic like most other phones.
summary: Best head phones for the money!

reviewText: I used these every day for a semester and then used them occasionally from that point forward. They still look and feel new (granted I baby them) and after they broke in, they only sounded better. Many friends who try them love them and half go out and buy themselves a pair. Monitor the price--these fluctuate like CRAZY!Edit: I'm here 25 months later and these things are still serving me so well. They age so well.

My last pair of these headphones I had lasted me 15 years! I was a on air radio dj and these cans never let me down. Crisp highs, clear mid range, the right amount of bass. These headphones are light weight and do not squeeze your head. I highly recommend these headphones!

I paid upper 70s on sale a couple of months ago. I think it's 10 to 15 less now.  They're worth $70 so if they've dropped in price then they're definitely worth it. Sound is good for digital stereo, but won't compare to a surround sound headphone. If all you need is stereo you won't be disappointed.

If you ask my hubby I know he would say this is the best gift I ever gave him.  He drives a truck and when he is getting loaded or unloaded he spends alot of time on the docks.  These headphones take out a done of the back round noises so he can listed to his MP3 player or do work on the laptop!
summary: Best gift I gave to hubby!

reviewText: Reviewed many brands, went back to Sony.  This model has some slight problem of being tight on headband for extended listening so I manually spread it a bit. Done carefully it eases it for current use but headband goes back to original so anyone with smaller head would still be comfortable (my head is large). Didn't need the pivot feature but chose the MDR-6 for the range of sound and it is really good for the classical, Celtic, folk and old Pop I like - full range from low to high even good on tin whistle and uillean pipe music. So good I don't even notice the tinnitus background that's with me constantly and can really enjoy the music, even at low volume. This headphone really does mute the external sounds without adding white noise.

These are the first studio quality monitor headphones that I have owned (I have listened to a few others, but have not owned others). I am thoroughly satisfied with the purchase! They sound great, are easily portable, and fairly comfortable. My producer friends are jealous!
summary: Great Headphones at a Great Price

reviewText: I bought these headphones back in June, and to be honest all headphones/ear buds have paled in comparison.
