might want to change out the ear cups to something a little more comfortable, but that's only a small complaint. sound quality is great after the initial break-in and i'm considering buying another few pairs before they stop making these bad boys

I've been using these headphones in the office for over a year. The build and quality is very high.I also found that the padded headband and large over the ear design makes them very comfortable to wear for extended periods of time.Sound isolation is just what I require in the office, at low volume the environment is just noticeable and a small increase in volume drowns out all other noise (so you can work in peace).I work in close proximity to other people and the sound of the music in the headphones does not reach them when hearing at a decent volume which is another reason I chose the Sony MDR-V6 headphones.All in all I find them to be great value for money and would recommend to anyone interested in good quality headphones under 100$
I got this new product and within a month the left ear sound went bad. Thank God the warranty is still valid

These are the second pair of stereo monitor headphones I've bought from Sony in 6 years. These are also the second pair that have just stopped working. Even buying them at a lower price on Amazon doesn't make up for the frustration and wasted money anymore.I work in radio production, and good headphones are a required part of my every day job. Only half the time is spent out in the field, but my phones aren't used roughly. They sit on my head or on my desk.The first pair cut out after 2 years. Sound just stopped coming in the left side, then very soon after the right side. I tried calling, e-mailing and chatting Sony's customer service for support. And the only answer is exactly what you find online to begin with - send them in to their qualified technicians, and if I'm lucky you'll only pay them half of what I initially paid for parts, labor and shipping. Unless it's covered under warranty - the first pair weren't after a year. (Next time I'll buy the extended warranty). In order to even submit the claim, I'd have to provide my credit card number so they could charge immediately if deemed not covered by warranty or manufacturer's defect ...So I bought another pair. These ones didn't even make it out in the field. Kept them inside at my laptop for 6 months before they died. Only half the frequencies come in on both sides. I've tested them on multiple devices from PCs, and Macs to MP3 players. Cleaned the jack, the input, stretched the coil .. basic stuff. Nothing. After trying 5 times to reach a real human in Sony's Customer Service over the phone or online, I finally got one of their botchats. After 30 minutes of pulling at straws to get a helpful answer, I was told to send it in so their technicians can take a look an determine. Oh, and make sure to include my credit card number. Included shipping, I could be paying up to as much as I paid on Amazon for a new pair through Sony. What's the point?

The left cup failed working about a month after purchase. I took the plug apart and I found that the soldering was very poor quality. I fixed it and now it works. Beware: the cord is very long, very bulky, very heavy. You can carry the headphones around, but not without some inconvenience.

And they haven't had to change them a bit. The headband is worn smooth through the pleather on the inside, but unlike the earcups, it isn't all sticky and flaky. To fix the earcups, yank them off and go in there with some rubbing alcohol and clean up the goop and put a new set on. I personally prefer the Beyerdynamic EDT 250 replacement pads (yes, they cost more than replacements from Sony, but so worth it for comfort.). Nice cozy velour, and it didn't diminish the bass response.I have several sets of other headphones, ranging in to the high end tier (>$1000), but I still have desire to hold on to these.
this headphones are amazing, the sound is really good and the quality of the product is excellent, this headphones are really comfortable, and it didn't weight too much.
The sound is definitely as good or better than the beats by Dr. Dre. They are lightweight but sturdy. Completely transformed my workout!
This product is really great... its worth the money.. Most importantly its very comfortable that you can wear it all day long

After a lot of cross referencing between the V6 and V600 headphones I decided to go with the V6s. At first listen I was very disappointed in my decision and even considered sending the headphones back. They were extremely "tinny" sounding and had almost no bass response whatsoever. For lack of having any other headphone option I continued to use them to play video games on my computer (straight jacked into the sound card)for about a week... then on a whim one night plugged them into my mp3 player which 1.) has higher fidelity music on it and 2.) had an EQ already setup (i later figured out id had the default computer set to flat)... my mouth dropped open in the first 5 seconds of "The Pot" by Tool.I literally got chills as the bass came in and I had to sit down for the rest of the song. I have never heard my music sound like these headphones make them sound before. Another week of playing on my mp3 player and they sounded orders of magnitude better when jacked into my computer... then i checked the EQ for the onboard sound and set it up like the mp3 player - bliss.These are the best Sony headphones I've ever owned ... and that's saying a lot as I've had at least one representative from every style in price ranges from $20 to $150.The headband is comfortable on my size 7 3/4 noggin and I've had no trouble wearing them for 4+ hours at a time (in a warm room they do make your head get a little hot though). They sit lightly on your head and exert a small amount of pressure around your ears.All in all I join everyone else in highly recommending these cans - especially for the price at Amazon. They sound twice as good, cost about the same, are less conspicuous, and fold unlike then my old Sony XD-400s (one of the kittens ate the cord)... I'll definitely be rebuying another set if the need ever arises.
This was a great purchase. The clarity of sound is wonderful.I think these sound better than Bose. I do recommend this product

I got these for my husband for Christmas, so he could hear his youtube videos, while we were watching tv. Too much sound competition going on around here. Now all is peaceful!  They really do cancel out background noise. We can't hear him, he can't hear us!  I've tried them myself, and it's like a real concert. Of course the headphone sound is only as good as the video or music you are listening to! ;)

I got these based on a recommendation.  I purchased these headphones for use with my church praise band and their Hearback personal monitor system.  With these headphones I can hear all of the nuances of our group whether it's the keys or vocals or even the acoustic guitar - all of this while playing my Roland electronic drum set.  At home they are really great for listening to music through your PC since the 1/4" adaptor can be removed to use the mini-plug.A MINOR con might be that they can be hot after a while of wearing them.  But keep in mind that I play the drums while wearing these - so I am not just sitting still listening to music.  Back to the plus-side of these MDR-V6's would be that they can fold up for storage in a compact bag provided by Sony.  They are also built very solid.  It appears that most of the parts are metal, not plastic which can break or feel cheap.  They are very comfortable for over-the-ear design with the adjustable band to match your head size.

There is static sound at the point where the plug meets the cord when it is moved a little. I returned it for a replacement and the second one is exactly the same. It seems there is a problem with this model.

I was looking at about 10 different headphones and somehow through extensive comparison of specs, reviews, and articles I ended up with this one.  I have only been listening to these for two hours now but they only keep getting better and better. Crystal clear sound quality from bass to mids to highs.  Fit very comfortably on your head tight enough to stay in place but not where they pinch your ears.  Great noise isolation.  Unless you want to spend a couple hundred dollars on a set of top shelf can's you will walk away with this purchase in pure euphoria. No buyers remorse whatsoever.
the sound is amazing, good solid feel when you wear them. i am extremely happy with these headphones. much better than i thought they were going to be
Use these in my studio and they work great!  Can pump a lot of volume through these without them distorting.

I'm was so sick of earbuds, that I treated myself to these headphones. Only had them a week but I've already realized what I've been missing.  The only issue I had was that on the iMac, there was no easy way of switching between built in speakers and headphones when the headphones were plugged into the headphone jack.  Solution was to get a USB adapter (from an old pair of logitechs) and now I can easily switch by a single click on the menu bar.  Highly recommended, and I'm seriously considering a second pair to use in work.

These are very comfortable headphones, and the sound is natural and deep. Construction seems to be of good quality. I enjoy using these when computer gaming and listening to music.Purchased 1/13/07 through Amazon, I started having my ears shocked at the end of December. It was noticed during Unreal Tournament 3. I thought at first it was a sound driver problem, but after checking it on a home stereo, it also caused the shocks, only much less.I hadn't realized it was a year, so when I contacted Sony today (1/14/08) I found I was a day late for paid labor service. Since they don't offer repair of these anymore, it would cost me fifty-eight plus shipping to get another model. Even if it was within a year, it would have been forty -four plus shipping. I paid about seventy.I'll never buy Sony products again with this kind of support.
summary: Good, but defective within 1 year; bad Sony support

reviewText: mdr-v6's are the only ones you'll need. service was prompt and without hassle of any kind. love the product, you should buy a pair right now!

What I wanted: full-range, uncolored headphones.  My intention was to use for monitoring in the recording studio and for silent bass guitar practice.  I noticed that the TV studio where I work used Sony 7506's.  I discovered that the MDR-V6 are nearly identical.  I ordered them and A-B them with the 7506 only to discover that I could not tell the difference.  Both were excellent.Which brings me to audio quality.  They are sonically invisible.  I put them on and suddenly, by the resonance of the kick drum, I can hear the shape of the room Bonnie Raitt's drummer was in when he recorded I Will Not Be Broken.  These headphones are full, flat, uncolored and clear.  They're perfect for what I want--to hear as faithfully as possible.I have owned these headphones for just over a year and I've used them almost every day.  No wear or mechanical problems to report.

U bought these headphones for a Christmas gift for my father to use with his iPhone.  The headphones arrived very quickly and in time for the holiday.  My father was very happy with them!  The sound is great!

If you pay attention to televised radio shows or recordiing studios you will notice that artist and DJ alike all where these headphones. Why, simply put they are the best. The sound quality and comfort are heads above any other headphones I have ever used.
summary: The best headphone you can purchase

reviewText: I bought these many years ago at Circuit City for audio listening. I remember putting them on in the store and being really impressed. I damaged them, hence the duct tape holding one speaker to the curled frame, and will replace the foam cup. However, I still use them regularly, listening primarily to either jazz vocals, funk, or a movie, and believe me, besides looking ghetto, they still sound pristine with a rich sound. They are comfortable, block out plenty of exterior sound, and remind me of old school quality where stuff you bought lasted. My only complaint - they are not wireless.
summary: 2 decades old, duct-taped togethr, but still sound great

reviewText: These are great headphones!I work in the music industry and for the price point, I would rather buy these versus any of the higher price Sony MDR models.

I have been using these headphones for only a few days. I can tell you that these headphones do sound great but for some reason require me to turn the volume really high to get sound out of them. This might just be how monitor headphones are though. But I wouldn't really know. Now on to the review. I plugged these into my Bose companion speakers and had to turn the volume more than halfway to get the normal amount of sound that I usually get from a regular pair of headphones. Now I know what you are thinking. This guy must be deaf if he has turn the volume that loud to hear something. But thats just not the case. Now I tried watching videos on youtube and listening to music on the computer and the volume was really low on them with volume turned up halfway on my Bose Companion Speakers. I also plugged these into to my Sony Walkman X Series to test the sound quality. I had to turn the volume all the way up to 19 to get surround sound. Now with the EX earbuds that came bundled with my walkman I only need to turn the volume up to 11 or 12 to get the same surround sound. Note that the volume limit on my walkman is only 30. So for me to have turn the volume up to 19 with the Sony MDR-V6 its already passed the AVS Limit which is the safe volume for listening to music. Like other reviews have stated before the headphones are extremely sensitive. This was especially noticeable to me when the volume on my walkman was 12 or below. The sound from the left and right side of the earpads would keep changing when I was walking around with it especially when the coil came in contact with something else. I was able to solve this problem though by turning the volume up to 19 on my walkman. The headphones them self are really light weight and comfortable to wear. The headphone cord itself is heavier than the pair of headphones. I would recommend these headphones if you were to just sit in one place and listen to them. But not if you are constantly moving around with them.
Works just how you want them too. Made to be good studio headphone monitors, and they are. Mine have one cosmetic problem but not a big deal.
Really love the sound quality and comfort of the headphones.  They fit well and feel comfortable even hours after putting them on.

No question about it, no headphone is better than Sony MDR V6 in my opinion. Just got mine today, and am simply awed by the fantastic build quality, sound and ESPECIALLY price of these cans. If the hundreds of great product reviews already written about these headsets aren't enough for you, take my word for it.. you will in no way be disappointed by these. $70???? are you kidding me? Its nuts, i would have easily payed over a $100 for these. Without knowing much about this product, I risked buying them, and am so glad i did, you will be to

It was worth the expensive cost too when one factors in the nice sound quality, leak proofing and the durability itself. The coil wire helps prevent snags and wire pulling. I recommend this product for anyone looking to not have to buy a new pair of headphones for a good while.
summary: I bought this product for durability

reviewText: After years of using mediocre headphones for god knows why (ok, because my car was/is my favorite place to listen to music), I finally decided it was time to buy something legit. I figured I'd have to spend at least $150. But after doing a little research, these seemed like a great gamble at $70. I was most definitely not disappointed.Background: No, I did not sample a ton of comparable headphones. My research said it was this, or Audio Technica ATH-M50s I wanted (http://www.amazon.com/Audio-Technica-ATH-M50-Professional-Monitor-Headphones/dp/B000P62ND6). I had seen enough favorable reviews of these to decide to save the $80 bucks and give them a try. While I didn't listen to a ton of comparable models (just being honest), I did listen to a friend's pair of Sennheiser open headphones, that retail for around $500, connected to an external amp and DAC, with FLAC audio. So, I think I at least sampled what the top end could be.While that was great, it was ultimately not what I was purchasing for. Open headphones sound amazing, but this purchase was for use at work, shutting out the rest of the world. On the positive side, I've ended up using them at home on weekends listening to music just for enjoyment. Additionally, I don't have a vast collection of lossless audio, or vinyl I listen to. Mostly spotify  at 320kbps, and stuff I have in iTunes.As far as music I listen to with them, it ranges from a ton of house/EDM, classical, and then everything in between. Largely those first two though, since I find lyrics distracting for getting work done.Anyway, the background info is just to let you know how I use them and what my expectations were, so if your requirements are different, you can take my review with a grain of salt.For listening to music from digital sources, without a separate amp, with the goal of closing out the world, these headphones sound fantastic, and at a great price. The performance per dollar is about as high as I can imagine you'll ever find, since the next step up is likely twice the price. Also, they do a great job of not letting sound out. I can be listening to music pretty much at an 11 on the loudness scale, and someone sitting next to me wouldn't know.Final thing, just be aware, these are NOT portables. The headphones themselves wouldn't be a huge issue, but the cord is long and heavy. This is a good thing, but not for walking around town or being on a subway, etc. For what it's worth, I recently purchased Apple's new earpods for that purpose for $30, and I'd also highly recommend those at the price point. Much more comfortable than the classic white Apple earbuds, and dramatically better sound.

sony's earphone headphone are usually heavily tuned, or heavily colored. but this is not the case for mdr V-6. after 5 years of use, it still remain one of the best ear phones i ever had.however. the ear cushions can easily be worn out (maybe because i have eye glasses?) I can't find a replacement. any ideas?
summary: one of the best earphones i have ever owned

reviewText: I was skeptical at first when I put these on.  They did feel a bit uncomfortable.  I'm used to using the kinda phones that stick into your ear canal and attach directly to your brain.  At first, these felt a bit hot as if I were wearing earmuffs.  Also, since I wear glasses, it bugged me having these giant ear-covers pressing them into the sides of my head.It's been a week or so, and I'm really, really glad I stuck with them.  They block out a good bit of noise at my office for not being of the noise-canceling variety, and the sound quality is really, really amazing.  I have netflix going on one monitor while I write code on the other, and I swear it sounds as though I'm sitting in front of my 60-inch TV at home rather than wearing headphones.  Also, I no longer feel the discomfort I originally felt.  Either I got used to it, or the headphones emit a sound signal that has brainwashed me into believing I don't feel it anymore.  Either way, I'm happy with the purchase.Yeah.  Five stars.  Looking forward to using these wonderful headphones for the next ten (or more?) years.

Bought mine in 09. Months later the ear cups are "shedding their skin" and they fall off very easily. This is not the Sony quality I am used to. It does sound great but man these cups are horrible.After all these months if I could return it I would

Beats everything I've tried under 200$ music listening and sound monitoring on location (I am a videographer). Though not all mp3 players can benefit from such an impressive frequency range. For example my ipod's frequency response is just 20-20,000Hz.

I don't have any complaints on the headphones, sound quality is superb and they can 'fold' to be carried.The only thing that I don't like but expected is that the cable is way to long. It is not an issue when playing an instrument, but it can be if you have an mp3 player.Another thing that I don't like and DIDNT expected is that the 'folding' mechanism is not straightforward. The headphones come with a manual and you are supossed to unfold both earcups at the same time which is frustrating as it is very difficult or impossible. I hope not following this instructions wont led to any serious issues because I wont.I will buy this again if I lost them.
I needed headphone that would not break the bank and sounded great at the same time.Pros:Sound greatpriceCons:a bit unconformable after some time. ( thinking of buying aftermarket cups)
summary: Quality headset for a minor price.

reviewText: Ken Rockwell's review convinced me to try these MDR-V6's to replace my worn out headphones. They are really accurate in reproducing sound while I edit video and even work great with my iPhone. They're not built like tanks, so I feel I need to baby them a little, especially out in the field while shooting video.

After reading many positive reviews of this item on the Internet, my expectations were high.  I have a pair of el cheapo Sony phones that came with a portable CD player and I was surprised by the quality of these very inexpensive phones.  Not that they are audiophile quality by any means, but they are listenable and good for the price.So, needless to say, based upon previous experience with these Sony products, I was expecting a very good sounding set of phones.  But when I heard these phones I couldn't believe it.  It was like trying to listen to fingernails scatching on a blackboard.  They were a little down in the lower midrange but the high's were thin, tinny and harsh sounding.  They also consistently introduced distortion in the higher spectrum above 7000 to 8000 hertz.I listened to these phones with a variety of input sources.  Even with the highest quality CD's played though my Denon and Keocera receivers they continued to be unlistenable.  I would much rather listen to the el cheapo $20 set of Sonys.I read reveiws of these phones from some calling themselves audiophiles and even one or two so-called "recording engineers".  How anyone who knows what music is supposed to sound like could give these phones even a decent rating is beyond me.  I have been a musician for over 45 years and have spent countless hours in recording studios (I also have a home studio).  I feel like I know what music is supposed to sound like and I want some headphones that at least make a good representation of it.  But trust me, these don't even come anywhere near accurately reproducing music.Sony should be ashamed for even putting these on the market and representing them as high quality monitor phones.

They sound just the way I want headphones to sound, balanced and detailed. Of course their design predates the current mobile-music era, so the long coiled cord and the thick plug aren't made for mobile phones in cases in your pocket. But I think I can work around that for this sound.

I honestly don't know a whole lot about electronics, especially things like music equipment. I bought these for my husband after researching studio headphones for hours. After reading countless positive reviews from people who said they have owned theirs for years, and even one guy who said he uses it in a professional setting for a television show I think, they sounded like a winner.I wanted to get headphones that would allow my husband to mix and have an accurate sound when he can't use speakers. He knows a lot about technical things and he loves them. They have a pretty accurate sound and are very flat. Of course nothing beats using proper studio speakers but if you can't use speakers for whatever reason, these headphones would be a great alternative.

I bought my first pair of Sony MDR-V6 headphones in 1999 while in College. I probably wear them 4-5 hours a day on average (often more), and I have never had anything other than mild discomfort.I was tired of bringing them back and forth to work, so I bought a 2nd pair to leave on my desk at work a few years ago.The earpads do tend to start flaking apart and the foam breaks down after a few years, but replacement pads can be found for cheap ($5 for 2 pairs last time I bought some).They are extremely comfortable. Audio reproduction is professional quality in a consumer-level budget.  If you ever watch "behind the scenes" videos of movie or audio production, you are almost guaranteed to see a couple sets of these headphones.
summary: My original pair from 1999 are still going strong!

reviewText: These headphones are great. They sound amazing, they are comfortable, and pretty sturdy. The only complaints I have about them are the cord length (its hard to use with a mp3 player, but that's to be expected, they are studio headphones), and my head feels a little sore if i wear them for more then an hour or so straight because they put a little pressure on my head.Overall the verdict is: Amazing, especially for the price.

I bought these as a gift. Compared to my 30year old MDR-V6 pair, the ~18 foot coiled cord is the same; perhaps the new ones are a bit more bassy but I'm not sure. I put new earpads on my old pair and it's pretty hard to tell which pair of headphones is which! I am telling you that if you invest in these they'll last you many years. Yes, the earpads wear out. Buy new ones at Suntekstore.com ($5) and move ahead. The sound quality shocks anyone who samples them and I feel confident that much of the music I hear was created with these on the engineer's head. The wire has never worn out. I carry them to/from the office and nothing has worn out but the bag. Someday I may own Sennheiser but not as long as these are working, if then. I hate Sony, it's the only thing I ever plan to buy from them.
summary: Same they were 30 years ago but less money

reviewText: Great product I use for every day use as well as for Djing.For the price u can't go wrong .

I've had these headphones since nov.2011. Before it's arrival, I've always settled to using cheap earplugs. It did the job (i'm no audiophile), but i had been severely pining for over-ear headphones for the longest time then. Now, I absolutely love using it every chance i can get. It's nearly borderline abusive that i wear them while commuting on foot/car/bus/train. Having these on long flights and lengthy road trips is an excellent escape to an isolated music-listening heaven.A friend recommended buying replacement pads for when the original pads begin to deteriorate, or just replace it all-together with the Beyerdynamic set as it reduces sweating. I'll probably get to those when my pair wears out then.Without question, I would buy this same set again if the need arises.
Whether you're an audiophile or a casual music enthusiast, I guarantee you will not regret buying these headphones. There are simply no faults.
I knew I was getting something neat just by looking at the brand and all the possitive reviews. These headphones rule, they feel very durable and the sound is just great.

Did you hear that? no...then you clearly don't have these! Joke aside, these are wonderful and clear as day when listening to any form of music by Headhunterz(bass/kick) or the Eagles(epic crisp guitar). No need to get expensive headphone into the hundreds when these are right here. I have worked with a few friends of mine in the Norway/east Europe techno circuit and these are the on the go top rated headphones for when the melody starts nocking in your head and you need to get it into the computer as fast as you can with as much clarity as you can. Personally I would rate these from home hobby to professional produces(as a travel or monitoring aspect) and leave the real high ends for live studio(over $150k-1m). So in short, you get these and your mix comes alive with terrible sounds that your old headphones missed...which in the by the end of the day will sound crisp and colorful thanks to Sony's MDR-V6s.
summary: From home to million dollar studio, you can't go wrong with these! Crisp and clear!

reviewText: This is the first review I've written here but I had to share how great these are. I had a cheap pair of Koss UR40 which were falling apart and everyone near me could listen to whatever I was playing. Wow what a difference in sound quality! For the price these headphones feel sturdy like they could last years of wear and tear and again the sound is simply beautiful. I'm just sitting on my couch listening to my itunes library enjoying all the fine nuances that I've been missing with my old headphones. I would highly recommend this product.

It was absolutely right to refer the reviews. This headphone with 20 years history by SONY was brilliant and reliable one. I and my friend are so happy with this, it was the best headphone that we have ever had!!!!!
summary: the best headphone I have ever had!

reviewText: At this late date I don't have much to add to many of the great preceding reviews. I have a set of Bose headphones with which I listen mostly to music when working at my desk/computer and a Sony MDRV6 (mainly for when I am watching TV) that I have had for nearly 7 years and it is still going strong; that is why I purchased this second set - and the price was too attractive to ignore.Throughout the years I could not tell any difference in sound quality or clarity; and since rap music is not to my musical taste, I have no issue with the "bass" notes as stated by other reviewers.

I first bought these for myself and found them to be really great.  They are very comfortable to use and are almost totally noise cancelling.  They were so good that I bought them as presents for family members.
for the money, these are almost impossibly excellent monitor headphones with full dynamic range and rich sound.  you will hear... Everything.
summary: best budget monitor headphones available, period

reviewText: Was looking for an alternative to buds and researching old school headphones . This product seemed like a quality starter and apt for just tuning anything online. For your PC these are a great alternative.  Sound is good , comfort good , bit heavy.  The ear pad came completely off after 3 weeks use and need nimble fingers to replace. It came off again a few days later.  I do not recommend the purchase unfortunately beacause of this specific lack of quality construction.

Pros: These phones have an amazing high frequency response, and they make excellent reference headphones. Music sounds good, TV shows and movies sound GREAT, and video games sound completely 3-dimensional. The over-ear cushions are comfortable inside.Cons: The headband and earcups have a grip like a vice! Both earcups always want to come together completely. Fresh out of the box they could clamp two pieces of paper together.  I stretched them out for a while (on the box they came in) and it reduced the pressure to a comfortable level, but they still want to meet together all the way.  Also, the hinges continually fold up when I don't want them to.  The coil cord makes itself dangle from my PC's headphone jack, so I have to weight it to the desk.  Sonically, my only complaint is that certain bass frequencies will distort if you boost them with an EQ.Other thoughts:  I tested these phones with a lot of albums that I know and love and continually noticed new things.  When my friend wanted to try them, I told him to put on something that he is familiar with.  As soon as he put them on he independently said the same thing, that he heard stuff he never heard before.I have not had any problems with the high impedance of these phones, even though I measured the DC resistance of mine at 74 ohms.  They're still loud and trebly with an ipod nano.  On my PC I keep the volume at 10 out of 100.I would recommend buying these headphones for general usage rather than specifically for listening to music.  That's not to say that you won't be constantly listening to music with them, because they do sound spectacular, but the most valuable function of these is to serve as a reference.
summary: Excellent reference sound, but not the perfect pair of headphones

reviewText: Crystal clear sound.amazing sensitivity.The design is such that most of the external noises are blocked out.These are easily the best headphones that I have ever used and they last for ages.

This is my first "big headphones" purchase (im talking big in size here)I tend to favor the high end earbuds for running/biking/hiking/flying etc. I have a set of Shure SE530PTHs which are absolutely phenomenal! However the Sony V6s are simply more rugged and have the freq response 5hz-30khz that the Shures dont have - some of my media requires the wider freq response. They are also more comfortable for super-long listening periods. These stay at home, the Shures go adventuring with me. 5 stars across the board for these and for the cost - can't be beat. I have not tried the "very similar" competition from Sony, but based my decision to buy the V6 based on all the reviews on here. I am very pleased.

Though I'm content with ipod earphones, I decided to upgrade to higher quality sounds and try headphones.The first headphones I owned were ATH-M50 and will use those as a comparison.I wanted to love ATH-M50 (twice the price 125$), they did sound good, easy on the bass +:D BUT WERE THE MOST UNCOMFORTABLE HEADPHONES. The top band of ATH-M50 tries really hard to pierce the top center of your head. :{MDRV6 for half the price has good, clear sounding audio, easy on the bass, and is really really comfortable.Good value for its quality audio.

Are you kidding me? These are nice. I did alot of research and admittidly, these did not have the most universally poitive reviews in the sub-$100 bracket. I have a big head and these feel like a feather on me. Especially compared to my Logitech G-35 gamers. Which are not comfortable at all. The sound on these are clear and crisp. There on my head now and I actually had forgotten for a few minutes. My biggest concern was they would hurt and they dont at all. I love the cord. The fold up feature is nice and they sit compact on my desk (unlike the G-35's). I have not tried any other "cans" so my experience is obviously limited and the group has some other highly rated headphones. The grado sr-60/80; AT ad700; and the 555's all get good reviews. Good luck chosing if you have to. These are very nice imo.

The 3 things that all great headphones have in common are: Durability; Sound Quality; Comfort.1) DURABILITY:  This may very well be the most important factor of headphones.  By definition, headphones are meant to be portable.  Everyone at one time or another has thrown their headphones into a backpack or laptop case.  Headphones generally need to be replaced only when they break or get misplaced.  The MDR-V6 are just about the most durable things I've ever seen.  It's classic Sony construction.  Mostly made of metal and thick in the vulnerable parts, these are built to last.  In addition, they collapse to a nice compact shape further enhancing portability and durability.  The coiled cord is also designed to last.  Think telephone cord.  So unless you have a pet who insists on chewing things, the cord will never be the reason you replace these.  Finally, they come with a bag for even more durability.  If you are even considering the Bose Triports, slap yourself sober now.  I can snap the Triports with 2 fingers.2) SOUND QUALITY:  The Sony Digital Line of headphones have been the standard for audio clarity for decades.  So if you're jaded by past experiences with non-Digital Line of Sony headphones, don't be.  These are on par with the newer High-Definition line of Sony Headphones.  Digital sound by nature is tinny.  But these headphones give equal clarity and attention to the low and mid frequencies.  I often listen to classical music, and woodwinds, bass and percussions glisten through these headphones.  I also use these for Hip-Hop, Rock, Pop, Jazz and everything under the sun except country.  These headphones excel across all genres.  Now with the obligatory comparison to the Bose Triports.  With Bose Triports, I have to REALLY exert myself to isolate instruments and sounds.  The MDR-V6 isolate sounds for you.  You can just sit back and enjoy the show.  In addition, Bose Triports sound like your listening underwater when compared to the MDR-V6s.  Once again, 1/2 the price, more than 2x the performance.  MDR-V6s dominate this category.3) COMFORT: These are on-the-ear heaphones.  NOT around-the-ear.  These require careful placement on your ears.  For maximum comfort, place as much of the pad directly on the fattest parts of your earlobe.  I know it sounds counter-intuitive, but place them a bit forward on your ears.  If placed properly, these are as comfortable as any set of headphones I've ever owned.  I have a REALLY big head, and these headphones with a tight headband give me no problems on even 7 hour flights.  Like any on-the-ear headphones, you will need to move them around to discover what is most comfortable for you, but once you find your sweet spot, these are as comfortable as you will ever need.Forget bang-for-the-buck.  These are great headphones no matter what price range your consider.  Sennheuser, Audio-Technica, Bose, or whatever brand you are considering...stop right here and click "Add to Cart".  You won't be disappointed.

I just read at a message board about someone who was considering buying the V6. I couldn't believe Sony still makes these! After eight years, I also realized how annoying the disintegrating pad covers can be, but the  audio quality is superb...which is why I never replaced them. Now I know I  CAN replace them....with a new pair. They cover the ears without feeling  bulky, and they're very lightweight for the class they're in.Sony  speakers truly suck, but the V6 phones totally rock. Can't tell you the  number of hours spent playing QII till the wee hours of the morning with  these...
These are time tested phones that I feel shine in the rock genre. A healthy bass and clear highs bring out the bottom without clouding the top.

I bought a pair of these to be my 'go anywhere' headphones, since my other headphones are much more expensive and stay at home (Sennheiser HD595s), and I had heard that these are built like a tank.When I got these, that is the first thing I realized; They are built extremely well. It seems like they'd survive being thrown around in a bag or just generally used a lot. I personally know somebody who has had theirs for 10 years and they still work great!I've heard that the coating on the ear cups flakes off (Read other reviews). Not a big deal, you can get replacements.The sound quality on these is fantastic for all kinds of music. My other headphones (HD595s) sound slightly better if it is live music, piano music, jazz, etc. The V6s trounce the 595s when it comes to anything heavy at all (And I'm not talking super heavy here.)The only thing I found bad about these is the fact that they are listed as circumaural (Meaning they go all the way around your ears, not just rest on them), but really, they are kind of in between supraaural (sit on your ears) and circumaural. They block out sound decently well.If you need a great pair of headphones to take on the road or are just looking for a good pair of headphones that will last at home for probably an indefinite period of time, pick up a pair of these. The value is phenomenal!
summary: Probably one of the best values in headphones!

reviewText: These headphones were recommended to me by a friend, and his advice did not fail me.  They were exactly as advertised, and definitely one of my favorite headphones to date.  They have excellent sound, and conveniently buckle down in size for easy transportation.  They fit comfortably on the head and ears for several hours, and block outside noise a little too well.
summary: Exactly what I expected and more.

reviewText: I am an avid music listener and can definitely appreciate quality sound. I've used many different headphones, ear buds, etc. and the Sony MDR-V6 are by far the best I've ever owned. The sound is crystal clear, they are comfortable to wear and they fold up! After doing my research and reading countless reviews I decided to pull the trigger and go for it...I'm glad I did, these phones rock!

headphone jack is thick and sturdy; the telephone-style cord is unique and handy, I suppose; these headphones give off a more professional appearance than Bose over-ears or on-ears. They sound better than bose on-ears, they're more durable than over-ears. Good purchase.
summary: Arrives wrapped in velvet colored cloth 'nuff said

reviewText: These headphones are amazing for the price.... Obviously not the greatest headphones in the world, seeing as they are sub 100 dollars, but for the money, they are just about the best I have found so far.
Great value, you would usually pay a lot more for this level of fidelity. Durable, good design. They fold up well.

These are so much better than headset in their price range, they are a no-brainer. If you're a Beatz from Dre fan, obviously you don't really care about sound quality, so keep on moving. The reason the normals want these is because we're looking for great quality sound, under $100, that won't leak all over the room.The build quality is exemplary. There is metal all over this thing. When you compare it to the plastic stuff out there, they feel like toys. These are passive noise cancelling, but are super comfy and just completely seal you away from the world.I thought they were too big, and wanted to send them back. I tried to replace them with other headsets and eventually saw why there are 600+ reviews, mostly positive.Just buy them, even to test the hype. You're probably going to be underwhelmed at first. Then compare them with all the other headphones in the price range you think will be better. You'll keep these, and probably add your own positive review.It's nice to know they are durable and will last a very long time. I love these things, full stop.
summary: I didn't love them at first, then I tried to replace them.

reviewText: This is my first pair of real headphones and I love them a lot. I was going to get the Grado SR-60i but I read they have very bad sound leaking and that turned me off. These have little to no sound leaking.

A few months ago I purchased these headphones to accompany my DJ setup.  Delivery was prompt and hassle-free.First off, the headband seems to be tilted forward a bit, making it seem a bit uncomfortably close to the forehead, but this turns out to be an excellent feature - when going one-cup, this forward tilt really makes it more comfortable. I'd give it a 5/5 for overall comfort, that headband issue included with other factors like ear cup comfort and just the right amount  of cling.In terms of sound, this set of headphones sounds GREAT - especially for the type of music I spin (house/techno), it delivers deep punching bass while maintaining excellent clarity throughout the mid-to-high ranges.  I can't really vouch for the headphone's native EQ tendencies (I'm always adjusting the EQ of each track while mixing) but I can say that these headphones, aside from their clarity and enjoyability, are benefited by that invisibility - the old analogy of a well-polished window to "see" your music clearly comes to mind.In terms of durability, I haven't really seen any real wear/tear issues - the only main thing I've noticed is the coiled cable getting a little looser but that's not much of a complaint.These headphones come in an attractive red velvety display box with a nice faux-leather pouch to keep/transport them in.  A screw-on 1/8" to 1/4" adapter is also included.Overall, a great set of headphones, hardly believable at the price of the 70 or so bucks.  I highly recommend to anyone, but especially DJs (although this is not marked under the "DJ" category) due to the ease of use, clarity, and (as far as I can see) durability.  Enjoy!
summary: Excellent headphones for a great price!

reviewText: These have to be the most amazing headphones for the price. Your mp3's and other digital music will never be the same after you have properly broken these in. As for comfort, they are soft and are pain free. I could wear them for hours. Bass response is excellent and the highs are crisp and clear. Buy these now!

pros: great sound, comfortable, closed headphones: when you put these puppies on you can't hear ANYTHING apart from the music, also it's hard for outside world to hear you even when you're rocking it.cons: i'm already on my 3rd pair because of the same problem: after about a half year of abuse (i.e shoving them in my backpack) one of the speakers stops working. for the life of me it happened with the first two i had. so i now bought mdr7506's which is basically the same but priced more (go figure). i think sony should make the v6's more tough though. throwing headphones into a backpack is a pretty important thing.

I bought these at $50 hoping for good quality sound output for some serious music. The first pair that I received had some issues with the audio jack though - sound was erratic, I could only hear through one ear and there would be static and I'd have to twist the audio jack around to ensure better sound. So, I contacted Amazon and was sent an immediate replacement. I was not disappointed. Sound quality is excellent in this one, so I put down the first one to a lemon.I did experience a dull ache on my ears after usage for an hour or so with the first piece that I received. Thankfully, the replacement seems a much better fit and doesn't cause any such problems for me. But, I can see that it might still be an issue for some with even bigger ears. If you are worried about comfort of the fit, perhaps there are better ones out there, but this one has very good output quality.

Let me start off by saying that I've owned quite a few pairs of headphones in my life, but none have been as good as this pair.The Sony MDR-V6s easily compete with headphones two to three times the price [they go for $70]. The sound quality, workmanship, and look are all top-notch, unlike the Bose Tri-Ports, which are only able to boast sound quality - and the Bose phones go for twice the price.I'll give a quick run-down of the look of the phones for anyone who's wondering what exactly they look like [images are scarce on the net]. Each can has large, soft cushions that circle around the ear [circumaural] and form a relatively air-tight seal that blocks out surrounding noises quite well. The cans have two joints each that allow them to be folded, facing each other, up under the headband that connects them for easy storage. The joints closest to the headband are made of both metal and plastic, which gives the cans a solid feel when you retract them. The cord, which is about a meter long unextended, comes away from the left can only, so you don't have to worry about tangled cords. The right can's wire loops through the headband to the left can.Above each can is a two-pronged arm that can swivel a few degrees left and right to fit every head shape. And above those, there are flat metal extensions, just like most headphones have, to adjust for your ear height [11 notches on each side].The last version of the V6s that were made are the ones you can get now, and they still have a great late-80s/early-90s look. Each can has a red and gold bar with text that says "for DIGITAL", and "Studio Monitor" is displayed on the top of the headstrap in silver lettering.I don't claim to be a headphone expert, but the sound produced by these headphones is certainly amazing. I was stunned when I heard the bass hitting solidly and accurately, as well as the crisp highs. Read some of the other reviews for a better description of the sound reproduction.All in all, the price for these phones is a bargain, especially since they're becoming rarer as stores sell the last of them. As of Feb of 2006, though, they're still available.

These headphones sound very good.  These headphones have exeptionally clear sound, especially for this price range.  These cans are easy to drive and don't let a lot of sound leak out or in.  If you are looking for a good pair of cans for a studio or just to listen in a noisy place, try these.

I just got these for home recording projects, and right out of the box, I love 'em. Good reproduction of sound...I'm hearing details that my old AudioTechnica cans missed. The fit seems fine for my lug head, despite a number of reviews that disparage that factor. I haven't worn them for three hours straight yet, but stick anything on your ears for that long and you're going to feel it. I can't talk about longevity yet, either, but so far, so good.

Pros -The audio is good once you burn it for 50+ hrs, the build looks solid that will last yearsCons -Heavy and uncomfortable. It presses hard on ears so you can't listen to for long time!I returned to to get more comfortable ones even though I got these ones at very good price 49$ from Amazon
summary: Sound good but uncomfortable for ears

reviewText: I recently found my original receipt for my first pair of MDR-V6 headphones. It's from 1988. These headphones have been through a lot. The ear pads wore out quickly, many years ago, so I bought replacements from Sony for way too much money ($45) at the time. Then one of the kids left them on the floor and the dog chewed them up (just the ear pads). I saved them in a drawer for a few years and suffered with some MDR-V600 (suck) headphones until I read a review one day about some softer earpads made by a competing company that also fit the V6's. $20 later, I've resurrected my V6's and am once again listening to true sound, rich bass, without the muddiness you get from the V600s.I liked them so much, I bought a second pair for home so I don't have to truck my work pair back and forth.You cannot go wrong with these. Durable, clear, well made, excellent sound reproduction. Not many products are built this well; way to go, Sony.

I'm no audiophile, but I have been an amateur musician for the last 30 years. These headphones are an excellent choice for the price. Comfortable fit, brilliant highs, booming lows and middy mids - also very good ambient noise blocking. Even with no input I have to take them off to have a conversation. Overall - just another really great product from Sony. You can get much better cans than these, but not at this price.
summary: Sony delivers at a great price

reviewText: The sound is good and cord is long enough.  Much more comfortable than buds.  Works well with i-Pod and laptop.
summary: My son likes it and he is musically very demanding.

reviewText: I wanted some nice portable cans that were closed and sounded good for about 100 bucks. You really can't beat these, very light and comfortable and sound terrific! I heard you won't find these in stores in the USA so I picked em up from Amazon! Couldn't be happier, beware of imitations...buy from a reputable vendor like Amazon. Take note of the box that they come in, these DO NOT come in a plain white box.
I would highly recommend these headphones, they are one of the only pairs I have ever owned that do not give me headaches, even after several hours of use.

These headphones are OK but the bass is a little underwhelming. Great for music like Michael Buble or some Sonatra, but don't really give you the right sound for "modern music." I have to hand it to Amazon though, they got to my house in less than a day and I didn't even get expedited shipping

This is the consumer version of Sony's professional MDR-7506 phones, widely used in the film and broadcast industry, which are standard issue at the radio station where I work. Due to the shallow ear cups, I find them uncomfortable after about two hours. But they are rugged, compact when folded, and the coiled cord is tops.However, I've never been content with their sound. The high end is exaggerated. This can be useful for location recording, as it accentuates hiss and other unwanted noises. However, I can't recommend mixing with these because it's hard not to overcompensate for their inherent brightness, and the strong high frequencies quickly induce listening fatigue. These phones have been in production for two decades, but I preferred their little brother, the discontinued 7504 model, which had a more balanced sound. That said, I haven't yet found a good, affordable alternative to the MDR-7506 (a.k.a MDR-V6).As others have noted, the only difference between the V6 and 7506 is a gold-plated plug adapter, the length of the warranty, and whether the stickers on the ear cups are marked "Professional" or not.
summary: The industry standard (for better or worse)

reviewText: The quality is what you would expect of Sony, consistent and well made. I also am a Bose enthusiast, but I was impressed with all the specs on the Sony Digital headset, so I thought I would give them a try.  I was not let down, they fit good, comfort is good and the sound quality is very good.

Audio engineering masterpiece! Sound quality rivals top of the line Sennheiser. Not only did Consumer Reports magazine give this model as #1 on the list when it first came out way back, but CR also gave the headphones a checkmark denoting exceptional quality! Relatively inexpensive for the audiophile dream-come-true masterpiece...I'd pay hundreds of dollars more for this baby if I had to!!!!!

I purchased my Sony MDR-V6 headphones in my very early teens (if not earlier) after reading a review in Stereo Review (I believe).  Since then, they've gotten tons of use and I've seen them everywhere.  I've gone through 3 or 4 cords over the years and they're finally falling apart.  I  wanted another pair but settled (ha!) on MDRV600's, which are very muddy -  all mids.  They're going back today to Best Buy and I'm getting a new set  of V6's from here -- I can't believe Sony has kept this model alive so  long.  These are incredible 'phones.  Trust me.

Got these in the mail, they were comfy out of the box. I bought the velour padding as others had suggested (which was a risk for $20), but totally worth it. Now they fit perfectly and they might as well be noise canceling. BUT: if you buy the padding, don't waste time trying to figure out the installation yourself. Just follow the very simple and dead-accurate instructions here:http://www.amazon.com/review/R2NMQ2X44EXIPH/ref=cm_cr_dp_title?ie=UTF8&ASIN;=B0016MF7W2&nodeID;=172282&store;=electronics
summary: Comfortable, solid, get the velour padding

reviewText: I used to use a set of these headphones back when I did some minor video production work, and was always impressed by their full range and sound quality.  I am not an audiophile, nor will I act like an expert in sound quality, but I am very pleased with these headphones.  I have been plodding along with some old Koss headphones on my gaming rig, and they were clearly at the end of their long life.  I have a nice little 5.1 surround setup for my computer to play games with, but when the wife goes to bed, I have to plug in the ear cans.  Going from all of the glorious booms and rumbles I get with the sub attached to my 5.1 system to the lack luster sound of my old headphones was jarring.  Well I can say that this is no longer a problem with these Sony headphones.  These produce a full range of sound that makes me forget I am wearing headphones instead of listening to my full speaker set.  Not overpowering on the low end, and not too tinty on the high.  As for the comfort on the head, some have said they dislike them, but I have no complaints.  I wear glasses, which can be problematic for extended periods of time with some headphones, but so far, these don't bother me at all, even after 3-4 hours of continuous wear.  If anything, the only problem I have with these, is that they block out the sound so well around me, that I can't hear when my wife comes into the room.  She was trying to talk to me the other night, and I had no idea she was speaking, which may get me in trouble one of these days.

I have a set of Sennheiser 590 headphones and I must say these do have more detail and clarity. They are very comfortable to wear. I highly recommend them. They are also very efficient (doesn't take a lot of power to drive them). I bought the Beyerdynamic EDT 250 Velour ear cushions to put on them, and did they make a difference. Very comfortable.
great, professional earphonesjust what I was looking for to get quality sound while mixing and working in the studio

I have had these headphones since about 1987.  I can't think of one other piece of electronics that I still own and use.  The bass on these are so phenomenal, but it's not overpowering.  You hear every piece of every piece of music.  Highs are also excellent.  These are the one thing that sounded better than my ex-speakers (Klipsch KG-4's).  The only thing I have replaced is the ear coverings, themselves.  Otherwise, just as perfect as ever and very comfortable, to boot.  You'll love them if you buy them.

reviewerName: Steven H. Koenig "Music Journalist, Poet, Tea...
reviewText: (Note: Do not confuse these with the MDR-V600, with lower quality sound.) Any piece of audio equipment must be evaluated both for sound and for practicality within the intended environment of use.  I bought a second pair of these after losing one abroad, and later a third for fear something would happen to my pair and I wouldn't be able to acquire another - and these did seem to disappear from the market for a few years.  I always hated the idea of listening to music on the subway; I'd rather read or daydream or meet new people, but the rules changes when boomboxes came in.  Even with the advent of the personal players, one had to put up with the t-t-t-t-t and s-s-s-s of another's music.  I began to wear headphone in transit as a form of self-protection.These cans are closed-ear. They close out a great deal of the outside sound (these are not noise-cancelling 'phones, mind you) while also preventing your music from harassing others.  Nearly no sound leakage while the -V6 is on your ears, even at overly high volumes.  Sound quality: not as great as the best of some high-end 'phones, but for outdoor purposes these are more than worth the price.  They are totally comfortable; I've worn them over 10 hours on international flight with no discomfort.  I can tell a real piano from electronic keyboards on 70s dance records on these, and human voices have natural timbres. They handle equally well orchestral, chamber, punk, vocal and jazz.  They also have a solid build; previous models I'd bought from Sony could not handle anything more than delicate use: wires tore, plastic pieces snapped off.  My current pair of -V6s have handled rough use for over three years.I highly recommend these if my descriptions fit your uses for a pair of headphones. I also use these to audition portable players; the salesman usually say they all sound alike; nonsense! (I rarely use headphones when at home, but these are way more than satisfactory; still, I'd always rather listen to a good pair of loudspeakers.)

Right out of the box the headphones sound clear and crisp. I do voice over and everything exceeded expectations. When I tweaked it with my equalizer I was blown away. Very comfy and plenty of slack. Would recommend!
summary: Great out of the box, but even better when tweaked!

reviewText: I use these headphones every night to watch movies on my tablet so I dont disturb my wife while shes sleeping. They sound great and for the price you cant beat them imo. comfortable for extended wearing and dont get too hot. The only negative criticism is the cord is curled and long and tends to get tangled easily. These might not be too good for headphones on the go.

After moving to Guam, I cannot find any decent Audio Store on this island! High-end audio store is out of the picture here! I decided to switch to computer-based music system and a pair of good headphone (fortunately, I am not addicted to high-end hype). By doing some homework, I found a very decently priced "Audirvana Plus" for AIFF playback. However, I still need a pair of decent headphone to complete my MacBookPro + Audirvana Plus music playback "system". Please believe me, you do not want to have too much $$$ stuff in your apartment/house on this island; otherwise, you may find them "all gone" when you go home! That is why I target on a pair of headphone less than $100.Again, going on the internet, doing some Google search, I found this Sony MDR-V6. OK, the following is my 1 week impression on MDR-V6...1. Fresh out of the box, it sounds a bit harsh, and I felt sound fatigue after about 30 minutes of continuous listening. But, this is not the "problem" at all.2. I ran in this headphone by playing music into it continuously for 3 days, and the sound is much better now! I am expecting it will keep improving after about 1 to 3 month(s) to have both drivers settled. (Will update about this part later).3. The sound of this headphone is like what they are designed for. Almost no coloration.Before writing this review, I saw two extreme ends of reviews. Most people were using this pair of headphone for years, and some reviews are cursing Sony MDR-V6... The story may (very likely) be that Sony has discontinued this headphone in Japan, and the replaced model is MDR-CD900ST (V6 was the CD600ST). In Japan, all V6's are actually  "imported"! Sony actually moved the original production line of V6 to China, and later, to Thailand. Since I only own this headphone for one week, I really are not in the position to judge the QA of V6. Mine V6 is printed "Made in Thailand" on the box. Maybe few years later; if I still remember this review, I could provide more info about how long does mine V6 live.

Based on the reviews thought I'd give this babe a try and boy have I been impressed!  I tried them with my iphone 3 and they sounded good. But, when I lost my iphone, I used my 30GB Zune player that I got from my daughter as she got an Ipod and then I turned on the EQ setting. Man, I heard sounds I never heard before from a stereo or headphones!!  The bass was awesome and I could hear the words much better!! Words I never knew what the singer was singing!!  So folks, it depends on your player for some awesome sounding bass.  I'm not sure if there is EQ app for iphone, but I will check when I get my replacement in a couple of months or some other phone if there is an EQ on the phone (doubt it, though may be surprised).  There ear pad on my left ear hurt a little at first after a little while but I adjusted the head band so it took most of the weight on top of my head and that worked.  Good luck in finding your headphones!  I found my babe.
These headphones are great for editing audio and video, everything can be heard crystal clear and the fit is very snug and comfortable.
Love these studio headphones! Well worth the money. Don't use Beats By Dre for studio work. Amateurs...Arrived promptly, and all pretty and shiny and whatnot.

Hopefully these phones will improve with age but for now they reproduce mid and high end well but little bass response. The Onkyo receiver I have is a good one so source is not a problem. I find I have to leave my floor speakers on to have adequate bass which obviously defeats the purpose. Foolishly I didn't listen to them first somewhere. My mistake.
I got these about a year or so ago. They sound good and are comfortable but after a year the covers on the ear piece are falling apart and are not cheap to replace.
summary: They are OK but don't last long.

reviewText: I will never by another pair of headphones ever again...they are the best that i have ever used, and they get even better when you get the velour earpads..its a dream

wrong description these do not cover your ear completely. Also i would like to return them for a new pair or refund because the ear pads are falling apart at the seams, definitely a manufacturing defect, after very light use. Do not buy!
summary: wrong description, ear pads falling apart

reviewText: I was looking for an inexpensive set of cans to do the job...i found a near perfect combination of sound quailty, comfort and price.Nice cans Sony

I studied everything on the market, and shopped all around for the best product I could find.  I was told to look for the greatest frequency response on the market.  These headphones have a frequency response of 5 Hz - 30 kHz.  I found that I could have gotten a lower rated Hz, but at a cost of over $200.  That was not an acceptable price for my budget.These headphones are very comfortable, reasonably priced, have a longer cord than absolutely necessary, have adapters for different size plugs, and outstanding quality of sound.  What more do you want?  ;o)

The headphones work fine.  I've had two or three, and especially appreciated the folding feature in my work.But this time around, the pads are awful.They come off all the time, for no apparent reason except that it's usually the worst possible moment, and are hard to get back on.I'm not the only person who says this. I know because I looked up the model and something like "pads come off" on the Internet, looking for some kind of hint as to how to fix the problem without covering the pads with tape or something. What I found was a lot of complaints.I just lost one in the middle of an important recording session. I could buy an official Sony replacement on this site for nearly $9 (one single plastic pad, not even a set), but it will be a cold day in hell when I give Sony any more of my money if I have a choice. I chose a much cheaper replacement set from another company. They probably won't last long, but probably long enough for me to find another set of headphones. From now on I'm going with somebody else.Sony markets the mdr-v6 to people who want a reliable set of headphones that they can use on the job.  This silly problem undermines that effort.

Like many have written here I have had my MDR-V6s for more than 15 years. They are still in production (July 2008) in a market where product life is measured in months this is strong testimony.They are very comfortable on my wide head. I enjoy their "flat" frequency response. Not boomy on the bottom and a open extended high end.Over the years I have used them on a broad range of equipment from computers to portable cassette and CD players to professional audio/video  equipment. They have always performed well.The ear cushions have deteriorated and need replacing. I have not found a comfortable headphone whose ear pads didn't crumble over years of use.Mine came with the 1/4" plug adapter yet Amazon suggests you order it separately.These are the real deal - Enjoy!
summary: For Better Highs and Tighter Bottoms

reviewText: This headphone set is fantastic.I use it all the time and can't believe the sound quality sometimes.I wish I had bought this headphone set years ago because it would have reduced some stress for me.

Amazing quality for the value. Would have given it 5 stars but because of my personal preference of liking things a little bit more bassy. Again its not a design flaw on their part but more of a preference thing for me.

I really did not think these were up to the ratings that they got. The wife kept telling me to send them back, get something with better sound. i don't really believe in headphone burn in but about 20 hours into using these i found myself turning to her and saying, "Dear iI'm sure it's in my head but these sound different". My music tastes are all over the place except maybe classical. All i can say is glad i did not listen to her. An all around music headphone as far as I'm concerned.I mostly use an iPod classic. What do i hate? the coiled cord I'm always am always untangling it constantly. One of the earpieces fell off after 2 months you have to really pay attention how to put it back on. I actually ended up putting the headphone itself back together wrong and the headphone wore a bare spot in the wire. And last they sometimes want to fold up when i am trying to put them on my head. Wish you could lock them somehow. i have 20 children so they have seen their fair share of abuse, can't hear them yelling most of the time, and they can be loud. Giving these up now would be like giving up one of my children, and the headphones are better behaved.

Got these for my teen who is a budding musician. He says " These headphones have okay mids and amazing lows. They can hurt your ears after a few hours of use from squeezing but its not that bad. I use them for music production and music listening".He would recommend them.

These really were a fantastic purchase. Let me say that I rarely write reviews and that my attitude towards speakers and headphones in the past has been - meh, is it really such a big deal?Well, yes, it is. I'm sure many other people can more eloquently and technically describe why these are awesome. But to these untrained ears, these were a revelation. Everything sounds far, far better. I've used these with my Mac, iphone, ipod, and a super low quality MP3 player - music sounds great, as do TV shows and movies. These also work surprisingly well to block out exterior noise.I purchased the Sennheiser HD203 closed back headphones for work (they were around forty bucks I think) and these are worlds better.  I understand that those weren't top of the line Sennheisers - but they aren't even in the same ballpark in terms of quality of sound and ability to block out external noise.Highly, highly recommend these. Frankly - they are a great deal for the quality you get.
summary: Amazingly good sound even to the untrained ear.

reviewText: These are my first pair of nice headphones. I was using earbuds before I bought these.  The difference was amazing. For  example, I found that I can listen to music at a lower volume with more clarity.  They are very comfortable.  The bass is more defined, but not overbearing.  I have had them for almost 4 months now and they still look brand new even though I use them everyday.  I was concerned before I bought them about the ear pads wearing down.  Mine aren't ripped at all, and I have a 1 year old! I do not use these for professional use, just normal everyday computer and ipod.  :) Hope I helped.

These are great.  The quality of sound is great and because you can't hear  other noises, these headphones can take you away...into the song, into your  thoughts and memories. Like most mommy's I adore my little cuties...but it  is nice to take a break and listen to my music, practice Spanish or  whatever without hearing every peep that they make.  However, you do have  to keep them in your sight. Have you ever seen a fight between a 3 & 6  ?  Well it is a lot better than hearing it! You know that commercial,  Calgon take me away...well, I say headphones (and Marvin Gaye or Beethoven)  take me away...!
summary: These headphones block out the phone and noisy little people

reviewText: Like Going On A Carefree Vacation ! No Packing ! No Traveling ! Just Put On ! Tune In ! And Relax ! As Everything Fades Away ! No Vacationing From Your Vacation When You Get Back ! No Luggage To Lose ! No Brutal Baggage Handlers ! Savage Porters ! Nasty Bell Hops ! Just A Little Righteous Brothers ! John Denver's Voice So Rich(A Download !!!!) ! And Cosmic Hum ! All Awesome ! Thanks Amazon ! A Sony Sound Demo Was Like Actually Being There ! Shockingly Clear ! A Demo For Cheaper Headphones ! Accidently Played On Top Of Cosmic Hum ! So Awesome ! Love It ! Ear Buds ? Last Resort ! Thanks Again Amazon ! Best Choice Ever !

I have always wanted a pair of these headphones. I scoured the net for all the reviews of the Sony MDR-V6 and most reviewers highly recommended them. I now see (or hear) why! The sound range of these headphones are incredible. I want to listen to my favorite music all over again just to hear nuances I might have missed before. I also want to watch DVD movies for the solid thuds, explosions and sweeping highs! I feel as though I have my own private theater with expensive sound system! For the money and the quality these headphones are the 'best buy' I have made in quite awhile. For jogging, I am trying outSony MDRE828LP/SLV Lightweight Earbuds (Silver), which I am starting to really like also!
summary: Made me pull out all my favorite music!

reviewText: After reading all the five star reviews of these phones I had very high expectations for these to replace my broken, nearly fifteen year old JVC phones. After all these are Sony's and I've always had great respect for Sony products. I mean the accompanying pamphlet states they have samarium cobalt magnets with high flux density and 16 micron high-molecule film and copper-clad aluminum voice coil and all that kinda good stuff. These phones even look cool packaged so nicely in a red velvet-like "bed". So how could I go wrong?Well, something got lost between spec sheet and ear drum for me. I consider myself not only somewhat of a finicky audiophile but also a musician. I listen to all kinds of music from symphony to jazz to Sinatra and the Beatles to the percussion classics of the 1960's. I put these cans through the paces for two weeks before writing this review.On the plus side, these phones do a nice job of separating and clarifying certain instrumental sections of an orchestra/band. Bass and midrange reproduction is pretty good overall. Not terrific, but pretty good. If you are listening solely to modern recordings with the latest technology you will probably be pleased.But these phones just don't respect percussion, particularly the treble clef. The ching of a finger cymbal, or the sound of a ride cymbal or xylophone on older recordings are barely audible on these Sony's on many of the recordings I listened to. I had to make certain I wasn't losing my hearing and listened to these tracks on my regular stereo system just to reassure myself that those sounds are still alive and well. And folks, my ol' JVC's reproduced those sounds as clear as a bell.Well, maybe it's just me after all and not the phones. But I strongly suggest you do a "taste test" with these phones with your fav cd before laying down your hard earned bread on these phones. And I can't help but ask myself, "How much do I gotta spend to get the kind of phones I can live with?"All I can say at this point is: "Damn, I miss my JVC's!!"
These headphones are great for the price but IMO, if you save up little bit more money and you can get a much greater enjoyable pair like ATH-M50 or MDR-7510.

everything about these headphones is great the sound reproduction, the highs and the lows and most importantly the BASS while not to overpowering. one con though, the cord is a little bit long but that really isn't much of a con for me and at $80 it's definitely a pretty cheap price considering what you get quality wise

My daughter has been wanting some headphones for a while.  These seem to cancel out noise and bring in the music from all around.  I want to wear them for karaoke, because you can't even hear your own voice when singing, so you think you are in tune (the family tells me I was a little pitchy).
Excellent love the product.  It's so nice and clear crisp sound.  They get two thumbs up!! I would recommend them to everyone.

I've had these headphones for years and years and years.  They're small enough and fold compactly enough to take with me travelling, yet they feel substantial and not flimsy. The sound quality is great, although at loud volumes I've noticed a tiny bit of distortion, but just a tiny bit. There has been a little separation of the foam cover around the ears, revealing the foam underneath, but otherwise they're in great shape for headphones as old as these.At the time of this writing, I may have lost them in an intra-office move.  I'm hoping beyond hope that I find them, but if not, I know what I'm asking for for Christmas!!Update: I found them this morning buried in my daughter's stroller. I'm doing the happy dance!!(Oh, and BTW, I find these very comfortable. I wear them all day every day at work. Definitely much more comfortable for extended wear than your average earbuds.)
summary: Great headphones for almost any use

reviewText: You can hear a mosquito fart with these babys on. After looking at the reviews and seeing what people had to say compared to other headphones I feel like these are as good as it gets, and with the price reduction from $90 to $60 you really can't pass this up!
summary: Best headphones I have ever had

reviewText: I read and read and read the reviews on these and paid close attention to the comments on the tightness of the headphones. Nearly everyone says that the sound quality is so fantastic that it makes up for the uncomfortableness. I decided to go ahead and purchase them. Got them about 10 hours ago. While the sound is truly fantastic and getting better with every hour played (That break-in time suggested is definitely true.) the tightness on my ears is not making me happy. I'm a woman and do not have a big head or ears, in my opinion, and these phones are almost as uncomfortable as my  previous pair of [...] Sony V150s. I'm trying to ignore it and hoping it gets more tolerable, but so far no. Even within a few minutes my ears start itching from the tightness.I am boycotting Bose for their ridiculously inflated prices, but my mom has a pair of the Bose QuietComfort 3 Acoustic Noise Cancelling Headphones, and I LOVE them! [...] though. Yikes! I'm contemplating the Bose Triports I've been testing every time I go to Target. They are light as a feather and the sound seemed good from the demos. However, all reviews complain of the quality of the build on the headband. I don't want to pay [...] just to have the phones fall apart in a few months.So, in my continuing quest I found some reviews on the V6 that mention replacing the pads with a velour pad from Beyerdynamic. The reviews on the difference in comfort are quite convincing. I'm buying these immediately and will report back my findings. [...]All in all, I just wanted to write my review for anyone else that may be waffling on the comfort issue. Many say the sound is so good that it's worth the discomfort. Not for me. Comfort is a huge part of enjoying my time listening to music. I'm not an audiophile either though, so maybe it is worth it for those that can tell the difference in every type of sound. The sound in these is pretty awesome though. A couple of raw recorded songs that I was listening to with talking at the end actually caused me to jump because I thought someone was right behind me. I hope the replacement pads work because the sound quality is excellent, especially at this price.2/8/08 - The pads help some but they still pinch my ears a bit. I found that taking out the middle foam section actually helps give my ear more room to hang out in there, but...... I actually went out and bought the Bose Triports, and while the comfort level was much better, the sound quality compared to the Sony's doesn't even compare, especially if you enjoy bass.
