reviewText: OMG,what a pair of head phones.they are astounding sounding.I have the 7506"s and I will not even try to pick which is the best.they both blow my mind.Where have they been all my life?

I'm going to try to mention the parts that you may not have read about for these cans.First of all, the sound quality is fantastic, if not somewhat heavy on the bass.  If you like a little deeper bass in your tunes, these pull it off amazingly.  I have the Senn 595's as well, and they are great sounding headphones, but sometimes I prefer the sony's because they have that extra punch in them.  Just be aware, if you don't like a lot of bass, look elsewhere.  These will not beat you over the head with bass, but I'm saying that you should expect them to lean towards the low end, got it?I also purchased the beyerdynamic earpads that happen to fit this exact model by sony because I read great things about swapping the earpads (the achillies heel of these headphones).  Yes, it is another $20 investment, and yes, it was worth it tremendously!  The soft felt-like material is much more comfortable in the long run.  These cans now compete with my Senn's for comfort, but the Senns still come out on top...though I've got no complaints for either anymore!The only thing I really don't like about these are the wires that hang around in the open where the folding part happens to snag.  This causes that little wire to get caught in there when I collapse the headphones sometimes and I worry that it will one day break the wire somehow.  However, they have been holding up very well for at least few months (and I purchased them used from a buddy).For the pricetag of $70-$80, these are totally worth it!FYI I listen to rock/oldies mostly.

the sony MDR-V6 is amazing.  the deep base sound can be heard clearly while the whole melody is still there.  it is indeed the best pair of headphones I owned.  for the price your getting, it's a steal.  every other headphones that come close or might be slightly better would cost you more than a $100.so if you are a professional, or simply a person who enjoys great music, this product is for you.

First off, my initial impression of this headphone was astonishment. The build quality all the way down to the solid way the headphone clicks into place when you extend each side was superb. Also, the fit was very good, i am 5'11 with a muscular build, and they cover my ears fine.When i put them on, i immediately noticed how quiet everything was, even with music playing low volume, i couldn't even hear myself typing this review on my very loud razer blackwidow keyboard that clicks every time you strike a key.The V6 is an older design (more than 15 years old), and it shows. Persoanlly though, i like the design and the look. It's very different from the all-plastic designs common to other inexpensive Sony headphones. The headband is wrapped in pleather, with minimal padding. Length-adjustable metal strips attach the earpieces to the headband. The driver housings are of black metal, a plus. The cups are covered in crinkled pleather. The coiled cord is one meter long at rest, but extends to three, and attaches to the left earpiece. The plug is a mini; the 1/8" adapter (included) screws on, to prevent accidental extraction. Both plug and adapter are nickel plated, rather than gold like the more expensive MDR 7506 (basically the same headphone with different stickers, gold plating on the jack, and an extended warranty), which is the only visible sign of the V6's relatively low price bracket. The V6 folds, in the manner of some of Sony's other headphones; that is, the ear pieces swing up under the band, to form a more compact package. After this treatment the V6 fits into the black pleather bag it comes with.Since the range is so large (5hz-30khz) you can hear everything, including the distortion of not well leveled sound. But that's whey these were made for the studio, and not really for personal listening. i am really glad that whenever i download songs, i make sure they are 192kbps or above. You can really hear any subtle nuances of instruments in the backround which is really an added plus. So if you get these headphones, make sure your music files are up to par.I cannot believe that that these headphones are under 100, and even further disbelief that i did not buy these earlier, they are one of the best headphones i have ever put on. Forget beats, go oldschool and get these studio monitors.Okay, these arnt all perfect, by now, my ears are getting a bit warm (lack of ventilation) but i guess that comes with any over ear headphones. Also, with thourough research, i found that the padding flakes off (the leather isnt real) BUT they can be replaced for under 20 bucks. Another padding that fits is the padding of Beyer DT-250 headphones which some say are a bit more comfortable, but i like these fine. These V6's last a very very long time, and is a great investment. I highly suggest it, you wont regret it.Also, a friend told me to let these play for a couple hours on high volume to "break them in". She also has these but for me, they play fine righto out of the box.
summary: The best of the best, old school

reviewText: First off, I'm not an audiophile.  This will horrify some people, but I'm not all THAT picky when it comes to sound.  I'm happy listening to movies and TV through my TV's speakers (though to be fair, I always try to buy a TV with good sound).  I'm content with the headphones that come with my iPod-that sort of thing.So on the audio front, my opinion probably doesn't mean that much.  That said, I could instantly tell that the sound on these was far better than my iPod headphones.  It's as good as anything I can recall hearing.That's actually not why I bought these though.  I work in a very loud environment.  It seems to be over 70db, and I've long been concerned that it might be wrecking my hearing.  I've tried using the ear protection gear I wear while mowing, but it's just not comfortable for long periods.  I finally started wondering if a good pair of headphones that enclose your ears would help...And as it turns out, they do.  These cut a significant amount of noise out, to the point that I'm pretty sure they really are helpful for my hearing.  Not as much as the actual hearing protection stuff, but the difference in noise when I take them off after wearing them for a while is huge.I was also concerned about how comfortable these would be, given the mixed reviews in terms of comfort.  At least for me, these are very comfortable.  I've been wearing them every day, 8 hours a day, and have no complaints.  I can feel them if I think about it, but the cushioning is soft and comfortable, and to me they just feel like they're gripping my head lightly-not unlike how a hat feels, I guess.  (For the record, I wear glasses, and these don't interfere with them at all.)So at any rate, they seem very well built, they sound great to my ear, they're comfortable, and they seem to block a substantial amount of noise.  They're one of the few products that I can recommend wholeheartedly...Well, I guess just to nitpick, the size adjustments on the side don't always stay in the same spot from where they were when I took them off the previous day, but that's really no big deal.  They do HAVE size adjustments though, which is worth noting.  I have a big head-finding hats that fit is very, very hard, but these fit just fine, so I think they'd work for most people.
summary: Fantastic-exactly what I was hoping they would be

reviewText: Got these for a great deal on Black friday and I would definitely recommend these to anyone who enjoys music.Use these at work and the are awesome!

So yea i ordered these headphones while i was in afghanistan during my depoyment. I was trying to decide wether i would be like everyone else in my shops and try Monsters Beats By Dre or find something else. so i decided with the MDR-V6's after reading reviews about the V6 and V650's. and man was i ever as happy in afghanistan then than when i got these headphones. Audio orgasm commence.... just wonderful. sorry just a good time.... man i never know my music could sound so good. but yea.... i like these most people will like these. just my style with the telephone style cord. and i was the ass hat in the gym that had these on and was away from my music device leaving a 4 foot cord between myself and my machine waiting for people to trip over it.... sorry.

I bought Sony MDR-V6 headphones in 1987 and am now buying a new set. These have been fantastic headphones. No, I'm not a professional, just enjoy the great quality and sound reproduction these headphones offer. Also, like the long cord, great for movies and other applications. So glad to see this product still on the market.
summary: 24 years, ready for a new set

reviewText: I purchased two pair of these for my kids to use with their iTouch's. They had been using earbuds but the sound was not that great and they never stay in very well. These seem like they would be more at home in the home theater than with an iTouch but my kids say a lot of their friends have started using headphones instead of ear buds. These things sound better and are less expensive than all the competitive models i listened too. We also use them in the van for watching movies on longer trips. They are very comfortable because they fit over the ear and not on the ear.
Super high quality sound and for the price they can not be beaten.  My friends all agreed these were the best headphones they have ever listened to.

I'd been using terrible ear buds for the longest time simply because they were cheap, but when i moved into my dorm room for college, i realized i wasn't going to be able to use my epic speakers very often, so i needed some truly quality headphones. I had used beats and monster and Skullcandy from friends, and they all seemed to focus on skull-smashing bass. When i wanted to use them to listen to Vivaldi or Chopin or some other classical or romantic composer, or to the more synthy electronica, they all just fell flat. Before i gave up, i did some research and heard a lot of good things about these headphones and how they sported a very "Full" sound that had a respectable bass that didn't overwhelm the other finer sounds, i tentatively grabbed them expecting to have to return them.I was HAPPILY disappointed. These sounded like nothing i had ever heard before. If you like really LOUD music, these aren't for you, but as far as being FULL sounding, and being able to pick out the FINER elements in a piece, these proved themselves without a shadow of a doubt.They are not noise CANCELLING but they still reduce outside sounds substantially.The audio bleed is almost non-existent. You can have your iPod or Zune up to nearly max and only barely be audible to people nearby. I can jam in the middle of class and no one even notices, (just the sound, they are still quite visible so be careful ;P  ).The cord is quite long which is a double edged sword. You can plug it into your computer and sit 10+ feet away with little discomfort, but when you are walking around, the cord is quite difficult to manage. I just stuff as much of it as i can in my pocket, and hold it there while i walk. Definitely not suitable for running or exercise unless the cord is secured on your person some way.I've had these for over a year I think, and the pads are only just beginning to wear, but that is easy to replace.These headphone are actually very comfortable despite their appearance. It took some getting used to, but i am able to wear them for hours with little to no discomfort.Really the only thing i worry about is the placement of the little cable that attaches to each headphone. They give these a lot of slack so that the headphones have free rotation about the horizontal pivot, but i'm always afraid i won't be paying attention and i'll slip the little cable between the headphone and it's stabilizing bar where it would get caught and maybe even cut that cable. This has not even come close to happening while I've had them, but it's always in the back of my mind.Last but not least, be very careful with the jack. I'm sure it can take natural wear and tear, but if you step on it accidentally like i did and bend it, the right earphone will not work. I have to wiggle the jack a little bit to get them both to work again every once in a while. I would never have had to do that, if i'd have left them on the table. As far as being tossed around and dropped though, these are surprisingly durable.These are the best sounding headphone i have ever used, (besides Bose but screw that price tag), and my only regret was stepping on them. Them still working after that should be proof enough. 5 stars, absolutely recommend to those who LOVE music.
summary: After Years of Poor Quality Headphones, These Were Unbelievable!

reviewText: If anyone tells you this are bad headphones they are lying to you big time! This are some pretty good pair of headphonesPros:Sound is quite amazing everything pretty vivid on them a lil to high on the high freqs but its okay i like them!They dont hurt your ears or crush your ears, you can wear them nicely for a few hours (not more than 2 without removing them a lil bit for your ears to fresh out)VERY WELL MADE its aluminium not cheap plastic like headphones this days, feels pretty sturdy and look quite coolComes with a carrying bag which is fake leather or something doesnt feel that good but its a plus so you can carry your headphones around, they also fold so its easier to carryIsolation is amazing at even half the full volume it doesnt leak at allCons:Dont wear them for more then 2 hours in a row without taking them off a few minutes Thats itIm really happy with them i recommend it to anybody who wants to listen his music how it should

I didn't find them comfortable for long use at all, hurt my ears, made them red by pressing them against my head too much. I have a hearing problem so I can't really comment on the quality, other than to say I didn't notice a problem with it.

V6 is a great monitor headphone, it is almost balance----not quite balance.I bought this to hear my vocal when I recording. It worked well, cos I didn't got any (may be just a little) noise when I recording vocal.But! I won't used it to do my monitoring, cos this is just a headphone, If you have to use a headphone to do your monitoring, I suggest you to buy a AKG K702 or bayer dynamic DT770/880 , anyway , the best way to do your monitoring is use monitor use speakers.Anyway, it's a great closed monitor headphone, you can trust it when you try to hear your vocal during the recording, no noise!Also a good choice for hifi~ If you have to use a headphone to do your monitoring and your budget is tight, you can try this one, or ATH-M30/50, want a better choice? Then go get a K702 or DT770/880. The best way? Get monitor speakers.
summary: Great choice for moniter headphones, but not the best

reviewText: I got the MDR-V6 as a gift and have had it for half a year.The sound quality is best of all headphones I've used.It's a bit uncomfortable because I wear prescription glasses. I have to take it off and relief my head after half hour's listening. But it's just a minor inconvenience.People who don't have eye glasses should have no issue at all.
If you don't want to spend a lot, and want quality headphone, then this is the head phone for you.The only complaint I have is that it becomes uncomfortable after extensive wear, over 4 hrs.
summary: Great headphone for a reasonable price

reviewText: Here is a simple test: Get out your Watermark CD by Enya. Select first track.  Forward at about 0:55 min. Play. DID YOU HEAR THAT? Yes, that! Yes, that low rumbling noise, the one that made you take off your headphones and check if the building is perhaps shaking.  No, that wasn't an earthquake -- its only your headphones.I must have heard the same track a thousand times before, mostly while I'm working -- I know it so well that I can use it to pace myself, almost let myself get absorbed in my task.  This time it gave me a pause, and a completely new appreciation of the whole album. Simply FANTASTIC!
summary: Fantastic sounds I never heard before but were aways there

reviewText: Back in 1991 I was originally looking at the MDR-V6 headphone from Sony, they were $129 back then. I eventually went with the MDR-V5 unit to save a few bucks. Just this past week, 18 years later, the MDR-V5 broke after falling off the edge of my computer. The phones still work but the left earpiece doesn't remain attached. It is a testament to the quality of build for the hadphones. I figured it was a sign to move on, but what should I get? The MDR-V5 were no longer available. Time to revisit the MDR-V6.Well, I couldn't be happier. I wish I has purchased these 18 years ago instead of the V5s. The earpiece covers my ears and rests comfortably on my head. The cord is coiled instead of straight and the sound quality is a nice flat curve. Ideal for studio monitoring. There is no over-amping of bass and no artificial high-end, just plain honest headphones. I also enjoy that they come with a pretty decent leatherette carrying case. The headphones fold up nicely to save space.The only negative is that back when they were producing these in the 80s and 90s they came with gold connectors. The new versions do not, however I kept the gold connector from my V5s so I'm still pretty happy.I did compare these to the professional version of this headphone MDR-7506. Why spend the extra cash simply for a longer warranty? I couldn't justify spending the extra money. I am very happy with my purchase thus far.

First pair I bought got stolen outta my car, somebody smashed my window and took my bag that held it :(Anyway, first pair sounded great.I bought another pair, there was an extremely disappointing crackle in one of the headphones from a low frequency.  This made me extremely annoyed/angry/disappointed.  I cannot stand bad crap, and I hate to give bad product reviews. But I had to send it back and now I will look for a different company brand, probably for the rest of my life.

I don't know whether or not it's the MDR-V700DJ's 50-mm drivers or the MDR-V6's 40-mm drivers that makes the slight difference in sound.  Both of these are EXCELLENT headphones.  Although the MDR-V6 are an EXCELLENT choice and an industry standards, I thought the sound was a tad bit less full sounding than the MDR-V700DJ's.  It may just be that the sound pressure level (?) was greater on the MDR-V700's since they have larger drivers.  I am very impressed with BOTH headphones, and I will most likely be doing the mastering of my musical projects with both headphones, as well as with my monitoring speakers (Event Project Studio 8 monitors, excellent!).

These headphones are great. The quality is amazing, and the sound is crisp and clear. The style is professional and mature, not flashy. After trying on my friends' headphones like Beats, Skullcandys, or DNAs, I've always felt that the Sony MDR-V6's were better. They give you the sound that music artists want you to hear. (Most recording studios use these headphones or the MDR 7506 which I haven't tried yet)The sturdiness of these headphones are amazing. I've stepped on them, sat on them, dropped them. And they're still fine.If you're looking for affordable, high-quality headphones you MUST get these or the MDR7506's.
summary: I've had these for 3 years. STILL STRONG!

reviewText: Great item , I love it !!!!

These headphones have lasted me about 4 years of dropping, snagging, and all types of abuse without a drop in sound quality. My only complaint is that eventually the headphone cushions shed and you get black stuff all over you so I recommend purchasing the more expensive replacements that do not shed on you through amazon. It's a bit pricy but worth it because those things last (the earbud replacements). It took a little bit getting use to the weight, it leaks a bit of sound, but other than that the sound is amazing, the headphone is extremely tough, and the cord is long as hell.Definitely recommend these to go with them:Beyerdynamic EDT 250 Velour Padded Earcushions for DT250, DT280, Sony MDR7506 and V6 Headphones (Pair)
summary: Most durable and toughest headphones ever

reviewerName: Yo'el A. Erez ".i xu do tavla fo la .lojban."
reviewText: These are great. I received them as a gift after doing several days of research looking for the best headphones I could get under 100 dollars.The Sony MDR-V6 are super comfortable, I wear them for hours on end listening to music on my computer. They have amazing sound quality and get loud enough to use as miniature speakers.But on top of all that is one of the best features: I live in a very small house, and my parents are usually sitting right behind me reading, or watching TV (my computer is in my living room). Even with them so close I can listen to my music loud enough to become completely immersed, and they can barely hear any, if any, sound leak at all.Something interesting to note is that my own voice is muffled when I have the headphones on, but anyone else speaking I can hear loud and clear. Unless, that is, any music is playing. In which case no outside noise gets in, and practically none gets out (unless you have your music very loud. If it's loud enough to be easily heard outside of these headphones I fear for your hearing). So great sound isolation.All in all, for the price especially, these are the best. They seem quite solid and unlikely to break, and even if they do 70 dollars is really not very much money to spend for something this great. I really can't recommend these enough. I mean, seriously, these are good enough that I decided to write a review for them. Which is saying a lot for me since I've purchased many products and no matter how much I loved them I've never written a review.If you buy these I can pretty much guarantee you won't be disappointed.

I've had my MDR-V6's so long, I can't remember when I bought them.  At that time, they were highly recommended.  They still are.  That should tell you something.  Second recommendation:  Do you watch any concerts via DVD?  Ever notice performers wearing a traditional set of headphones?  Those pros are often wearing MDR-V6's;  they're distinctive, with a red horizontal stripe across the back of each driver.Two issues: Vinyl coating that flakes off the ear cups; when it happens, just peel the rest off.  The fuzzy fabric beneath ends up being more comfortable than the vinyl, since it 'breathes' and your ears stay cooler.Electrostatic discharge (zaps to your ears, in a dry wintry environment);  I fixed that, by removing one ear cup, and attached a fine brass wire loop that I grounded to the neutral wire that serves the L & R drivers.  This fine wire shows / is visible inside the ear cup.  In use, this rests on my ear (not detectable as pressure on the ear) and constantly drains off any static electricity buildup.  Bottom line: no more zaps;So, ya want GREAT headphones?  Buy 'em and enjoy 'em.
summary: MDR-V6: It doesn't get better than this

reviewText: These headphones have it all in my opinion. Sound, comfort, build quality, tried and true design, reasonable price. You will hear details in your music that you haven't heard before. Enjoy.
Comfortable cups. Long and durable cord. Bought them for my husband who likes to lay down on the couch and listen to his music.
It's really really a excellent headphones. I had a very nice music trial with it! Even though its outlook is not fashion as those new serial products.
Build quality is amazing, sound quality is amazing, price is beautiful. The only issue is the pads rip and flak easily and the cables above the earphones get jammed in the hinge sometimes. Worth it.

I've had both the 7506 and these.  I'm not saying that I can't tell the difference, because I haven't listened to them side by side.  But I'm so  happy with these that I can't imagine that I needed any of the "betterness" that the 7506s provided. I listen to Dj BabyAnne and Drumcell and Pan Pot on these things and I often think to myself "these are some nice headphones".

I have used these headphones for a few months now and I felt it was time to finally write a review. I have used them for listening to music, watching videos, and playing computer games. The audio quality is very balanced and if anything the sound feels a little light or thin, but if you add bass through an equilizer, it will come through. They are extremely comfortable and I can wear them for long periods of time. I was impressed at first with how much they also deaden any external noise, too. The cord should be long enough for any setting and the storage bag is nice enough. Overall, I don't regret this purchase at all and I would recommend them to a friend.

Super happy with the product. Very happy I bought it online rather then at the Sony store. I found that you need to set your equalizer to drop the middles -20% and boost the high just a touch 10% to get them to sound great. But YMMV.

These headphones are exquisite. They have changed my experience of listening to music greatly, as I have heard small intricacies in the sound that I had never noticed before. They are very comfortable and very durable, with a frame consisting mostly of metal. The sound quality is comparable to a pair of headphones that you would get for triple the price. The bass is also quite good. For studio work or just listening to your favorite music, you can't go wrong with these.
summary: Excellent Headphones for a Great Price

reviewText: Besides the fact this came out of a brand new box and with awesome packaging, it is an excellent product. I've been looking for a nice pair of headphones for a near year now and was surprised with how compact these were along with their quality of sound and ease of use.I have a good feeling judging from other reviews and my own experience so far that this is a keeper.02/27/13: Definitely a keeper! Almost 3yr

I've owned the MDR-V6 since 09 and the sound quality is still as awesome as the day I bought them. My only gripes would be is that the pads came unattached about a year ago and now I have to keeping putting them back on which is kind of a nuisance. Also sometimes I have to twist the input jack to make the right ear work.

I owned the originals a couple of decades ago and was very pleased with them. These are virtually the identical head phones. My only complaint is that the very supple ear covers had a small slit right near the edge. This does not take away from my listening experience, so I still gave them 5 stars. The sound quality is still excellent, full range and neutral. I will always own a set of these. I was planning to buy the Beyerdynamic EDT 250 ear cushions anyway.

I have had a pair of these headphones for about 20 years. I have just bought another pair of these.  Before I bought my second pair, I tried Bose and Sennheiser headphones.  Some of them cost more than $300 per pair, but nothing beats these old Sony headphones in sound quality.

Fantastic value - even at the non-sale price.I use these at my desk all day at the office.  They are comfortable for long time wear, and the sound quality is phenomenal (no amp necessary w/ iPhone).  Their range is even wide enough to cover music like dubstep if this is your cup of tea.I use them with my iPhone 4, and my only complaint is that the cord is quite long and heavy and has pulled my phone off the desk once or twice.  And of course, I'd love if the cord was detachable (which it is not) so I could add an iPhone remote.But frankly, they are not made to be used with the iPhone as I do, so I can not give any negative rating because they do the job very well.  I just hope that if someone was looking to use these in a similar fashion, they can take note of my review.Happy listening.- Zak
summary: Unbeatable for the price - not perfect for iPhone.

reviewText: Got these headphones yesterday. There's really no comparison in sound to any of the earbuds I've been using in the past few years, these are exactly what I needed, I can study in my apartment without hearing my roommate's TV in the other room. They get a bit sweaty after a few hours but that's expected of over-the-ear headphones, and even so, they're not unbearably hot.

These are excellent sounding, consistently performing, highly durable, and a wise purchase. If you are looking for larger studio monitor style cans these should be closely considered alongside the much more expensive models available. Usually I do not write reviews of things I purchase, but after more than 18 months of continuous and varied use, I would like to contribute my opinion on what I consider to be one of the best pieces of electronics I've owned.Highly Recommended.
These have good sound and they are very comfortable to wear for long period of time. I am not saying they are the best but they are worth the money.

This is probably the best money I have ever spent on. I originally bought a pair of V6 at Best Buy ten years ago. YES, ten years later they are still functioning well except the ear pad falling off and I replaced the ear pad. It sounds still amazing compare to a lot of phones I got in recent years - Bose, even compare to B&W.... This is definitely worth the SONY brand. Highly recommended!
summary: Still the Best Headphone After Ten Years!

reviewText: excellent sound, of course these lack the base that we have in the new headphone we have now but i'll still pick these over a beat or bose.the only thing i don't like is the long very long wire which make them more for home use headphone.

These headphones lasted 2 years total.  The included muffs only lasted 1 year before they started slipping off very often and flaking.  I bought a replacement for $20 and I thought I would be good.  All of a sudden the left speaker stopped working, 2 years after the purchase date.  I'm not wasting my time with any more sony trash.  Save yourself some time and go with a better brand.
I use these to monitor the mix for my wife's band and our son's band.  The recordings are very faithful to the original mix.

Very good pair of headphones! 40mm driver gets the job done. I was little hesitant seeing that these model of headphones are kind of out of date compared today's technology, but it still produces the same or better quality than most "big named" headphone brands. Very balanced sound, i have owned a pair of beats earbuds and these can compete with those. Could use a slight bass boost, but there are other models out there made by Sony that resolves this issue. (Shouldn't be a problem if you have your own mixer settings on your soundcard). The cord is not too short, not too long...perfect for desktop PC usage, but may become tangled while using a laptop. It does get uncomfortable after a few hours. Also, very nice packaging.Overall very pleased...I give it 5 for sound quality.

I compared these to the Bose Triport which go for an average of $50 more retail and I have to say, these headphones have impressive sound for the price.  Another plus is these are surprisingly very comfortable to wear.The voice coil is long and unobtrusive, and the carrying case is a very convenient plus.

Bought this item for use at the office at my cube.  The sound production is very good.  I've only tried it through my phone's music player using high bitrate mp3's so not exactly the best source, so I'm not going to dig too deep into sound quality.  I'll just say that I am happy with the sound production.On the comfort side, the cups are pretty comfortable.  I've repeatedly worn these for an hour or so at a time and have not had any discomfort from my ears.  The only slight discomfort I experienced was from the head band.  I wish there was a little more padding so the band conformed more to my head.  As it is, the band makes a pressure point at the top of my head which can be discomforting after awhile.  But that could just be the shape of my head.In terms of manufacturering, the product feels quality made, from the band all the way down to the end of the plug.  Overall, I'm happy with the purchase.
